name: Bellbrae War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Bellbrae War Memorial is located in the grounds of Bellbrae Primary School. The stone cairn list the names of twenty-nine fallen and returned soldiers who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Benalla War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Benalla War Memorial, located in the botanical gardens on Bridge Street, was established April 15th 1922. The memorial comprises of a statuary monument of a digger standing at ease. It lists a total of 199 soldiers who fell in the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Bendigo War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Bendigo War Memorial Obelisk, located outside the Bendigo Soldiers' Memorial Institute Memorial, commemorates conflicts after the First World War, including the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam and Kuwait.

name: Benjeroop Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Benjeroop Memorial Gates consist of stone pillars and wrought iron gates that serve as an entranceway to Benjeroop Public Hall. The memorial commemorates those that served in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Bentleigh War Memorial Fountain
description: <FONT size=2>The Bentleigh War Memorial is an ornamental fountain located in the Memorial Gardens. It was unveiled on the 25th of July 1920, with a marble scroll listing the names of those who served in the First World War. A bronze plaque was added with the dates of the Second World War, Malaya, Vietnam and Borneo.

name: Berriwillock War Memorial
description: The Berriwillock War Memorial, on Taverner Street, comprises of a soldier statue on a columned pedestal. The monument was unveiled on the 6th of May 1920 and commemorates those that served in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: Berwick War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Berwick War Memorial, on High Street, is a stone pillar monument that commemorates the First World War and the Second World War. The monument sits on a low stone platform and has white ornamental lion resting in front of it.

name: Beulah Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Beulah Memorial Gates serve as the entranceway to the sports ground in Deakin Street. They comprise of large stone pillars with wrought iron gates. Built in 1928, the gates list the names of eighty-six fallen and returned soldiers of the First World War.There is also a small rock monument at the centre of the gates with a plaque for the Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Birchip War Memorial
description: The Birchip War Memorial is located in Soldiers' Memorial Park, which was established on 22nd May 1931. The memorial comprises of a cenotaph with gold letter inscriptions of sixty-two soldiers who fell in the First World War. A plaque was added for the 50th Anniversary of the Second World War, Korea, Vietnam and the 90th year Anniversary since the Anzac landing at Gallipoli. The Soldier's Memorial Park, originally named Birchip Shire Soldiers Memorial Park, also features large Moreton Bay Fig Trees.

name: Mount Evelyn Avenue of Honour
description:
On 1st November 1987, a memorial plaque and flagstaff was erected to replace the Mount Evelyn Avenue of Honour which was no longer intact. The plaque and flagstaff honour 35 residents who served in the First World War.

name: Cheltenham Avenue of Honour
description:
The Cheltenham Avenue of Honour was planted on July 28th 1917 to commemorate those who served in the First World War. The idea for the avenue was initiated by G. Livesley of the Cheltenham Progress Association in June 1917. The original plan was to plant 120 trees from Centre Dandenong Road down Point Nepean Road towards Mentone. It was also decided the Avenue would feature native trees with a timber guard and brass plate with the name of the volunteer. Money for the Avenue was raised through public subscription with each tree costing ten shillings and six pence.

The fundraising was successful receiving enough money for 142 trees. It was then debated at length in what order the trees would be planted, some suggested it should start with those who enlisted first. Following that reasoning, the first tree to be planted at the ceremony was dedicated to A. Fisher. However, a week later it was discovered that J. Warburton was in fact the first district serviceman to enlist.

At the opening ceremony of the Avenue "God Save the King" was played and then followed by C. H. Fairbank, the president of the Progress Association introducing O.R. Snowball, a local politician and member of the Legislative Assembly of the Victorian Parliament. Fairbank praised the avenue of honour and also urged parents to allow their sons to enlist.

Snowball then planted the first tree on the corner of Centre Dandenong and Point Nepean roads attaching the name of A. Fisher to the tree guard. Six weeks after the ceremony Livesley wrote to the Moorabbin News to report that 199 trees had been planted, including nine trees without name plates to leave room for future volunteers.

Since 1917, Point Nepean Road has been reconstructed several times, transforming from a two lane road to an eight lane highway. Today there is no physical evidence that the Avenue existed. However the names of the men who served are recorded on the two memorial broken columns in the memorial garden behind the RSL Club Rooms in Centre Dandenong Road.

name: Castlemaine War Memorial (Cemetery)
description: <FONT size=2>The Castlemaine War Memorial in the Cemetery has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Caulfield Memorial Stone
description: <FONT size=2>The Caulfield Memorial stone is located in the rose garden in Caulfield Park. Originally the stone marked the North Road Avenue of Honour which no longer exists. The memorial lists the names of 298 individuals who died in the First World War.

name: Caulfield War Memorial
description: The Caulfield War Memorial, on Hawthorn Road in Caulfield Park, was established in 1930. It commemorates those who served in the First and Second World Wars. The front inscription reads: "This memorial was erected in honor of those citizens of Caulfield who volunteered their services in the Great War 1914 - 1918. May it forever remind us that we enjoy a liberty maintained and enriched by the sacrifice of many noble lives upon this stone is now inscribed our gratitude for those citizens of Caulfield who defended the cause of freedom in the Second World War 1939 - 1945."

name: Cavendish Memorial Gateway
description: <FONT size=2>The Cavendish Memorial Gateway marks the entrance to the memorial park. The gateway was erected to commemorate the First World War.

name: Cavendish WWII Memorial
description: The Cavendish WWII Memorial is located in the park near the Memorial Hall, on the north east corner of Scott and Barker Streets. The monument comprises of a tapering pylon of six dark grey granite blocks. It has two hollowed granite planter boxes at the sides and two shallow bluestone steps in front. Below a simple incised and gilded cross there is a dedicatory inscription to those who served from Cavendish and district during the Second World War, with a list of eight names below. The lettering is also gilded. The memorial is placed diagonally in the north-west corner of the park.

name: Charlton War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Charlton War Memorial, on High Street, comprises of a soldier statue resting on a large pedestal. It lists the names of sixty local residents that served in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam.

name: Chelsea War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Chelsea War Memorial is a cenotaph situated in front of the Town Hall. It commemorates local residents that fought in all conflicts.

name: Chatsworth War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Chatsworth War Memorial is situated in a small reserve in the centre of the now relatively dormant township of Chatsworth, at a site known locally as 'Fiveways.' The memorial comprises of an obelisk dedicated to those who fought in the First World War and was erected c.1920s. The Memorial is enclosed with a wire fence but is unfortunately in poor condition.

name: Moorabbin WWI Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Moorabbin WWI Memorial consists of two broken stone pillars and inset stone cross formerly located in the native garden setting of Cheltenham Park. Established in April 1925, the pillars commemorate local residents of Moorabbin and district who served in the First World War. The pillars have since been relocated to the rear of the R.S.L., next to the WWII Memorial.

name: Cheltenham Boer War Memorial
description:
The Cheltenham Boer War Memorial, located in Cheltenham Park, was originally situated on the north-west corner of Nepean Highway and Chesterville Roads, Moorabbin. The memorial was established in 1904 and names 47 fallen and returned residents from Moorabbin who served in the Boer War. Of the 47 names, four died; one at Rustenburg, one at Elandshock, one at Wilmansrust, while the place of death of the fourth trooper is not given.

The memorial comprises of a polished red granite obelisk sits on a black basalt base. Originally it had two handsome circular glass enclosed gas lamps and a bronze drinking fountain as part of its construction but these are now lost. The Memorial still rests within Cheltenham Park but was relocated to Park Road.

name: Chetwynd War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Chetwynd World War One memorial comprises of an obelisk located on the main road of town.

name: Chewton Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>Chewton Memorial Gates serve as the entranceway to Chewton Soldiers Memorial Park. Located along the Pyrenees Highway and Fryers Road, the gates commemorate those who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Clayton Avenue of Honour
description:
The Clayton Avenue of Honour was planted in 1918 to commemorate locals who served in the First World War. The Avenue is located on Carnish Road starting from the railway crossing and stretching east. It was planted with Portugal Oaks (Quercus lustanica) but the entire northern row of trees are missing while the remaing trees have been pruned due to powerlines.

name: Kiewa Avenue of Honour
description:
The Kiewa Avenue of Honour was planted in 1920with 100 Eucalyptus, Elmand Oak trees to commemorate the First World War. The avenue is no longer intact with only a few trees remaining.

In Australia, commemorative trees have been planted in public spaces since the late nineteenth century. name: Kingston Avenue of Honour
description:
The Creswick Avenue, along the Creswick-Newstead Road, was planted to commemorate the First World War. The avenue was opened on December 18th 1927 by Captain T. Parkin along with a memorial obelisk, unveiled by Brigadier General Elliott, DSO. Elliot addressed his audience in familiar patriotic tones and stressed the continuing links between Australia and the United Kingdom.

The Avenue contained 286 trees each one representing each man or woman from the shire who served in the military forces between 1914 and 1918. Each tree originally bore a tablet with the name of a volunteer but over the years some have faded or been erased. Graham's 'Early Creswick' contains an alphabetical listing of all those remembered in the avenue with the number of each tree originally bearing their individual names. The trees consisted of Dutch Elms (Ulmus x hollandica) and stand at a height of 16 metres. A stone plaque reads: "Shire of Creswick Avenue of Honour a tribute to the men and women who served in the Great War 1914-1918.

The granite obelisk sits on a pedestal, protected by granite post and wire fence. As well as the inscription dedicating the Avenue of Honour, a plaque has been added to commemorate -

"The Service of Our Men and Women in World War 1, World War 2, And in the Borneo, Malaya, Korea and Vietnam Campaigns. 'Only Those Deserve Freedom Who Are Prepared to Defend it.' Lest We Forget."

name: Christmas Hills War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Christmas Hills War Memorial is located in the Christmas Hills Memorial Park on Eltham and Ridge Roads. The white stone obelisk was unveiled on December 10th 1921 and dedicated to local men who served in the First World War.

name: Clayton War Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Clayton War Memorial Swimming Pool comprises of a granite block memorial at the entrance to the Pool, dedicated to the memory of the Second World War. The memorial was unveiled in April 1990 to mark the 75th Anniversary of Anzac Day.

name: Clunes WWI War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Clunes War Memorial, on Fraser and Service Streets, was established on April 25th 1925. The memorial consists ofa soldier sculpted of marble, mounted on a granite plinth; with the names of Clunes' First World War fallen inscribed on the plinth. Of the 300 men and women from Clunes and district who served in the First World War, forty- five were killed. The memorial is surrounded by a decorative cyclone metal fence with four timber posts.

name: Cobram Memorial Clock Tower
description: <FONT size=2>The Cobram Memorial Clock Tower, on Punt Road and Bank Street, is made up of rocks and characterised by two plaques which list the names of those locals who fell in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Coburg War Memorial
description: The Coburg War Memorial, located in Bell Street outside the City Hall, comprises of a granite cenotaph. The memorial was built in 1924 to commemorate the First World War. It has since been rededicated to the Second World War, Korea, Borneo, Malay, Vietnam and UN Peacekeeping missions.

name: Cockatoo War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Cockatoo War Memorial comprises of a stone pillar monument located outside the RSL Hall. The memorial was established to commemorate local residents who served in the First World War, a plaque was then added with the names of those who served in the Second World War.

name: Coimadai War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Coimadai War Memorial, on the Diggers Rest-Toolern Vale Road, comprises of a multi-coloured slate cairn. The memorial was established in April 1973 to commemorate citizens of Coimadai who served their country in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Cohuna Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Cohuna Swimming Pool, on Tennis Court Road, was built as a tribute to the men and women of the Cohuna District who served in the Second World War.

name: Rokewood Junction Avenue of Honour
description:
The Rokewood Avenue of Honour, of some 67 trees, was planted in 1918. The trees were supplied by residents and planted by voluntary labour. Further research is required on the exact location and condition of this Avenue.

name: Coonooer Bridge War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Coonooer Bridge War Memorial, near Yeungroon-Coonooer Road, comprises of a stone obelisk that commemorates locals who served in the First and Second World Wars. Also situated next to the memorial is a gun dating from the First World War.

name: Corack War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Corack War Memorial, located beside the Corack Memorial Hall, comprises of a stone obelisk. It lists the names of locals who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Corryong War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Corryong War Memorial is situated in Memorial Gardens on Hanson and Donaldson Streets. The memorial, a monumental stone obelisk, was established in November 1926. The monument lists the names of 83 fallen locals killed during during the First and Second World Wars.

name: Cranbourne Cenotaph
description:
Cranbourne Cenotaph, located at Greg Clysedale Square, is a large memorial located on Sladen Street. Established on the 29th of August 1939, it commemorates locals from the community who fought in the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

At the top of the face of the memorial is an art deco sculpture in bas-relief, which features a centrally placed angel figure flanked by figures standing shoulder to shoulder wielding long rod-like objects. At the top on the rear side, an engraved panel has been added that shows three servicemen and one servicewomen.

The exact date of the Cranbourne War Memorial is not known. Reputedly, it was originally constructed c.1919 when it was sited at the top of the hill in High Street at the commencement of the Honour Avenue that was planted in the same year. However, the design of the memorial would suggest a later date (possibly post-World War II). It is known that after being damaged by a milk truck in 1949 it was repaired and moved to a site outside the Shire Offices. An official ceremony to mark its restoration on the new site was held in 1952. In the 1990s it was relocated to its present site in Greg Clydesdale Square.

name: Creswick War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Creswick War Memorial consists of a column and ball monument enclosed by a stone pillar fence with steel piping. The structure was built to commemorate locals who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Crib Point War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Crib Point War Memorial comprises of a stone cenotaph with plaques. Located along Stony Point Road and Park Road, outside HMAS Cerberus, it commemorates individulas who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Borneo, Malaya and Vietnam (men of HMAS Tingira).

name: Cressy Memorial Gateway
description: <FONT size=2>The Cressy Memorial Gateway, in the Recreation Reserve, consists of brick memorial pillars and wrought iron gates. The memorial was built in memory of local men who fought in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Croyden War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Croyden War Memorial is a stone obelisk located at the roundabout at Kent Avenue, Croydon Road, Railway Crescent and Wicklow Avenue, Croydon. The memorial, fenced with pillars and chain, was established on October 27th 1919. It lists the names of 76 fallen and returned individuals from the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Culgoa War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Culgoa War Memorial is a red brick structure that commemorates all conflicts particularly the Second World War. The memorial was donated by the Culgoa Lions Club in 1996.

name: Curyo War Memorial
description: Curyo War Memorial comprises of a stone obelisk located on the main road into town. The memorial commemorates locals who served in the First World War. This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Dandenong Cenotaph and Pillars of Freedom
description: <FONT size=2>The Dandenong Cenotaph and Pillars of Freedom Memorials are located at Palm Place, Clow Street and Princes Highway, Dandenong. The large stone stone cenotaph and Pillars of Freedom were unveiled together on June 25th 1995. They commemorate locals who fought in the Boer War, the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Darlington War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Darlington War Memorial, at the corner of Hall and Ware Streets, consists of a stone obelisk. The structure is fenced with stone pillars and piping. The memorial commemorates the local people who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Daylesford War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Daylesford War Memorial consists of a stone column and ball structure located in Bourke Square. It commemorates locals who served in the First and Second World War.

name: Dean Primary School Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Dean Memorial Gates, on Ballarat Road, were built to commemorate locals who served in the First and Second World Wars. The Gates erected by the ex-students and residents and unveiled by Insp. J.S.B. Bacon on January 27th 1951.

name: Alphington WWI Memorial
description: Located in Alphington Park, the Alphington War Memorial is a marble statue of a First World War soldier standing at ease on a grey granite pedestal. Tbe north face of the memorial reads, "Erected By The Residents In Grateful Remembrance Of The Men Of Alphington Who Fought In The Great War 1914 - 1919. May We Be Worthy Of Them." The memorial lists the names 105 fallen and returned soldiers. It was unveiled by his Excellency Lord Forster P.C. G.C.M.G.Governor General of Australiaon September 25th 1921.

name: Digby Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Digby War Obelisk is a small memorial marking the entrance to the Avenue of Honour.

name: Digby Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>Located near the Mechanics' Institute, the Digby Memorial Wall is adorned with plaques bearing the names of locals who died in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Donald War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Donald War Memorial is a large, elaborately ornamented monument with soldier statue. Erected in 1921, the monument lists the names of 53 fallen soldiers from the First and Second World Wars.

name: Doncaster Memorial Plantation
description: <FONT size=2>The Doncaster Memorial Plantation located in Zerbe's Reserve replaces the original Avenue of Honour which was dedicated to locals who served in the First World War. Amongst the plantation, a square granite monument records the dedication on April 20th 1975.

name: Doncaster War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Doncaster War Memorial was established on August 13th 2000 outside the Doncaster RSL. The memorial comprises of a wall with a series of plaques naming 386 locals (fallen and returned) who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam. The wall includes plaques relocated from the memorial formerly located on the facade of the Athenaeum Hall.

name: Drik Drik Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Drik Drik Memorial Gates, located at the entrance to the former site of the Drik Drik Primary School, are dedicated to the memory of First and Second World Wars. The memorial is characterised by two concrete pillars featuring lists of those who served and a wrought iron gate in the centre.

name: Drysdale War Memorial
description:
The Drysdale War Memorial is located in the grounds of the former Drysdale Courthouse. It is a granite obelisk sitting on a plinth characterised by a rising sun insignia. The monument was unveiled at a large gathering by Mr. Lester in 1919. The monument is engraved with the names of soldiers from the Drysdale area who enlisted the in the First World War, never to return home. The names of servicemen who died in the Second World War were also added to the monument. The First World War inscription reads,

"In Memory of Drysdale of Drysdale Soldiers who fell in the Great European War 1914-1919

Anderson AJ

Bennan FR

Bennan RH

Carlson TJ

Clarke TL

Davis RS

Foster LI

Lyons C

Matthews H

Moffat F

Thompson EW

Turner SC

Waterson NS

Wiffen FC."

name: Drouin War Memorial
description: The Drouin War Memorial is situated within a small park on the south side of Princes Way within the Drouin commercial centre. Sculpted by R. Ewers, the memorial comprises of a Second World War infantryman wearing a slouch hat, cape and pouches, and holding an Owen Gun in his right hand. The statue sits on a concrete and brick paver base, with flagpoles on the northeast and northwest sides. It was unveiled in November 1949 to commemorate 102 individuals who served in the First and Second World Wars. In front of the soldier is a smaller polished red granite block with a sloping top dedicated to service in Korea, Malaya, South Vietnam and Peacekeeping Missions.

name: Dromana War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Dromana War Memorial consists of a granite wall flanked by two small pillars, built in memory of the First and Second World Wars. The structure stands in the old shire grounds on Verdun Street and the Nepean Highway.

name: Dunolly WWI Memorial Pillar
description: Dunolly WWI Memorial Pillar, located in front of the Town Hall on Broadway,was unveiled on November 18th 1921. The pillar is topped by an urn and rests on a square concrete plinth, which lists the names ninety-four locals who died serving during the First World War.

name: Lakes Entrance Avenue of Honour
description:
The Lakes Entrance Avenue of Honour was planted in 1924 to commemorate the lives of twenty-six residents killed in the First World War. The avenue originally resembled an avenue of Cypresses, however during the 1990s the trees were beginning to show signs of over maturity and were thought to pose a safety risk. To preserve the history of the avenue, the Council decided to crop the trees, rather than completely remove them and invited a local "chain saw artist" to develop wood carvings on the remaining stumps. The carvings depict servicemen, nurses, Red Cross workers and local families affected by the First World War. The avenue was rededicated in 1998 after a community project costing $15,000.

In Australia, commemorative trees have been planted in public spaces since the late nineteenth century. Arbor Days were held regularly in most Victorian State Schools during the late 1800s and early 1900s, and numerous trees were planted in parks in Melbourne and throughout Victoria to mark the visits of important and famous people.

This tradition of commemorative planting was continued in 1901 when at the end of the Boer War trees were often planted for each soldier of the district who was killed in South Africa. These plantings, however, rarely consisted of more than two or three trees in each town.

During and after the First World War avenues of honour consisting of trees lining significant streets became a popular form of commemoration. They represented a new egalitarian approach to the commemoration of soldiers where rank was not a consideration: each tree symbolises a person.

Avenues of honour are a uniquely Australian phenomenon. Australians, and in particular Victorians, embraced the idea of planting them more enthusiastically than any other country in the world. Dating from May 1916, the Eurack Avenue of Honour is the earliest known avenue of honour to be planted in Victoria.

By the time of the Second World War avenues of honour had declined in popularity as a means of commemoration. Today it is estimated that over 300 avenues of honour have been planted in Victoria to commemorate service personnel since 1901.

name: Avoca Avenue of Honour
description:
The Avoca Avenue of Honour was initiated by the Australian Natives Association who strongly supported the war effort.The A.N.A. along withthe Arbor Day committee, planted trees in 1918 in Avoca to honour the enlisted men of the First World War. It is located on York Street near the Avoca railway station.

name: Eltham Avenue of Honour
description:
The Eltham Avenue of Honour Avenue comprised of over 100 Hybrid Plane trees (Platanus x acerifolia) symmetrically arranged on either side of Main Road, leading up the rise from Dalton to Brougham Streets.The Avenue was planted after the First World War. However the current trees in the Avenue were planted to replace those planted between 1918-19.

name: Buln Buln Avenue of Honour
description:
The Buln Buln Avenue of Honour consists of English Elm trees planted along Old Sale Road, from Brandy Creek Road to Buln Buln School. Originally 60 trees were planted to commemorate the First World War with a picket fence to protect them. Today 47 of the original trees remain while others have been replaced.

name: Bealiba War Memorial Pillars
description: <FONT size=2>Bealiba War Memorial consists of three granite pillars (formerly gate posts) located in front of the Town Hall. The pillars commemorate those who served in the Second World War.

name: Box Hill War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Box Hill War Memorial, on Whitehorse Road and Station Street, comprises of a soldier statue on a stone pedestal. Established on the 19th of February 1922; the memorial lists the names of ninety-eight soldiers who fell in the First World War. Next to the statue is a small stone monument thatcommemorates those who served in Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Campbells Creek Primary School War Memorial
description:
Campbells Creek Primary School War Memorial is characterised by a granite obelisk set on a large slab of concrete paving, in a grassed and tree setting. It comprises a smooth faced granite column with pointed top resting on a stepped smooth faced granite pedestal, the whole resting on a stepped base of massive rough faced granite blocks. The memorial names the local men who lost their lives in the First and Second World Wars. The dedicatory inscription facing the main road (west face) says that the memorial was 'Erected by the Campbells Creek Returned Soldiers to the memory of their comrades'. A list of seven names is followed by the words 'who paid the supreme sacrifice in the great war 1914-1919. Gone West'.

After the Second World War, a second list of nine names prefaced by the words,'Also to the memory of our comrades' and followed by the words 'Died World War 1939-45', was added to the south face. A separate plaque in tribute to Arthur Rivers Ford, who was blinded in the First World War, was added after his death in 1954. Another tribute plaque, to Allen F. Gabriel MM, was added by the Campbells Creek Memorial Committee, after his death in 1962.

name: Edithvale Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Edithvale Memorial Wall consists of a brick or stone wall, with a plaque commemorating all conflicts.

name: Eildon War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Eildon War Memorial, located in the town centre, comprises of a coloured stone obelisk. The monument commemorates those locals who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Edenhope War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Edenhope War Memorial, on Elizabeth Street, comprises of a soldier statue on a pedestal. The memorial commemorates 114 locals who served (fallen and returned) in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Eldorado Memorial Shelter "Gun House"
description: <FONT size=2>The Eldorado Memorial Shelter shed is the former "Gun House". Situated at crossroads in Main street, the site commemorates the First World War.

name: Elphinstone War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Elphinstone War Memorial comprises of a stone obelisk located in a road reserve near the railway station. The memorial commemorates 32 locals (fallen and returned) who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Eltham War Memorial
description: The Eltham War Memorial, located in front of the Eltham RSL, was established on the 3rd of August 1919. The stone obelisk is features the names of thirty-eight locals who died during the First and Second World Wars. The memorial was moved to the site in the 1960's from its original location on the corner of Main Road and Bridge Street.

name: Ensay War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Ensay War Memorial comprises of a broken stone column on a stepped pedestal. The monument records the names of thirty-three fallen locals of the First and Second World Wars.

name: Epping War Memorial
description: The Epping War Memorial Obelisk was located in the Memorial Hall gardens with metal plaques dedicated to RSL members and locals who served in times of war. It has since been moved to Harvest Home Road.

name: Essendon War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Essendon War Memorial, located in Queen's Park, is a tall sandstone monument established on April 25th 1929 in memory of the First World War. It was then rededicated to all individuals who served in the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam and peacekeeping missions.

name: Essendon World War Two Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Essendon World War Two Memorial is a rock feature located at Highpoint West Shopping Centre. It was established to commemorate all Victorian Anti-aircraft and Searchlight Units utilised in World War Two.

name: Alphington WWII Memorial Fountain
description: The Second World War Memorial, situated in Alphington Park, comprises of a stone fountain and plaque. The metal plaque reads, "This Fountain And Playground are a Tribute From the Citizens of Fairfield And Alphington to the Memory of Those Who Served in The World War 1939-1945. Lest We Forget."

name: Altona War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Altona War Memorial located outside the Civic Offices, is one of only four 'eternal flames' in Australia. The stone memorial stands in front of three flagpoles and commemorates the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Bairnsdale Rowing Club Memorial
description:
The Bairnsdale Rowing Club was founded on 11th November 1872 with Joseph Day as President. The first regatta in March 1873 drew a crowd of four hundred people. A boatshed was then erected in 1888. After 1953, the Annual Regattas did not continue and the Club was disolved in 1965, with the boatshed demolished the following year.

In October 1936, a monument was unveiled by Albert Eli Lind MHR, Minister for Lands and Forests. It comprises of a memorial obelisk dedicated to the fifty-seven enlisted and fallen members of the Bairnsdale Rowing Club, who served with the AIF in the First World War.

name: Ballan War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Ballan War Memorial, outside the Post Office, consists of a column and ball monument. Unveiled on March 27th 1920, it lists the names of three hundred and thirty-seven fallen and returned soldiers. The memorial commemorates those who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Fish Creek War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Fish Creek War Memorial is a granite rock located in lawns in the town centre. The site commemorates individuals who served inthe First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaysia and Vietnam.

name: Flinders War Memorial Seat
description: <FONT size=2>The Flinders War Memorial comprises of a stone seat, lined with pebbles, located along the ocean end of Cook Street. The monument was built in 1922 to commemorate individuals who served in the First World War, names were added for those who served in the Second World War.

name: Fitzroy Memorial Rotunda
description: <FONT size=2>The Fitzroy Memorial Rotunda located in Edinburgh Gardens, St George's Road, was built in August 1925. The site commemorates individuals who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Footscray RSL War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Footscray RSL War Memorial is a stone obelisk located in front of the Footscray RSL in Geelong Road. The memorial commemorates all conflicts.

name: Castlemaine Victory Gardens
description: <FONT size=2>Ornamental gardens with monuments, comfort station, childrens' play equipment, picnic shelters etc adj to former Market Reserve and building.

name: Framlingham War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Framlingham War Memorial commemorates locals who served in the First and Second World Wars. This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Frankston War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Frankston War Memorial, on Davey Street, consists of walls and murals in front of the Civic Centre. The memorial commemorates individuals who served in all conflicts.

name: Second World War Observation Station
description: A Second World War Observation Station was located in Beacon Reserve at Lake Tyers. This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Castlemaine Primary School War Memorial
description: The Castlemaine War Memorial Pillar, on Mostyn Street and Urquhart Street, is located in the grounds of the Castlemaine South Primary School. The memorial commemorates ex-pupils who served in the First World War.

name: Castlemaine War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Castlemaine War Memorial is a ornamental structure located in Mostyn Street in front of the RSL hall. It commemorates those who served in the Boer War, the First World War, the Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam. Nearby is a small monument for Victoria Cross winner Sgt. W. Peeler.

name: Geelong West War Monument
description: <FONT size=2>The Geelong West War Monument comprises of a flagpole erected outside the Town Hall to commemorate the First World War. The base of the flagpole is engraved with the most significant places of the war for Australians: Gallipoli, France and Palestine.

name: Geelong North Vietnam Avenue of Honour
description:
The North Geelong Vietnam War Memorial is located on the corner of Swinburne Street and the Princes Highway. The memorial consists of a polished granite panel inscribed simply with "Vietnam, Together Then, Together Again." The monument marks a Vietnam Veterans' Avenue of Honour officially opened by the Honourable Con Sciacca, Minister for Veterans' Affairs, and CR. Gerry Smith, on 1st October 1995.

name: Geelong Transvaal Square
description: Geelong Transvaal Square,on Eastern Beach Road, has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Gembrook Memorial Cairn
description: The Gembrook War Memorial, on Main Street outside the RSL, comprises of a tiered stone cairn dedicated to Australian servicemen in all conflicts.

name: Tyabb Soldiers Memorial
description: The Tyabb Soldiers Memorial, on the Frankston-Flinders Road, comprises of a grey granite obelisk. The names of those who served in the First World War are chiselled into three of the faces of this pillar. Eight sturdy brick pillars covered in a deep grey stucco and joined by poles surround the monument which stands upon a concrete base. Two north facing bronze plaques also commemorate the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Hastings Soldiers Memorial
description: The Hastings Soldiers Memorial, located in the Foreshore Park on Marine Parade, consists of a granite and marble obelisk with the inscription: "Erected by the residents of East Riding of Frankston and Hastings Shire as a tribute to the men who enlisted, and in memory of those who made the Supreme Sacrifice in the Great War 1914-1919." The obelisk was rededicated to include service in the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam. In total the memorial lists eighty names of soldiers fallen and returned. Alongside the monument is a memorial honouring Victoria Cross winner, George Morby Ingram.

name: Taradale War Memorial
description: The Taradale War Memorial is a grey granite obelisk, surrounded by a rock pillar and steel chain fence. Located in Mineral Springs Park, one hundred metres east of the Calder Highway, it commemorates the service of the citizens of Taradale in the First and Second World Wars, listing them by name and rank. A lone bronze plaque has been added for Private J.C. Boyer who served in Vietnam.

name: Port Melbourne Memorial Drinking Fountain
description: <FONT size=2>The Port Melbourne Memorial Drinking Fountain is a white marble cupola over a granite basin on a bluestone plinth on a two-stepped bluestone base. It is no longer in use as a drinking fountain bet there are still steps on the the south, east and west sides. Supported by four concrete columns and a marble tablet inscribed with: " Australian Commonwealth Military Forces- erected by the Municipality and citizens of Port Melbourne in memory of those who fell in the Great War 1914-1918 for King and Country."

name: Colbinabbin War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Colbinabbin War Memorial comprises of a stone obelisk in parkland in the town. It commemorates locals who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Concongella War Memorial
description: The Concongella War Memorial is located off Landsborough Road in the cemetery drive. At the entrance to the Memorial and Cemetery are two rows of mature pine trees, terminating with the War Memorial. The War Memorial consists of a narrow granite obelisk having an elongated base and stepped plinth. Fence posts and round steel rails define the memorial boundaries. Marble tablets affixed to the memorial list the names of the soldiers who fought and died in the First World War. One tablet also reads, "In Memory of Our Soldiers Who Fell in the Great War 1914-19, Lest We Forget".

name: Merrigum War Memorial Obelisk
description:
The Merrigum War Memorial Obelisk is located in Merrigum Park on Morrisey Street. The memorial was erected to commemorate the ten local men who died during First World War. First erected on a site in the south-east corner of the Recreation Reserve, it was officially unveiled on 29th May 1921. In 1965, it was removed to its present place in the Merrigum Hall Reserve and now features the names of those locals who served in the Second World War.

The memorial comprises of a Harcourt granite obelisk on a rock face granite plinth and sawn bluestone block base. The obelisk features discreet fluted detail and bronze plaques listing the fallen from the War, which are fixed to two sides of the memorial. The site also includes an associated timber flagpole and two trees.

name: Dennington War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Dennington War Memorial is a stone obelisk which names twenty-nine locals who served (fallen and returned) in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Diamond Creek War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Diamond Creek War Memorial comprises of a polished stone column and urn. Established on June 19th 1921, it names thirteen locals that died during the First World War. The Memorial has been relocated from Collins Street and rededicated to all conflicts since the First World War on October 6th 1996.

name: Lubeck Soldiers Memorial Reserve
description: The Lubeck Soldiers Memorial Reserve is located on Horsham Road.

name: Kangaroo Flat Avenue of Honour
description:
The Kangaroo Flat Avenue of Honour, located along the Calder Highway, comprises of Sugar Gums (Eucalyptus cladocalyx). Further research is required on this place.

name: Hurstbridge Avenue of Honour
description:
The Hurstbridge Avenue of Honour was planted in 1918, along Anzac Avenue, to commemorate the First World War. Further research is required on this place.

name: The Great Ocean Road Arch Memorial
description: The Great Ocean Road Arch Memorial marks the start of the road and commemorates those who fought in the First World War. The arch is constructed from timber logs and stone pillars. All along the Great Ocean Road, are numerous structures that honour the memory of those who lost their lives fighting the First World War and in subsequent conflicts. The Road was built over 13 years by up to 3000 returned soldiers.

name: Nathalia War Memorial
description: The Nathalia War Memorial, on Blake and Weir Streets, is a white marble statue mounted on a grey granite columned pedestal, dedicated to the First and Second World Wars. In front of the statue are two polished grey granite slabs resting on a stone flagstone base. The statue resembles a First World War digger standing easy, holding the barrel of a rifle and leaning against a tree trunk. The pedestal is inscribed with the names of those who served and the main inscription reads, "In Memoriam. 'We sleep in many lands that you may live.' Nathalia District Memorial. The Great War 1914-1918. In memory of those who gave their lives for God, King and Country. 1939-1945."

name: Woodhouse-Nareeb War Memorial
description: The Woodhouse-Nareeb War Memorial comprises of two stone cairns that commemorate the Second World War. The cairns were erected by Woodhouse-Nareeb RSL in 1978. Two plaques list servicemen and women of the war of 1939-45. The cairn on the left, specially mentions the nursing sisters who lost their lives in the Java Sea and on Banka Island in 1942. It was dedicated by a survivor of those sisters, Betty Jeffrey. The classic elegy "Lest we Forget" links this memorial, which has little of the classic symbolism, to the broad tradition of commemoration of war dead.

name: Shepparton Showground Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Shepparton Showground Memorial Gates has been idenitfied as a site but requires further research. If you wish to contribute to this record please contact the administrator.

name: Goyura Memorial Reserve
description: The Goyura Memorial Reserve, on Henty Highway, comprises of a memorial cairn. This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Euroa Memorial Trees
description:
The Euroa Memorial Trees are located in the Memorial Garden beside the RSL on Kirkland Avenue, they were relocated from Binney Street. The trees commemorate three Victoria Cross winners who served in the Boer War and the First World War. Lieutenant Fredrick Harold Tubb, was awarded the VC with his mate from Euroa, Private Alexander Stewart Burton, for exceptional bravery at Lone Pine where Burton was killed. The third VC was awarded to Lieutenant Leslie Cecil 'Elsie' Maygar for bravery in the Boer War - Maygar died at Beersheba in 1917.

There are further memorials dedicated to the VC winners on the Hume Highway, witha plaque dedicated to Lieutenant Tubb and aplace dedicated to Lieutenant Maygaras "Maygar's Hill."

Private Alexander Stewart Burton was born at Kyneton, Victoria. The family moved to Euroa and, after attending the state school, Burton followed his father into the firm of A. Miller & Co., working in the ironmongery department. He was a chorister in the Euroa Presbyterian Church, a member of the townband, and was active in sport.

On 18 August 1914, Burton enlisted in the 7th Battalion and embarked for Egypt in October. He landed at Gallipoli in early May. Burton was slightly wounded in action and in July was promoted to lance corporal for having volunteered for and taken part in a dangerous operation; he was later promoted to corporal. Burton was posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross for conspicuous bravery in the trenches at Lone Pine on 9 August. He has no known grave, but his name is commemorated on the Lone Pine memorial.

name: Mordialloc Memorial Cross
description: The Mordialloc War Memorial, located on the Nepean Highway, commemorates the First World War. The memorial resembles a cross mounted on a tiered, granite plinth and lists the names of nineteen fallen local men.

name: Nullawil War Memorial
description: The Nullawil War Memorial, located within Nullawil Park, commemorates the First and Second World Wars. It consists of a flagpole on a granite base that is engraved with the dates of the First and Second World War. In 1995, a plaque was also added for the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Sandford War Memorial
description: The Sandford War Memorial, located on the corner of Burke Street and the Henty Highway, is a granite monument obelisk, commemorating the First and Second World Wars. On each face the names of soldiers who served are listed. The inscriptions read, "In Loving Remembrance of Sandford Men who fought in The Great War 1914-19" and "In Honor of the Men of Sandford who Answered Their Country's Call 1939-45." A plaque was added to commemorate those who served in the Korean War and Vietnam War.

name: The Sheep Hill War Memorial
description: The Sheep Hill War Memorial, located on Sheep hill and Bangerang road, commemorates the First and Second World Wars. The monument consists of a fenced flagpole, the base of which is inscribed with the names of those who served.

name: Bolton Park War Memorial Swimming Pool
description: The Bolton Park War Memorial Swimming Pool is located on the corner of Firebrace and Hamilton streets, Horsham. This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Heywood War Memorial Obelisk
description: The Heywood War Memorial, on Hunter Street, comprises of an obelisk mounted on a granite plinth and surrounded by a concrete post fence. The Memorial includes the names of those who served in the First and Second World Wars. There is also a dedication to those who served in conflicts between 1950- 1973, including Korea, Malaya, Sabah-Sarawak, Malayan Peninsula and Vietnam.

name: Moyston WWII Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Moyston War Memorial comprises of a stone archway commemorating the First and Second World Wars. Maroona and Moyston erected the archway in honour of the district service men and women. The top of the arch was specifically dedicated to the memory of Sgt. E Wilton killed in action, August 25th 1943.

name: Murtoa Avenue of Honour
description:
Further research is required on the Murtoa Avenue of Honour regardingwhich conflict it commemorates.

At the 1902 Annual General Meeting of the Murtoa Progress Association it was reported that among the 533 trees planted in 1901 were 28 kurrajongs]. The kurrajongs were planted in Comyn Street and are looked after by the residents of that street who also donated the trees. A further 28 trees were planted the following year. A postcard postmarked 1903 shows the avenue of young trees in tree guards along Comyn Street.

The avenue of 49 Kurrajongs planted in 1901-02 is located along Comyn Street between the Wimmera Highway and McDonald Street. There are 28 trees along the north side and 21 trees along the south side. A tree measured on the north side, at the intersection of McDonald Street has a trunk circumference (1.4m above ground level) of 1.92m, height 11m and canopy spread 13m. The trunk circumference ranges in size from 1.09m to 1.92m.


Most of the trees are in good condition, exhibiting single trunks and spreading crowns. Some trees on the northern side in the western half have been subjected to powerline clearance. The construction of aerial bundle cables has now reduced the need for severe pruning, except to four trees at the western end where the powerlines are still mounted on cross-arms.

The Kurrajong avenue is historically significant as being the earliest known Kurrajong planting in Victoria, and being amongst the earliest surviving street tree plantings using an Australian native species.

name: Wilsons Promontory Tidal River Memorial Pillar
description:
The Wilsons Promontory Tidal River Memorial Pillar was erected to commemorate the birthplace of the Commando in Australia and in memory of all those Commandos who made the supreme sacrifice in the Second World War. It was dedicated on 16 November 1964 by the Lieutenant Governor of Victoria Lieutenant General Sir Edmund Herring and raised under the auspices of the Commando Association (Victoria), by Australian commandos. The restored memorial was rededicated by the Premier of Victoria, John Brumby, on 18 November 2007.

Military Mission 104, led by Lieutenant Colonel J.C. Mawhood, arrived in November 1940 with the idea of raising and training British style 'special' or 'commando' units, which had proved successful in operating against German-occupied Europe. The Australian Army decided to raise four 'independent' companies and train them at the innocuously named No. 7 Infantry Training Centre at Wilson's Promontory, a national park since 1898. It was an isolated area of high, rugged and heavily timbered mountains, precipitous valleys, swiftly running streams, and swamps, sand dunes, thick scrub, bays and cliffs.

From 1941 to 1942 there were two camps at Wilson's Promontory. No.1 Camp was in two sections at Darby River adjacent to the present day Lilly Pilly car park. A chalet for visitors had been built south of the Darby River bridge in the 1930s after the road was constructed, and this served as the campsite for officers. When fully established, the section north of the river had floored tents to sleep thirty-five NCOs and sergeants, forty-six corporals and sixty-two other ranks. Both camps had mess huts, lecture huts, ablutions, latrines, a combined kitchen, six bed camp dressing station, a signals workshop and explosives store. No.2 Camp was at Tidal River camping River:

"All that was there as we approached the Prom on the right hand side was an administration hut, a cook house and the showers and mess hall. This was virtually all there was there. On the left hand side was virgin scrub and they said, 'Dump all your kit bags here', and within half and hour you were covered in sand. 'Well there's your camp area; there's your tents. You go over and bash the scrub down and pitch your own tents." (Harry Levey, 2/5th Independent Company, quoted in Pirie 1996).

The Prom was "ideally suited for training troops who might fight anywhere from the Libyan deserts to the jungles of New Guinea, the only drawback being that in winter...the climate was often more polar than tropical", as Captain Freddie Spencer Chapman, instructor in fieldcraft, wrote later. He wrote that in the beginning:

"We talked vaguely of guerilla and irregular warfare, of special and para-military operations, stay-behind parties, resistance movements, sabotage and icendiarism, and darkly, and still more vaguely of 'agents'; but the exact role of the...Independent Companies had never been made clear." (Chapman 1948)

The role of the Independent Companies would be:

"to stay behind, live off the country or be provisioned from the air, and be a thorn in the flesh of the occupying enemy, emerging in true guerrilla style to attack vital points and then disappear again into the jungle. We also visualised long range penetration of the enemy lines by parties highly skilled in fieldcraft and living off the country that they could attack their targets and get back without getting detected." (Chapman 1948)

The first three companies had completed their training by the second half of 1941. Initially destined for the Middle East, with the Japanese threat growing, they were deployed in the islands to the north. The 2/1st Independent Company (sometimes just known as the 1st) was sent in sections to Manus, New Ireland, the Solomons and New Hebrides. The 2/2nd was sent to Timor, and the 2/3rd to New Caledonia.

The 1st to 8th Independent Companies, the colour patches of which appear here and on two New Zealand Units, were formed and trained in the Darby and Tidal River areas. Subsequently, Commando Training was continued thereafter at Canungra, Fraser Island and elsewhere in northern Queensland and Garden Island, Western Australia.

name: Fairfield War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Fairfield War Memorial comprises of a stone obelisk, outside the entrance to the RSL, in Railway Place. The site commemorates all conflicts.

name: Marong War Memorial Gates
description:
The Marong War Memorial Gates are located in front of the old Marong Shire Hall, on the corner of Adams and High Streets. The memorial was unveiled on 11th November 1926 to commemorate the First World War, the left pillar lists names of those Marong residents who served:

J. Green

J.G. Green

E.S. Goulden

L. Pocock

H.K. Palmer

F.E. Salis

Names were then added to the right pillar in memory of those residents who served in the Second World War:

A. Baird

J.P. Barnes

S. Maynard

name: Joel Joel War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Joel Joel War Memorial at the intersection of Greens and Stawell-Landsborough Roads, Northern Grampians Shire. The memorial comprises ofa granite obelisk set upon a tiered plinth and surrounded by four stone posts. It commemorates the service of soldiers from Joel Joel in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Lake Bolac War Memorial
description: The Lake Bolac War Memorial, in Montgomery Street opposite the Memorial Hall, commemorates the First and Second World Wars. The memorial comprises of a granite pillar and features the names of those who served from the Lake Bolac district in both wars.

name: Lismore War Memorial
description: The Lismore War Memorial, on High and Heriot Streets, was erected in April 1931 to commemorate the First World War. The memorial comprises of a granite obelisk and rests in a grassed median. Plaques have been added to the obelisk to acknowledge service in the Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Warrak War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Warrak War Memorial Obelisk is located outside the hall on Warrak Road and Buangor - Ben Nevis Road. The monument commemorates the First and Second World Wars, marble plaques listing the names of 69 fallen and returned district servicemen.

name: Westmere War Memorial
description: The Westmere War Memorial commemorates local servicemen who served in the Second World War. Their names are listed on granite tablets under the inscription " We Honor These Our Kin Who Served in World War II." The tablets flank a central ornamental red panel. The monument stands in front of a flag pole within a small gated reserve.

name: Willaura War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Willaura War Memorial is a mounted granite obelisk commemorating those who served in the First and Second World Wars. Below the names of the servicemen of the world wars are the dates of Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Cobram Lone Pines
description:
The Cobram Lone Pine Memorial is located beside the Cobram and District War Memorial in the centre of town. It consists of two trees in the gardens each characterised by a plaque. The plaque on the south side reads, "Aleppo Pine (Pinus Brutia) from the Original Lone Pine On Gallipoli Grown in the Jubilee Year 1965 planted in Memory of Departed Comrades 'Lest We Forget.'" The plaque below reads,"This Tree was planted by Major Doug Hunter 8/13 Mounted Victorian Rifles on Anzac Day 1981 to replace the original Tree mentioned above."

The plaque on north side has the insignia of R.S.L and reads "Aleppo Pine (Pinus Brutia) Grown from the seeds obtained from Lone Pine on Gallipoli planted by Paul Mckay President Cobram R.S.L. on Anzac Day 1981 in Memory of Departed Comrades 'Lest We Forget.'"

name: Gordon Reserve
description:
The Gordon Reserve is a small triangle of land bounded by Spring Street and Macarthur Street, containing the Stanford Fountain (1870), the Gordon of Khartoum Memorial (1889), the Adam Lindsay Gordon Memorial (1932), the underground women's public toilet (c1924), and five Canary Island date palms. The Reserve was originally part of the Parliament House grounds, but it became detached from these in 1863 and was called Carpentaria Place.

In 1889 the Statue of Gordon of Khartoum was placed on the apex of the triangle at Macarthur and Spring Streets facing towards the Treasury Reserve. General Charles Gordon (1833-1885) was killed at Khartoum, in the Sudan in January 1885. Gordon was an important figure in imperial history and his exploits in China and the Sudan were the stuff of legend before his death. A memorial was suggested and funds were raised by public subscription. The Statue is a copy of Hamo Thorneycroft's statue that had been originally destined for Trafalgar Square. The base and pedestal on the Melbourne statue differs significantly from that in London with scenes from Gordon's life rather than representations of Fortitude and Faith and Charity and Justice. The Gordon Statue is one of the first statues erected of a public figure in Melbourne (preceded by Burke and Wills in 1865 and Redmond Barry in 1887). Gordon's memorial marked the beginning of the 'heroic age of colonial statuary' with another 11 monuments being erected in Melbourne in the next twenty years.

The five Canary Island date palm trees that can now be found at the site were planted in the early 20th Century when the plantings were rationalised and the link fences were installed that delineate the site and cordon off the General Gordon Memorial. As a consequence the site has retained its Edwardian flavour with its mixture of memorials and greenery. The site was not renamed the Gordon Reserve until the 1960s.

name: The Sisters Memorial Tree
description: The Sisters Memorial Tree stands outside the Memorial Hall. It is a single Calabrian Pine (Pinus Brutia) and one of the four original trees raised from the 'Lone Pine' in Gallipoli. Unfortunately this tree is the poorest of the group with several trunk wounds.

name: Garfield War Memorial
description: The Garfield War Monument, on the main street, comprised of a stone cairn with flagpole. On June 20th 2001, a new monument was unveiled replacing the cairn base with a concrete block. The memorial was unveiled by Len Everlyn (9th Australian Division RAE 1942-6) and dedicated by Fr. Peter Rickards, Fr. Bernard Buckley and Rev. Allen Dyall. It commemorates all the men and women of Garfield and district who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Geelong War Anzac Memorial Sculpture
description: <FONT size=2>The small memorial, in Johnstone Park on Gheringhap Street, comprises of a small bronze sculpture of an Anzac artillery man.

name: Tourello Avenue of Honour
description:
The Tourello Avenue of Honour was planted c.1918 to commemorate soldiers who served in the First World War from the Tourello district. The avenue comprises of thirty-five trees at an average height of 6.5 metres. Tourello is one of the ten surviving avenues of honour in Victoria which are specifically associated with plant symbolism, in this case Walnut trees (Juglans regia L.) which are traditionally associated with funerals.

name: Moyston Avenue of Honour
description:
The Moyston Avenue of Honour, located along Ararat-Halls Gap Road, was planted to commemorate the First World War. The Avenue comprises of twenty-seven Pinus Radiata (Monterey Pine) trees, twenty-four metres in height. This is the only known example of using this species in a commemorative avenue.

name: Drik Drik Avenue of Honour
description:
The Drik Drik Avenue of Honour, opposite the State School on Drik Drik-Nelson Road, was planted in 1918 to commemorate the First World War. The avenue consists of about 17 Moreton Bay Figs (Ficus macrophylla), standing at 13 metres high. A stone marker maps the specific trees attributed to each of the servicemen.

name: Creswick Avenue of Honour and War Memorial
description:
The Creswick Avenue of Honour was planted as a tribute to those who served in the First World War. Consisting of Ulmus x hollandica (Dutch Elm), the 285 trees are 16 meters in height. A stone plaque reads: "Shire of Creswick Avenue of Honour a tribute to the men and women who served in the Great War 1914-1918." Each tree originally bore a tablet with the name of a man or woman from the shire, but over the years some have faded or been erased. Graham's 'Early Creswick' contains an alphabetical listing of all those remembered in the avenue with the number of each tree originally bearing their individual names.

The Avenue is located on either side of Creswick-Newstead Road, beginning approximately 500m north of the junction with Midland Highway and continuing to the northern limit of Kingston (with some breaks). It is then continued towards Smeaton with apparently more recent plantings. The area considered here does not include the section within the town of Kingston or that running north to Kingston, since the uniformity of the design is abrogated on entering the town. There are extensive evenly spaced plantings of exotic trees along the roadway. A war memorial obelisk is situated on the east side of the roadway, 100m north of the present Kingston township.

The avenue was opened on December 18th 1927 when Captain T. Parkin conducted a ceremony in which the obelisk was unveiled. The obelisk consists of Harcourt granite and was officially unveiled by Brigadier General Elliott, DSO. Elliot addressed his audience in familiar patriotic tones and stressed the continuing links between Australia and the United Kingdom.

name: Arthurs Creek Avenue of Honour
description:
The Arthurs Creek Avenue of Honour was planted after the First World War. Further research is required on this place.

name: Bandiana Vietnam Memorial Drive
description: <FONT size=2>The BandianaVietnam Memorial Drive was opened on November 11th 1991 by Wodonga's Mayor, Les Boyers. Adjacent to the memorial drive is a monument also dedicated to the Vietnam War.

name: Barnawartha Avenue of Honour
description:
The Barnawartha Avenue of Honour was planted to commemorate those who served in the First World War. Further research is required on this place.

name: Benalla Avenue of Honour
description:
The Benalla Avenue of Honour originally lined both sides of Barkly Street with thirty silky oak trees, planted in 1917. However, the first section of Barkly Street has been closed and partly incorporated into Benalla High School, so the avenue is no longer intact. Nonetheless a small monument, in the Botanical Gardens on Bridge Street, marks where the avenue once stood. The plaque is inscribed: 'In memory of those who fell in the Great War 1914-18.'

name: Bonnie Doon Avenue of Honour
description:
The Bonnie Doon Avenue of Honour was destroyed with the construction of the Bonnie Doon Dam in the early 1950s.

name: Branxholme Avenue of Honour
description:
The Branxholme Avenue of Honour Avenue was plantedin1919 in the Recreation Reserveto commemorate the First World War. The Avenue consists of sixty trees. Further research is required on the condition of this Avenue.

name: Eureka Miners' Memorial and Soldiers' Memorial
description:
The Eureka Memorial consists of both the Miners' Memorial and the Soldiers' Memorial, together with a small number of marked graves. The memorials commemorate those gold diggers and members of the 40th and 12th Regiments who died as a result of the fighting at the Eureka Stockade on 3 December 1854. Erected in 1856, the Miners' Memorial is a grey sandstone obelisk surmounted by a draped urn; its base is made of bluestone. The obelisk is 3.3m high. It consists of several inscriptions including the names of many of the miners who died at Eureka. The monument was presented to the people of Ballarat by James Leggatt of Geelong.

Constructed in 1879, the Soldiers' Memorial was erected through the efforts of parliamentarian, William Collard Smith, and journalist/historian, William Bramwell Withers, and consists of a freestone obelisk mounted on a pedestal and with marble slabs inserted on the east and west faces. The structure is about 4.3m in height. Each of the memorial enclosures is surrounded by a fence made with a bluestone base surmounted by cast iron work.

name: Nurse Edith Cavell Memorial
description:
The Edith Cavell Memorial is located in the Kings Domain, on Birdwood Avenue opposite the Shrine of Remembrance. Edith Cavell, born in 1867, trained as a nurse in England and was later posted to Brussels. With the advent of the First World War, Cavell was put in charge of the Hospital (which became the Red Cross) caring for Belgian, British and French soldiers. In 1915, the German occupying forces accused her of helping prisoners escape and she was sentenced to death by firing squad.

The memorial features a carved marble bust of Cavell on pedestal with bronze plaques depicting the nursing and execution of Edith Cavell. It was sculpted by Margaret Baskerville and unveiled by Sir Harry Chauvel on 11 November 1926. One of the plaques is inscribed with her last words: "But this I would say standing as I do in view of God and eternity I realise that patriotism is not enough I must have no hatred or bitterness to anyone."

name: Sir John Monash Monument
description: <FONT size=2>A bronze statue of Sir John Monash (b.1865-d.1931) is located on the corner of Birdwood Avenue and Government House Drive in the Kings Domain, Melbourne. It was unveiled on the 12th November 1950, by the Right Honourable William McKell K.C., Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia. The monument resembles Sir John Monash in military uniform astride a charger, and is mounted on a stone pedestal. The tablet on the base of the monument is inscribed: "General Sir John Monash C.M.G., K.C.B.,V.D.,soldier and engineer, Commander, the Australian Corps France 1918; Chairman, State Electricity Commission 1921-1931; 1865-1931".

name: Sir Thomas Blamey Monument
description: A statue of Field-Marshal Sir Thomas Blamey (1884-1951) is located in the Kings Garden, on the North side of Government House Drive. The bronze statue depicts the controversial Marshal in uniform, holding on to the top of a Jeep windscreen. The inscription notes his military roles, as G.O.C. of the A.I.F. 1939-1942 and Commander in Chief of Australian Military Forces and Commander Allied Land Forces South West Pacific 1942-5. The statue, designed by Raymond Ewers, was unveiled by the Prime Minister, Robert Gordon Menzies, on 27 February 1960.

name: Eaglehawk War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Eaglehawk War Memorial located in Brassey Square, Eaglehawk, consists of an obelisk charactersied by plaques and wreath ornamentation. Unveiled on August 5th 1922, the memorial commemorates locals that served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Rutherglen War Memorial
description: The Rutherglen War memorial, located in the Memorial Park on Murray Street near High Street, commemorates the First World War. The monument resembles a grey granite obelisk on a two-stepped concrete base on aggregate paving stones. It is surrounded by a fence of stone posts and nearby two cannons.

name: Ballarat East Avenue of Honour
description:
The Ballarat East Avenue of Honour was one of many towns that began plans for their memorials well before the First World War ended, in 1917. Ballarat East planted a total of 490 trees (Fraximus species).

name: Cambrian Hill Avenue of Honour
description:
Cambrian Hill Avenue of Honour consists of sixty-two trees planted in 1917 to commemorate those who served in the First World War. Further research is required on the exact location and condition of this Avenue.

name: Digby Avenue of Honour
description:
The Digby Avenue of Honour is located along the Casterton-Portland Road. Many towns such as Digby began plans for their memorials in 1917, well before the First World War ended. The formal ceremony of planting for the Digby Avenue took place on Saturday August 11th 1917 in the presence of a large and representative gathering of people. There were representatives from the local council and churches and members of parliament. After the tree planting was completed afternoon tea was served at the nearby school. There was a suitable address to the gathering and patriotic songs were sung. The proceedings were completed by the National Anthem.

The Avenue was restored in 1991 and still comprises of ninety-seven Elms (Ulmus spp.), with individual bronze plaques for every district soldier who fought, placed at the foot of each tree.

name: Seymour Avenue of Honour
description:
The Seymour Avenue of Honour was planted with 115 trees along the old Trawool Road. The Avenue was begun in 1917 and was planted by school children in memory of those locals who served in the First World War. The Avenue is now known as Anzac Avenue and the trees have been replaced by a monument on the median strip.

name: Orbost Avenue of Honour
description:
The Orbost Avenue of Honour was planted to commemorate the First World War. Orbost is linked with the history of many of the avenues of honour in other important regional centres such as Albury, Bairnsdale, Traralgon, Leongatha, Berwick, Lilydale, Seymour, Hamilton and Ballarat. Where the avenue stood is no longer clear but a possible avenue of elms and plane trees was found in 1997. However senior Anzac residents had no knowledge of any Avenue of Honour being planted.

name: Bairnsdale RAAF Avenue of Honour
description:
The Bairnsdale Avenue of Honour was planted to commemorate the fallen of the Second World War. The Avenue is marked by three boulders and plaques listing the names of those who served in the R.A.A.F.

name: Hamilton Avenue of Honour
description:
The Hamilton Avenue of Honour, on Clarke Street, was planted by the children of the Elementary School on Arbour Day 1917. The idea for this memorial avenue was first presented to the Elementary School Committee by Mr Hughan, the Curator of the Hamilton Gardens. The suggestion was unanimously approved, and after the Borough Council had given its approval to both the site along the banks of the Grange Burn, and to the use of the name 'Anzac Avenue', planning proceeded. At this time, there were already 25 former pupils of the school who had lost their lives serving their country during the First World War. Twenty-six of Hamilton's men came from Clarke Street,this represented the highest enlisted/resident ratio in the Commonwealth.


The School Committee invited the Mayoress, the wife of the President of the Shire of Dundas and representatives of the bereaved relatives to participate in the Arbour day ceremony, and the Mayor and members of the Ministers' Association and the Roman Catholic Church to deliver addresses. Anzac Avenue was proposed to follow the Grange Burn from Skene Street to the railway bridge. Mr Hughan supervised on the first occasion when the nucleus of the avenue was formed by the planting of 36 trees. In 1918 the number was increased to 93. During the summer months, the boys from the School watered the trees, and the Borough of Hamilton minutes of February, 1921 record that they had carried 600 buckets of water to Anzac Avenue, for which they received a vote of thanks from the Councillors. During the next few years many of the trees in the avenue had to be replaced, as the original plane trees were not suited to the heavy soil.

Over the years the surviving trees grew to maturity and formed the avenue envisaged by Mr Hughan. Gradually, the significance of the trees was forgotten, so that by the latter part of the century, very few residents in Hamilton were aware of their existence. Members of the Hamilton History Centre, while researching war memorials in the town, stumbled upon information about the Avenue in Mr Sidney Officer's unpublished manuscript Hamilton Spectator 1910-1918: "A Record of the Part it Played in the Great War with Honour Roll." Immediate steps were taken to determine if the plans of the Avenue survived, and if anything remained of the Avenue trees.

Trees were found to be growing in two rows, following along the banks of the Grange Burn, from the southern end of Kennedy street westwards towards Portland Road. Most of the trees are barely discernible as the vicinity is overgrown with elm tree suckers and blackberries. The future of Anzac Avenue is uncertain. The area is now one of the few remaining habitats for the endangered Eastern Barred Bandicoot, and a restoration of the avenue will destroy the vegetation necessary for the preservation of this scarce marsupial.

Dating from May 1916, the Eurack Avenue of Honour is the earliest known avenue of honour that was planted in Victoria.

By the time of the Second World War avenues of honour had declined in popularity as a means of commemoration. Today it is estimated that over 300 avenues of honour have been planted in Victoria to commemorate service personnel since 1901.

name: Pyramid Hill Avenue of Honour
description:
The Pyramid Hill Avenue of Honour was planted in 1929 to commemorate the men of the district who served in the First World War. The avenue comprises of twenty Sugar Gum trees (Eucalyptus cladocalyx). It is marked by a stone cairn which includes a plaque re-dedicating the avenue to include the servicemen of the Second World War.

The Mallee and Wimmera were not climatically suited to growing European trees and those examples which do exist are of Australian natives - Sugar Gum (Eucalyptus cladocalyx) at Pyramid Hill, Kaniva and Kotupna and Kurrajong (Brachychiton populneum) at Nathalia.

description:
The Kaniva Avenue of Honourcomprised of twenty-seven Sugar Gum trees(Eucalyptus cladocalyx) planted to commemorate the Second World War.Further research is required on the exact location and condition of thisAvenue.

name: Creswick R.S.L. War Memorial
description: The Creswick R.S.L. War Memorial comprises three flagpoles with rough cut rock bases. Each flagpole lists the names of those who served from the Creswick district in the Second World War, Korea and Vietnam conflicts.

name: Piggoreet Avenue of Honour
description:
The Piggoreet Avenue of Honour was planted to commemorate the First World War. Unlike most other types of memorials, Avenues of Honour involved a high level of participation by the local community of the city or town in which they occurred such as in Piggoreet where the trees were planted at working bees by enthusiastic residents. Further research is required on the exact location and condition of this Avenue.

name: Lara Avenue of Honour
description:
The Lara Avenue of Honour, on the Walkers Road, was planted in 1948 to commemorate the Second World War. The avenue was planted with 98 Cypress trees (Cupressus macrocarpa), 93 of which survive. The Avenue is one of ten in Victoria that specifically chose trees because of their symbolism, Cypress trees are symbolic of death and melancholy.

description:
The Inverleigh Avenue of Honour comprises of Cypress trees, a traditional symbol of death and melancholy. The date of planting and conflict commemorated need to be confirmed.

name: Cranbourne Avenue of Honour
description:
The Cranbourne Avenue of Honour, along the South Gippsland Highway, consists of approximately 172 English Oak (Quercus robur) trees planted to commemorate the First World War. The avenue was opened on August 9th 1919 by the Shire President, Cr. D. McGregor and planted by the Cranbourne Patriotic Association.The Avenue in its original condition represented 59 men and two Sisters, E and N Lehman. Currently it comprises of mature trees in good condition as well as some younger ones planted in the last decade.

name: Epsom Avenue of Honour
description:
The Epsom Avenue of Honour consists of a single row of seventeen Cotton Palm trees (Washingtonia filifera) planted in 1919 to commemorate the First World War. The area the trees were planted on now comprises of a private property but further research is required to confirm the exact location.
