name: Balliang East Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Church of England Grammar School Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The entrance gates to the Church of England Grammar School are dedicated to the Old Boys of the school who fell in the First World War.

name: Serviceman's Memorial Bowling Club
description: <FONT size=2>The Serviceman's Memorial Bowling Club is located at 309 Creswick Road, Ballarat.

name: Ballarat WWII Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Ballarat WWII Memorial, on Sturt Street, was erected in 1995.

name: William Dunstan VC Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The William Dunstan VC Memorial, on Sturt Street, is dedicated to the First World War Serviceman who was awarded the Victoria Cross Medal.

name: Ballarat POW Memorial Flagstaff
description: <FONT size=2>The Ballarat POW Memorial Flagstaff, inside the Ballarat Botanical Gardens was erected Feburary 6th 2004. It is dedicated to Australian Prisoners of War in all conflicts.

name: Ballarat Recent Wars Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Ballarat Recent Wars Memorial, on Sturt Street, was unveiled on November 11th 2000. The memorial comprises of a granite cross leant against a block and inscribed with 'Lest We Forget.' It is dedicated to Korea, Borneo, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Albert Coates Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Albert Coates Memorial, on Sturt Street, comprises of a bronze statue. Coates (b.1895- d.1977) was a Lieutanant Colonel in the Australian Army Medical Corps. During the Second World War, Coates was imprisoned in a Japanese Prisoner of War Camp in Sumatra where he saved many lives. The plaque on the statue is inscribed with ex-POW Private Bill Hood's memory of Coates: "Colonel Coates stood out...he not only saved lives...he saved reason...he was a man among men."

name: Balmoral Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Balmoral Memorial Hall, on Glendinning Street, was opened in 1957.

name: Balwyn North War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Balwyn North War Memorial was erected by the R.S.L on April 16th 1989. The Memorial comprises of a cenotaph dedicated to the "Memory of Deceased Comrades."

name: Walter John Spiers Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Walter John Spiers Memorial, located in the sports ground, comprises ofa small stone monument erected in 1992. The plaque records that Bamawm local, Spiers, was killed in action at Mount Tambu, New Guinea on July 16th 1943. He was buried in the Lae War Cemetery.

name: Bangholme Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Bangholme Memorial Cross
description: The Bangholme Memorial Cross, in Bunurong Cemetery, was erected to commemorate those who gave their service in conflicts around the world including New Zealand (1860-1861), Sudan (1885), Boer War (1899-1902), World War I (1914-1918), World War II (1939-1945), Korean War, Malayan Emergency (1950-1960), Confrontation (Indonesia 1964-1966), Vietnam War (1962-1972) and the Gulf War (1990-1991). The memorial also lists the names of those who died fighting in Vietnam.

name: Bangholme Vietnam Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Bangholme Vietnam Memorial, in Burnong Cemetery, is located behind the Memorial Cross. The Memorial depicts a typical battlefield in Vietnam in bronze relief form.

name: Barkly Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Barkly Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Anglican Church, are dedicated to the memory of those who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Barnawartha Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Barnawartha Memorial Hall, on High Street and Havelock Street, was established on July 9th 1921.The hall was built to honour the men from Barnawartha and district, who served in the First World War.

name: Barnawartha Public School Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Barnawartha Public School Memorial Gates are located at the entrance to Barnawartha Primary School. The Gates are dedicated to the memory of the Second World War.

name: Barrabool Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Barrabool Memorial Gates form the entrance to the local sportsground. They were erected in memory of the First World War and also the first pioneers of the district.

name: Barwon Heads War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Barwon Heads War Memorial, outside the Barwon Heads RSL, was unveiled November 11th 1971. The memorial is a small monument positioned between two flagpoles. The memorial was erected in memory of the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Baxter Naval Memorial Club Monument
description: The Baxter Naval Memorial Club Memorial is located on Barrett's Road. The Memorial comprises of a red brick wall, an anchor and two flagpoles. The inscription reads "In Memory of Fallen and Departed Shipmates."

name: Bayswater War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Bayswater War Memorial is located in the grounds of the Bayswater RSL at 626 Mountain Highway. The memorial comprises of a wall panel with plaques and flagpoles. It commemorates the Boer War, Boxer Rebellion, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Indonesian Confrontation and Vietnam.

name: Ripon Peace Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Ripon Peace Memorial Hospital was established December 8th 1923 and is dedicated to the memory of the First World War.

name: Beaufort RSL War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Beaufort RSL War Memorial comprises of an obelisk erected on November 22nd, 1991. It is dedicated to the memory of 399 service men and women who fought in Korea and 500 servicemen who fought in Vietnam. In 1998, two plaques were dedicated to the memory of those who fought in the "Boer War and All Conflicts and Peacekeeping Missions" and "To the Unknown Soldier and to all Australian P.O.Ws returned and known only to God."

name: Beaumaris RSL War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Beaumaris RSL War Memorial is located outside the Beaumaris Ex-Services Club on Balcombe Road. It is a simple brick monument with a bronze wreath positioned in front of a flagpole. It commemorates all conflicts.

name: Beechworth Servicemen's Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Beechworth Servicemen's Memorial Hall, on Ford Street, was established July 23rd 1957.

name: Belgrave Alepbo Pine
description:
The Belgrave Alepbo Pine, in Anzac Park, was established May 21st 2000. The pine is a descendant of the original Lone Pine of Gallipoli. Inscribed on the plaque is a verse of Rudyard Kipling:

Whereby our dead shall sleep

In honour unbetrayed,

And we in faith and honour keep

That peace for which they paid.

name: Belmont Primary School Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Belmont Primary School Memorial Gates form the entrance to the School on Mount Pleasant Road. They are dedicated to the First World War.

name: Benalla RAAF Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Benalla R.A.A.F. Memorial comprises of a tan brick monument. It is dedicated to all those who served at the No. 11 Elementary Flying Training School and all those associated with the Tiger Moths during the Second World War. The monument was officially unveiled by Air Commodore M.J. Rawlinson on June 17th 1995.

name: Sir Edward Weary Dunlop Drinking Fountain
description: <FONT size=2>The Sir Edward Weary Dunlop Drinking Fountain was donated by the Shepparton R.S.L. in 1997.

name: Benalla Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Benalla Soldiers Memorial Hall, on Nunn Street, was established January 22nd to commemorate the First World War.

name: Benalla and District Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Benalla and District Memorial Hospital is located at 45-53 Coster Street.

name: Sir Edward Weary Dunlop Benalla Memorial
description:
The Sir Edward Weary Dunlop Benalla Memorial, located in the Rose Gardens on Bridge Street, was erected on November 10th 1996. It is dedicated to the memory of Sir Edward Weary Dunlop, a Benalla local and Second World War hero. In 1942, Dunlop was in command of the No.1 Allied General Hospital at Bandoeng, Java when the Japanese invaded and he became a Prisoner of War. Transferred to the Burma-Thailand Raliway in Singapore, Dunlop continued to work as a doctor saving many men from the harsh conditions of camp life.

Sculpted by Louis Laumen, the memorial comprises of a dramatic scene where two men assist a weak, emaciated figure. One of the plaques is inscribed with Donald Stuart's memory of Weary Dunlop: "When despair and death reached out to us Weary Dunlop stood fast, a light house of sanity in a universe of madness and suffering."

name: Gallipoli Landing Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Gallipoli Landing Memorial Plaque was established in 1975 to commemorate the 60th Anniversary of the landing on Gallipoli.

name: Benambra War Memorial
description: The Benambra War Memorial is located outside the Public Hall on Gibbs and Limestone Streets. The Memorial comprises of an obelisk dedicated to First and Second World Wars. It lists the names of those who served including nine who never returned.

name: Benambra Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Benambra Memorial Gates,at the entrance to the sports oval, are dedicated to the Second World War and Korea. There is also a specific dedication to C. Toland, killed in the Second World War.

name: Bendigo Memorial Stairs
description: <FONT size=2>The Bendigo Memorial Stairs, at the entrance to the High School, are dedicated to the memory of students who fought in times of war.

name: Bentleigh East Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Moorabbin Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Moorabbin Memorial Swimming Pool is located at East Boundary Road, East Bentleigh.

name: Bemm River War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Bemm River War Memorial comprises of a small mounment and flagpole, dedicated to the First World War, Second World War, Malaya, Korea, Borneo, Vietnam and Kuwait (First Gulf War).

name: Yarra Yarra Golf Club Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Yarra Yarra Golf Club Memorial Wall is dedicated to all wars.

name: Bethanga Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Bethanga Soldiers Memorial Hall, on Bridge and Jobling Streets, was established in 1923. The entrance is marked by an archway inscribed with "Lest We Forget" with the dates of the First and Second World Wars.

name: Beulah Memorial Hall and Free Library
description: <FONT size=2>The Beulah Memorial Hall and Free Library was established 14th September 1921.

name: Beveridge War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Beveridge War Memorial comprises of seven polished panels, each listing a conflict and the names of those who fought. The pine trees behind the memorial were planted by children during the Second World War in memory of those who served.

name: Birchip Soldiers Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Birchip Soldiers Memorial, located in the Birchip RSL Memorial Park, was unveiled November 11th 2007 by Ken K.Kemp (Ex R.A.A.F. Flying Officer WWII). The Memorial comprises of a Digger statue in the standing at ease. Plaques on the statue's base are dedicated to the 90th Anniversary of the Galliopli landing and the 60th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Salvation Army Memorial Rose Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Salvation Army Memorial Rose Garden is located at Salvation Army Inala Elderly Citizens Village, 220 Middleborough Road. The Garden is dedicated to the memory of members of the Salvation Army who served in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War (2/22nd Battalion Band), Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam and East Timor.

name: Bobinawarrah Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Boolarra District Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Boorcan Soldiers Settlement Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Boorcan Soldiers Settlement Memorial was erected to commemorate the original soldier settlers and their families of the Marida Yallock Estate Subdivsion, established 1947. The memorial comprises of a cairn with a plaque mapping the location of the families' properties.

name: Booroopki Avenue of Honour
description:
The Booroopki Avenue of Honour was planted with thirty-five Eucalyptus and Pine trees in memory of those who fought in the First World War. The Avenue was opened on 29th August 1918 at a ceremony that began with the national anthem and featured an address by Mr C.D. Block. Block expressed his hope that years after the conflict had been forgotten the towering, dignified Pine trees would be a reminder to the next generation of the sacrifices made by their forebears. Three trees were given prominence as those dedicated to three deceased servicemen: Pte. J.R. Gardner, C.F. Patching and P. Brennan. After the ceremony the congregation gathered at the residence of Mrs C. Wong for afternoon tea.

On January 15th 2000, B.C. Ruxton unveiled a stone cairn memorial to mark the avenue and list the names of those who served. The names are as follows:

Pte J. Brennan
Pte C. Brennan
Pte J. Biggin (Jack)
Trpr A. S. Bull (Dick)
Pte C. H. L. Crabtree
Pte W. Cameron
Pte H. G. Crabtree
Gnr E. C. Carracher
Gnr J. D. Carracher
Pte P. Dowling (Peter)
Pte T. Dowling (Tom)
Pte J. Delaney (Jack)
Pte T. Delaney (Tom)
Trpr F. J. Forster
Pte G. A. Forster
Pte W. G. V. Gardner
Sgnr E. Hinch
Pte L. G. Hamilton
Air Mec C. J. Kerr
Lieut J. M. Leyden
Segt. C. T. Moodey
Pte J. T. W. Major
Pte J. W. S. Mcdonald
Pte J. T. O'brien
Pte Jas O'brien
Pte H. B. Phillips
Pte O. Pritchard
Pte H. B. Schinckel
Pte J. D. Schumann
Pte A. E. Stehn
Pte J. J. Wilson
Pte P. L. Wilson

In Australia, commemorative trees have been planted in public spaces since the late nineteenth century. Arbor Days were held regularly in most Victorian State Schools during the late 1800s and early 1900s, and numerous trees were planted in parks in Melbourne and throughout Victoria to mark the visits of important and famous people.

This tradition of commemorative planting was continued in 1901 when at the end of the Boer War trees were often planted for each soldier of the district who was killed in South Africa. These plantings, however, rarely consisted of more than two or three trees in each town.

During and after the First World War avenues of honour consisting of trees lining significant streets became a popular form of commemoration. They represented a new egalitarian approach to the commemoration of soldiers where rank was not a consideration: each tree symbolises a person.

Avenues of honour are a uniquely Australian phenomenon. Australians, and in particular Victorians, embraced the idea of planting them more enthusiastically than any other country in the world. The Eurack Avenue of Honour is the earliest known avenue of honour in Victoriawith planting commencing in May 1916.

By the time of the Second World War avenues of honour had declined in popularity as a means of commemoration. Today it is estimated that over 300 avenues of honour have been planted in Victoria to commemorate service personnel since 1901.

name: Boort Memorial Gates
description: The Boort Memorial Gates form the entrance to the Boort Primary School. The gates were erected by the Boort Sub-Branch R.S.L. in memory of students who enlisted and those who fell in the two world wars.

name: Boronia War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Boronia War Memorial is located outside the Boronia R.S.L. on Dorset Road. The memorial comprises of a small obelisk and is dedicated to all those who paid the supreme sacrifice in wartime.

name: St Peter's Anglican Church Memorial
description: St Peter's Anglican Church, on Whitehorse Road Box Hill, features a stone plaque laid on 9 March 1952.The plaque is dedicated to those who gave their lives in the two world wars. Nearby the Church Hall also features a Memorial Plaque, laid on 25 January 1958, to commemorate the First World War and Second World War.

name: Box Hill Memorial Clock Tower
description: <FONT size=2>The Box Hill Memorial Clock Tower, in Wattle Park, was erected in 1948. The tower is dedicated to the memory of Royden Louis Charles Bennett who fought with the 7th Battalion AIF and was killed at Pozieres, France on August 18th 1916. The memorial was donated by Royden's mother Mrs. Zilpah Bennett.

name: Branxholme Cemetery
description: <FONT size=2>Located in the Branxholme Cemetery is a headstone for Private C. McKinnon who fought in the Boer War with the 4th Imperial Contingent. McKinnon died of disease in South Africa on July 17th 1901.

name: Branxholme East Soldier Settlement Monument
description: <FONT size=2>The Branxholme East Soldier Settlement Monument commemorates the Koornong Estate allotted October 8th 1957.The monument comprises of a stone cairn with a plaque mapping the locations of the Families' properties.

name: Branxholme WWI Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Branxholme WWI Memorial, on the Henty Highway, lists the names of those local men who served in the First World War.

name: Branxholme North Soldier Settlement Monument
description: <FONT size=2>The Branxholme North Soldier Settlement Monument commemorates the Ardachy Estate established on February 14th, 1947 for the Returned Servicemen and their families.The estate consists of 9,324 acres which was subdivided into 15 allotments. The monument is a stone cairn with a plaque mapping the location of the allotments.

name: Briagolong War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Briagolong War Memorial, in Anzac Park, was erected in 1920 to commemorate the First World War. The memorial comprises of a large obelisk flanked by two smaller obelisks. The large obelisk was unveiled by Mrs John Mills in January 1921, while the two small obelisks were added to commemorate the Second World War.

name: Bridgewater Memorial Hall and Free Library
description:
The Bridgewater Memorial Hall and Free Library, on Eldon and Erskine Streets, was established October 3rd 1923. The front entrance of the Hall lists the names of 215 fallen and returned soldiers who fought in the First World War, Second World War and Korea.

A Vietnam Veterans plaque recognising those who enlisted while living in Bridgewater, or who were born in Bridgewater, was added to the Memorial and unveiled on 25 April 2011. The plaque lists the following names:

Terry Wickham
Ian Paynter
Edward Paynter
Bruce Tarran
Colin Poyser
William Lucas
Alan Cordy
Hugh Cordy

name: Bright WWII Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Bright WWII Memorial comprises of a rough-cut stone monument outside the Bright R.S.L. Erected in 1995, the monument commemorates the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Brighton WWII Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Brighton WWII Memorial, in the Town Hall Gardens, comprises of a sun dial. It commemorates the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: St. Cuthbert's Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The St. Cuthbert's Memorial Hall is dedicated to the memory of the men and women of St. Cuthbert's Church who served in the two world wars. The foundation stone was laid by General Sir Edmund Herring on September 29th, 1951.

name: Anzac Hostel Brighton Memorial Plaque
description:
The present day Brighton Anzac Hostel opened in 1998, and is set in the beautiful gardens of the Kamesburgh property on the corner of North Road and Cochrane Street, Brighton. In the grounds of the hostel is a small memorial commemorating the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

This hostel is a current day incarnation of the Anzac Hostel in the Kamesburgh Mansion that was purchased by the Repatriation Department in 1919. Severely disabled soldiers lived there from the early 1920s. The Kamesburgh Mansion became an Anzac Hostel after the First World War. Itis a large two storey, rendered brick, Italianate mansion set in an extensive formal garden thatwas built in 1874 for businessman William Kerr Thomson by builder David Mitchell to the design of architect Lloyd Tayler. The property was bought by the Repatriation Department in 1919 with a gift of 25000 pounds from the Baillieu brothers for the care of severely incapacitated soldiers. In this period the building was converted with the addition of a lift and an enlargement of the service wings. The Repatriation Department also constructed an occupational therapy building (the day centre) and a mortuary.

name: Brim Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Brim Memorial Hall was established October 6th 1920.

name: Brim Memorial Bowling Club
description: <FONT size=2>Brim Memorial Bowling Club, on Swann Street,was founded in 1945. The entrance sign is inscribed with the date of the 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War, "Australia Remembers 1945-1995."

name: Broadford Memorial Seat
description: <FONT size=2>The Broadford Memorial Seat, in the Broadford Marketplace, is dedicated to a soldier killed in the Second World War. The plaque reads: "In Memory of Geoffrey Welsh killed at Tobruk May 1st 1941. By His Parents, Sisters & Brothers."

name: Broadmeadows Remembrance Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Broadmeadows Remembrance Memorial, on Raleigh Street, comprises of a grand red site featuring five flagpoles and three frieze panels. The memorial was unveiled by the Hon. Richard R. McGarvie, Governor of Victoria, on November 11th 1995 and was dedicated to all servicemen.

name: Broadmeadows War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Broadmeadows War Memorial, on Raleigh Street, comprises of an obelisk with crenellated top. It was erected in memory of the First World War.

name: Broughton Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Bungaree War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Bungaree War Memorial comprises of a small stone monument and flagpole, dedicated to the memory of all citizens who served Australia in times of war.

name: Shire of Buninyong Roll of Honor 1914-18
description: <FONT size=2>The Shire of Buninyong Roll of Honor 1914-18 is located on a red brick monument, near the R.S.L. Memorial Park, on Learmonth Road. The roll lists the names of 496 fallen and returned soldiers from the First World War.

name: Buninyong P.O.W. Memorial Pergola
description: <FONT size=2>The Buninyong P.O.W. Memorial Pergola is located in the RSL Memorial Park, on Learmonth Road and Warrenheip Street. The pergola was unveiled by V.A. Bradley, past president of the Buninyong R.S.L. Sub-Branch, on Anzac Day 1988. It is dedicated to Australian men and women who died in Prisoner of War Camps.

name: Buninyong Memorial Rose Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Buninyong Memorial Rose Garden, in the RSL Memorial Park, was established on Anzac Day 1988. The Garden comprises of a small stone monument and a flagpole, dedicated to the fallen of all wars.

name: Birdwood Park Memorial Grove
description: <FONT size=2>The Birdwood Park Memorial Grove comprises of trees planted to commemorate the First World War.

name: Burrumbeet Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Burrumbeet Soldiers Memorial Hall, at 46 Burrumbeet Road, was established in 1935.

name: Wattle Park School Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Wattle Park School Memorial comprises of a small block monument with flagpole. The plaque simply reads 'Lest We Forget.'

name: Royal Australian Survey Corps Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>A small stone cairn, in the East Burwood Reserve, marks the location of the Field Survey Training Depot between 1941-1943. The plaque also commemorates the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Peter James Centre Remembrance Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The plaque and flagpole in the Peter James Centre Remembrance Garden are dedicated to all Servicemen and women who served in all wars.

name: Buxton Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Buxton Memorial Hall was built on the site of St. John's Anglican Church according to plans supervised by Sir George Coles and designed by Louis Williams. Opened in 1957, the hall was dedicated to those who fell in the Second World War.

name: Cambarville War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Cumberland Memorial Reserve comprises of 275 Hectares of high country set aside as a reserve in memory of Victorians who lost their lives in the First World War, Second World War and conflicts since 1945. It was unveiled by Bruce Ruxton on Feburary 16th 1994. A small stone and plaque marks the reserve's memorial purpose.

name: Camberwell Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>The Camberwell Cenotaph, on Camberwell Road, commemorates the lives of all servicemen and women who paid the supreme sacrifice in times of war.

name: Camperdown Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Camperdown Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Camperdown School, are dedicated to the memory of ex-students who were killed fighting in the Second World War. The gates were opened by General Sir Dallas Brooks on April 18th 1958.

name: Cann River War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Cann River War Memorial is located outside the RSL Hall on Genoa Street. The memorial lists the names of Cann River men who paid the supreme sacrifice in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Canterbury Memorial Home Units
description: <FONT size=2>The Canterbury Memorial Home Units, on Canterbury Road, were established April 17th 1980. Thehome unitsare dedicated to the memory of the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam. It also features an honour roll of the names of those who served in the First World War.

name: Biggsley Memorial Sundial
description: <FONT size=2>The Biggsley Memorial Sundial, in the Canterbury Gardens, is dedicated to Captain J.C.L. Biggsley killed in the First World War.

name: Caramut Soldier Settlement Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Caramut Soldier Settlement Memorial is dedicated to the memory of families who settled in the area after the Second World War.

name: Carapook Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Carapook Memorial Hall was erected in memory of soldiers of Carapook and District who were killed in the Second World War.

name: Cardross War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Cardross War Memorial comprises of a small rock and plaque dedicated to the memory of those who made the supreme sacrifice in the Second World War. The plaque was previously attached to the former Infant Welfare Centre.

name: Carrajung Memorial Park
description: <FONT size=2>The Carrajung Memorial Park is dedicated to the memory of soldiers who fell in the First World War, Second World War and later conflicts. The park comprises of a cricket ground.

name: Caulfield Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Caulfield Memorial Swimming Pool commemorates the First World War and Second World War.

name: Carrum Downs Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Carrum Downs Memorial Hall, on Frankston-Dandenong Road, is dedicated to the memory of men from the Casterton district who died in the Boer War. The hall comprises of a weatherboarded and cement sheet clad building with joint cover strapping, symmetrically arranged multi-pane glazing and a gabled porch. It is typical of public halls of its era but is it is one of the few intact public buildings in the city from the 1920s-30s.

name: Casterton War Memorial
description: The Casterton War Memorial, in Bryan Park on Henty Road, comprises of a granite obelisk. It lists the names of 132 fallen and returned soldiers of the First and Second World Wars. Plaques were later added for the Korean and Vietnam Wars.

name: Casterton Memorial Hospital
description: The Casterton Memorial Hospital was opened on February 6th 1959 by General Sir Dallas Brooks.

name: Casterton Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Casterton Memorial Swimming Pool was opened by Col. E.E. Dunlop on February 1967. The pool is dedicated to the memory of all those from the Casterton and district who made the supreme sacrifice in the Second World War.

name: Castlemaine War Memorial Sports Stadium
description: <FONT size=2>This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Beersheba Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Beersheba Memorial Plaque, in Caulfield Park, was unveiled April 25th 1995. Sculpted by Ross J Bastiaan, the bronze relief plaque commemorates the First World War Battle of Beersheba in 1917.

name: Caulfield Racecourse Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Caulfield Racecourse Memorial comprises of a small stone monument and plaque located in the racecourse grounds. The memorial commemorates the contribution of the Victorian Amateur Turf Club and the Caulfield Racecourse, where thousands of soldiers joined the 2nd Australian Imperial Force during the Second World War. During the war, the army used the racecourse as a recruiting depot, barracks and clearing house for the medical examinations of young recruits.The memorial was unveiled on August 12th 1995, to mark the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Caulfield Memorial Park
description: Caulfield Memorial Park was officially opened by Mayor Alan Grossbard on November 23rd 1997. The park includes a central paved ring, where several memorial plaques have been re-sited from their former position in Avenues of Honour along North Road, McMillan Street and Point Nepean Road. The plaques commemorate the district servicemen who fell in the First World War.

name: Caulfield South Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Caulfield South Memorial Gates, on Bundeera Road, form the entrance to Caulfield South Primary School. The gates were erected in memory of former pupils and teachers who served in the forces during the First World War and Second World War.

name: The Cavendish State School No. 116
description: <FONT size=2>The Cavendish State School No. 116 is located on Barker Street. In 1952, the School built memorial gates to commemorateformer students who served in the Second World War.

name: Cavendish War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Cavendish War Memorial comprises of a small stone and plaque monument dedicated to Returned Service Personnel from the Cavendish District.

name: Shire of Charlton Honour Board
description: <FONT size=2>The Shire of Charlton Honour Board, outside the Charlton Shire Offices, lists the names of those who served in the First World War.

name: St. Martin Anglican Church
description: <FONT size=2>The foundation stone of St. Martin's Anglican Church was laid on April 28th 1963, in memory of those who fell in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Charlton Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Traveller's Rest War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>Traveller's Rest on High Street is an amenities building. Attached to the building is a plaque dedicated to the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War. The tables on the site were donated by the Charlton R.S.L in honour of the men and women who served during the Second World War.

name: Moorabbin-Highett War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Moorabbin-Highett War Memorial, located in Cheltenham Park, comprises of a marble tablet inscribed with names of those who servedin the First World War from the Moorabbin-Highett district. The monument stands near the broken pillar monument also dedicated to the First World War.

name: Canakkale Gardens
description: <FONT size=2>The Canakkale Gardens symbolise the bond between Moorabbin's citizens and the citizens of Canakkale, Turkey, the closest city to the Gallipoli battlfields. The mayor of Moorabin Cr. Barry Neve and the mayor of Canakkale Ismail Ozay dedicated the garden on April 24th 1993. At the ceremony sand from Anzac Cove was combined with Australian soil and two Aleppo Pines were planted to commemorate the bond.

name: Kingston Centre War Memorial Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Kingston Centre War Memorial Garden is located outside the Hopsital entrance. The garden was unveiled by Major General David McLachlan on 17th September 2003. The garden is dedicated to all those men and women who have served in the armed forces.

name: Cheshunt Memorial Trees
description:
In 1959, two memorial trees were planted in Cheshunt in memory of Sister Caroline Ennis and Sister Dorothy Gwendolyn Howard Elmes. Both nurses were evacuated from Singapore on the Vyner Brooke, which was bombed by the Japanese on February 14th 1942 near Banka Island, Indonesia. Sister Ennis was killed in the bombing while Sister Elmes was one of twenty-one nurses massacred on the Banka Island beach.

On the evening of 12 February 1942, the Vyner Brooke was one of the last ships carrying evacuees to leave Singapore. Among the passengers were the last sixty-five Australian nurses in Singapore. Throughout the daylight hours of 13 February, Vyner Brookelaid up in the lee of a small jungle-covered island, but she was attacked late in the afternoon by Japanese aircraft, with no serious casualties. At sunset, she made a run for the Banka Strait, heading for Palembang in Sumatra.

Not long after 2pm, Vyner Brooke was attacked by several Japanese aircraft. Despite evasive action, she was crippled by several bombs and sank. One hundred and fifty survivors evenutally made it ashore at Banka Island, after periods of between eight and sixty-five hours in the water. The island had already been occupied by the Japanese and most of the survivors were taken captive.

A terrible fate awaited many of those who landed on Radji beach. There, survivors from the Vyner Brooke joined up with another party of civilians and up to sixty Commonwealth servicemen and merchant sailors, who had made it ashore after their own vessels were sunk. After an unsuccessful effort to gain food and assistance from local villagers, a deputation was sent to contact the Japanese, with the aim of having the group taken prisoner. Anticipating this, all but one of the civilian women followed behind.

A party of Japanese troops arrived at Radji Beach a few hours later. They shot and bayoneted the males and then forced the twenty-two Australian nurses and the one British civilian woman who had remained to wade into the sea, then shot them from behind.

There were only two survivors - Sister Vivian Bullwinkel and Private Cecil Kinsley, a British soldier. After hiding in the jungle for several days, the pair eventually gave themselves up to the Japanese. Kinsley died a few days later from his wounds, and Bullwinkel spent the rest of the war as an internee.

Of the sixty-five Australian nurses who embarked upon the Vyner Brooke, twelve were killed during the air attack or drowned following the sinking, twenty-one were murdered on Radji Beach, and thirty-two became internees, eight of whom subsequently died before the end of the war.

name: Chewton WWII Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Chewton Second World War Memorial is located in the grounds of the Elderly Citizens Facility on high street. It comprises of a small rock and plaque unveiled in the 50th Anniversary year of the end of the Second World War. It is dedicated to Chewton servicemen and women who volunteered for active service during the Second World War.

name: Chiltern Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Clayton War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Clayton War Memorial, located at 264 Clayton Road, was unveiled on Australia Day 1999. The Memorial comprises of a contemporary cenotaph design and is dedicated to all men and women who served in times of conflict.

name: Clifton Hill War Memorial Fountain
description: <FONT size=2>The Clifton Hill War Memorial Fountain is located in the grounds of Spensley Street Primary School. The fountain is dedicated to Sister Margaret Montgomery who served in the First World War.

name: Spensley Street Primary School Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Spensley Street Primary School Memorial comprises of an obelisk dedicated to the memory of 'old scholars' who served in the First World War.

name: St Paul's Clunes War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The St. Paul's Clunes War Memorial, in the grounds of St. Paul's Anglican Church, is dedicated to the First World War. The memorial comprises of a mounted stone cross and lists the names of sixteen fallen soldiers.

name: Clunes Primary School Memorial Gate
description: <FONT size=2>The Clunes Primary School Memorial Gate, on Canterbury and Cameron Streets, is dedicated to the Second World War.

name: Clunes Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Clunes Memorial Swimming Pool, in the Recreation Reserve on Ligar Street, is dedicated to the Second World War.

name: Cobram and District Memorial Pool
description: <FONT size=2>This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Coburg City Hall
description: <FONT size=2>Coburg City Hall, on Bell Street, was officially opend by the Earl of Stradbroke on April 1st, 1922. The Hall was built in honour of those who served in the First World War. The Hall now houses the offices of the Moreland City Council.

name: Coburg Memorial Garden
description:
The Coburg Memorial Garden was planted by school children in May 1991 in memory of all those who lost their lives in war. The garden replaces the 'Soldier's Avenue of Trees', which used to be in the school ground and was planted in memory of former pupils who died fighting in the First World War. The garden features a plaque listing the names of those former students who never returned home.

The original memorial avenues of trees were planted on Saturday 30 August 1919 by relatives and friends of the soldiers from Coburg who were killed in the First World War. Originally, each tree honoured an individual soldier. The remaining trees collectively commemorate all those who made the supreme sacrifice and the ninety-one Coburg names on the memorial. It was unveiled 29 April 1990.

name: Cohuna Memorial Gazebo
description: <FONT size=2>The Cohuna Memorial Gazebo, in the grounds of the primary school, is dedicated to the First World War. Attached to the structure are two plaques: the first reads "Their Service - Our Heritage", the second is inscribed with the Anzac Requiem by Dr. Charles Bean.

name: Colac Park War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Colac Park Memorial comprises of a small rock monument with a plaque. The plaque is inscribed with "To the Last Man and Last Shilling", an expression of the early Anzac tradition. The monument records the fact that the expression originated in a speech delivered in Colac by Andrew Fisher, leader of the Federal Opposition, on July 1st 1914.

name: Colbinabbin Memorial Centre
description: <FONT size=2>This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Coldstream and Yering War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Coldstream and Yering War Memorial, on the Maroondah Highway and Melba Highway, comprises of a coloured stone block monument. The memorial lists the names of seventy-two fallen soldiers who fought in the Boer War, First World War and Second World War.

name: Collingwood Sailors' and Soldiers' Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Collingwood Sailors' and Soldiers' Memorial Hall, on Hoddle Street, opened on June 29th 1924. It was unveiled by Brigadier General R. Smith in memory of those who enlisted from Collingwood in the First World War.

name: Collingwood English Language School Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Collingwood English Language School Memorial, on Cambridge Street, comprises of a mounted flagpole monument. The monument is unusual, bearing no inscriptions or plaques on its base.

name: Congupna Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Congupna Memorial Gates were erected in 1952 in memory of the Second World War.

name: Cooma Uniting Church Memorial Tablets
description: The Cooma Uniting Church Memorial Tablets are dedicated the First and Second World Wars. Each tablet lists the names of those who served in each world war.

name: Connewarre and District Memorial Hall
description: The Connewarre and District Memorial Hall was opened on August 13th 1976.

name: Corinella Memorial Tree
description: <FONT size=2>The Corinella Memorial Tree, in the Bass Valley School grounds, features plaques listing servicemen in the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Coronet Bay Avenue of Honour
description:
The Coronet Bay Avenue of Honour was planted by the community of Coronet Bay and District to commemorate those who served in the Second World War. Further research is required on this place.

In Australia, commemorative trees have been planted in public spaces since the late nineteenth century. Arbor Days were held regularly in most Victorian State Schools during the late 1800s and early 1900s, and numerous trees were planted in parks in Melbourne and throughout Victoria to mark the visits of important and famous people.

This tradition of commemorative planting was continued in 1901 when at the end of the Boer War trees were often planted for each soldier of the district who was killed in South Africa. These plantings, however, rarely consisted of more than two or three trees in each town.

During and after the First World War avenues of honour consisting of trees lining significant streets became a popular form of commemoration. They represented a new egalitarian approach to the commemoration of soldiers where rank was not a consideration: each tree symbolises a person.

Avenues of honour are a uniquely Australian phenomenon. Australians, and in particular Victorians, embraced the idea of planting them more enthusiastically than any other country in the world. The Eurack Avenue of Honour is the earliest known avenue of honour to be planted in Victoria and dates from May 1916.

By the time of the Second World War avenues of honour had declined in popularity as a means of commemoration. Today it is estimated that over 300 avenues of honour have been planted in Victoria to commemorate service personnel since 1901.

Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Cowes Memorial RSL Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Phillip Island R.S.L. opened on June 17th 1939.

name: Cranbourne Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Cranbourne Memorial Wall, outside the Cranbourne RSL on Cameron Street, is entitled simply with "Lest We Forget."

name: Creswick Memorial RSL Hall
description: <FONT size=2>Creswick Memorial R.S.L. Hall was established on October 4th 1952. The foundation stone was laid by J.C.P. Strachan and F. James.

name: Croydon War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Croydon War Memorial, comprising of a stone obelisk was unveiled on October 27th 1919. The memorial lists the names of 76 fallen and returned servicemen from the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Croydon Memorial Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Croydon Memorial Pool, on Springfield Avenue, is dedicated to the memory of the fallen.

name: Croydon Civic Square Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Croydon Civic Square Memorial, in James N Stevens Memorial Park, was erected in 1988. The memorial comprises of a small granite block and lists the names of 31 soldiers who died fighting in the First World War, Second World War, Korea

name: Croydon RSL War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Croydon RSL War Memorial consists of a rough stone cairn dedicated to the Korean and Vietnam Wars.

name: Curyo Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Curyo Memorial Gates list the names of district servicemen who died fighting in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Dadswells Bridge Soldier Settlement Memorial
description: The Dadswells Bridge Soldier Settlement Memorial is dedicated to families who settled on 3608 acres of Stapledon's Estate, Dadswells Bridge in October 1959. The memorial names of the three soldier settlers and their wives who settled the estate were W.S. and K.W. Facey, D.J. and V.M. Huddleston, W.L. and G.A. Hutchesson.

name: Dallas North Memorial Grove
description: <FONT size=2>The Dallas North Memorial Grove was established by the Dallas North School Community to commemorate the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Dandenong RSL Vietnam War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Dandenong R.S.L War Memorial, dedicated to the the Vietnam War, was unveiled by Governor General Michael Jeffrey on April 30th 2005. The memorial comprises of two soldier statues on a wide base that features the names of Vietnamese provinceswhere battles took place. Next to the Memorial is a "Dust-off" UH-1V helicopter donated to the R.S.L by the United States to commemorate the Australian-American alliance during the Vietnam War.

name: Dargo War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Dargo War Memorial comprises of a flagstaff erected on November 11th 2001. The monument is dedicated to all those men and women of the Dargo-Crooked River district who paid the supreme sacrifice in times of war.

name: Darlington Peace Bell
description: <FONT size=2>The Darlington Peace Bell was erected with money raised by the Darlington town and district communities. The bell was rung after the signing of the Peace Treaty ending the First World War. The bell was then used by the Darlington School no. 777 as the school bell.

name: Darnum War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Darnum War Memorial consists of a stone cairn erected to honour the residents of the Darnum - Cloverlea District who died during the First World War and in the conflicts that followed.

name: Darnum Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Darraweit Guim Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Darraweit Guim Memorial Hall is dedicated to the memory of the First and Second World War. The current building was opened by Cr. I Amess on 11th November 1978, replacing the original 1921 hall which was destroyed in a bushfire on January 8th 1969.

name: Dartmoor Memorial Gates
description: The Dartmoor Memorial Gates are dedicated to the First World War, each pillar lists the names of those local residents who served.

name: Daylesford and District Memorial Swimming Pool
description: The Daylesford and District Memorial Swimming Pool, unveiled on November 11th 1972, is dedicated to the memory of all those who served.

name: Deans Marsh Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Deans Marsh Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Soldiers Memorial Park, are dedicated to the First and Second World War.

name: Daylesford R.S.L Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>Outside the Daylesford R.S.L, at 20 Vincent Street, features two plaques dedicated to the First and Second World War. The first plaque, dedicated in memory of both the world wars, was unveiled on November 24th 1960 by the Governor Sir Dallas Brooks. The second plaque is personally dedicated in thanks to L.L. Righetti andhis crew who served in Sundra Strait, March 1st 1942.

name: Daylesford State School Memorial Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Daylesford State School Memorial Pool, opened in 1955, is dedicated to all former pupils who served in the First and Second World War.

name: Dederang Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Dederang Memorial Hall was established in 1954.

name: Dereel Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Dereel Soldiers Memorial Hall, located on Swamp Road, was established in 1921.

name: Dergholm Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Dergholm Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the sports ground, are dedicated to the First and Second World Wars. The first pillar lists A.M. Cassidy, A.T. Donehue and G.I.G. Robertson as the fallen of the First World War. The second pillar lists G. Coates, L.W. Howlett, R.S. Patterson and W.S. Patterson as the fallen of the Second World War.

The plaque was unveiled by Major General WB 'Digger' James (AO MBE MC), National President of the Returned and Services League of Australia.

description: <FONT size=2>The Epping Memorial Tablet is located next to the Epping War Memorial on Harvest Home Road. It is dedicated to those who paid the supreme sacrifice during the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Epping Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Epping Memorial Hall is located on High and Hall Streets. Outside the building is a memorial flagpole erected on November 11th 2003, in memory of Whittlesea residents who served their country in times of war.

description: <FONT size=2>The Light Horse Gates form the entrance to the Bendigo Jockey Club at the BendigoRacecourse Reserve. description: A small plaque and flagpole, located in Queens Park, was erected by the Essendon Branch of War Widows and Widowed Mothers to commemorate the 50th year of Anzac and honour all those who have served in Australia in times of War.

name: Essendon Boer War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Essendon Boer War Memorial, a granite cenotaph, is engraved with the names of 68 fallen and returned soldiers who fought in the Boer War. The monument was first erected as a Rockery on June 2nd 1902 to commemorate the Boer War and the accession to the throne of King Edward VIII. It was then re-erected in its present form on August 30th 1936.

description: <FONT size=2>Essendon Primary School 483 erected a tablet monument in memory of former students who gave their lives in the Second World War. The inscription reads "Gladly They Lived and Nobly They Died for God, King and Country."

name: Essendon Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Essendon Memorial Hospital was established by the community on December 6th 1964, in memory of the Essendon men and women who served Australia during the Second World War.

name: Weary Dunlop Memorial Tree
description: On November 7th 1993, a tree was planted in Queen's Park in memory of Sir Edward Weary Dunlop (1907 -1993), renowned sugeon, humanitarian and ex-prisoner of war on the Burma-Thailand Railway.

name: VP Day Memorial Tree
description: <FONT size=2>The VP Day (Victory in the Pacific) Memorial Tree in Queen's Park was planted to commemorate the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War. The tree was planted on August 15th 1995, fifty years after Japan accepted the Allied demand of unconditional surrender in the Pacific on August 15th 1945.

name: Euroa War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Euroa War Memorial is located on the Old Hume Highway. The memorial comprises of a natural stone monument with a plaque bearing the names of thoselocals who served in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War and Korea.

description: <FONT size=2>The Euroa Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the sports ground, are dedicated to the all those who died in times of war. It was erected by the Euroa Sub-Branch R.S.L. The sombre inscription reads "Remember ye who enter here, those who fought and died that you might live in liberty."

name: Unknown Soldier Memorial Tree
description: <FONT size=2>A memorial tree was planted for the Unknown Soldier on Foy and Clifton Streets, Euroa.

name: Euroa Anglican Church War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Euroa Anglican Church War Memorial Gates are dedicated to those locals, killed in the Second World War, who used to worship at the church.

name: Euroa Anglican Church Memorial Plaque
description: The Euroa Anglican Church Memorial Plaque, attached to a single gate, is dedicated to Douglas McLaine who was killed on active service August 17th 1943. The plaque and gate were erected by his comrades and family.

name: Euroa Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Euroa Memorial Swimming Pool, on Bury Street, was opened by the Honourable R.J. Hamer (Minister for Local Government) on Feburary 13th 1971. It is dedicated to the memory of the Second World War.

name: Carl Verey Memorial Cross
description: <FONT size=2>The Carl Verey Memorial Cross is located in the cemetery grounds. The cross features a plaque inscribed with"Lest We Forget" above emblems of the Australian Army, Navy, Air Force and Merchant Navy. The monument is also dedicated to Carl Verey in recognition of his services to the Fawkner community.

name: Fawkner Memorial Panel (at Fawkner Cemetery)
description: <FONT size=2>The Fawkner Memorial Panel, in the grounds of the cemetery, commemorates the dead of all wars. The plaque is inscribed with the "Ode of Remembrance" from Laurence Binyon's poem "For the Fallen."

name: Proposed Vivien Bullwinkel Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>One of the memorial crosses in Fawkner Cemetery was proposed as a potential memorial for Nurse Vivien Bullwinkel.

name: Fentons Creek Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Fentons Creek Memorial Hall is located on Logan-Wedderburn Road. name: Lower Ferntree Gully War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Lower Ferntree Gully War Memorial, relocated from Ferntree Gully Primary School to Dorset Road, comprises of a small granite obelisk dedicated to local scholars who died First World War.

name: Lower Ferntree Gully Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Lower Ferntree Gully Memorial Wall is located behind the First World War Memorial Obelisk on Dorset Road. The wall is constructed out of red tiles and features an artist's depiction of battle scenes in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam. It was unveiled by C.R. D.G. Lucas and Cr. W.H. Tew at 11am, 11th November 1988.

name: Kokoda Track Memorial Walk
description: <FONT size=2>The Kokoda Track Memorial Walk is a fivekilometre track from the Ferntree Gully Rangers Office to the One Tree Hill Picnic Ground in Ferntree Gully, in the Yarra Valley and Dandenong Ranges Shire. The track is a 1000 step climb that attempts to convey part of the soldier's experience of traversing the Kokoda Trail in Papua Guinea during the Second World War between 1942-43. Throughout the track are plaques explaining the key sites of the original Kokoda Trail and also commemorating significant people who died on the trail such as journalist Damien Parer and Bruce Steel Kingsbury, who was posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross.

name: Damien Parer Memorial
description: The Damien Parer Memorial is located onon the Kokoda Track Memorial Walk in the Dandenong National Park. It is dedicated to the life of Parer who was a Photographer and War Correspondent (b. 1st August 1912 - d. 17th September 1944). Parer's film of the Kokoda Trail, Kokoda Frontline, recorded the appalling conditions Australians were dealing with while fighting the Japanese. The film won the 1943 Academy Award for Best Documentary, the only newsreel to receive an 'Oscar'. On September 17th 1944, Parer was killed by Japanese machine gun fire while filming the advance of U.S. Marines at Peleliu, Palau, Caroline Islands in the Pacific.

name: Bruce Steel Kingsbury Memorial
description:
The Bruce Steel Kingsbury Memorial commemorates the life of Kingsbury, who was posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross for his heroic actions against the Japanese on the Kokoda track, at the Battle of Isurava in March 1942. The memorial plaque rests on the Kokoda Track Memorial Walk in the Dandenong Ranges National Park.

Kingsbury was part of the 2nd/14th Battalion which was significantly outnumbered by Japanese forces who were attacking the battalion's positions. On March 29th, the Japanese threatened to take the Australians' headquarters when Kingsbury launched an attack shooting a Bren gun and single -handedly killing thirty Japanese soldiers. As Kingsbury continued to inflict fire on the Japanese, allowing the Australians to move forward, he was shot by a single Japanese sniper. He died as he was carried to the Aid site.

Kingsbury's actions are considered a turning point in the Battle of Isurava which meant the Australians were able to secure the defence of their Headquarters and halt the Japanese destruction of the battalion. He was awarded the Victoria Cross on Feburary 9th 1943, which his family received on his behalf. It was the first Victoria Cross to be awarded to a soldier in the Pacific and the first awarded on Australian Territory.

name: Fitzroy Memorial Pergola
description: <FONT size=2>The Fitzroy Memorial Pergola, in the Edinburgh Gardens,was erected by the Fitzroy Cricket, Football,Bowling, Baseball and Tennis Clubs to commemorate the First World War.

name: Flemington War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Flemington War Memorial comprises of a concrete cairn, topped by a small crucifix and mounted on a three tiered plinth. The monument is dedicated to all the district servicemen and women who served in times of war.

name: Tannery Park Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Tannery Park Memorial is a granite cenotaph dedicated to 19 fallen men of the First World War, who were employees of Michaelis, Hallenstein Co. Pty. The monument stands on the western side of the Maribyrnong River on Hopkins Street.

name: Nunawading Memorial Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Nunawading Memorial Pool, now known as the Aqualink Nunawading, is dedicated to the memory of the First World War, Second World War and Korea.

name: Foster War Memorial Arts Centre
description: <FONT size=2>The Foster War Memorial Arts Centre was established on 12th November 1966 in memory of all those who died in serving Australia in times of war.

name: Frankston Primary School War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Frankston Primary School War Memorial is located on Davey Street in front of the school. The memorial is a flagstaff dedicated to the First World War.

name: Garibaldi Memorial Gate
description: <FONT size=2>The Garibaldi Memorial Gate was the entrance to the former school. It is dedicated to Corporal Leo O'Loughlin who died in a Prisoner of War in Siam on December 20th 1943.

name: Geelong Korean War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Geelong Korean War Memorial was opened by Patron Major General Jim Hughes and C.R. Gerry Smith on 3rd November 1996. The memorial is a flagstaff surrounded by a circular black brick wall.

name: Geelong and District Memorial Swimming Centre
description: <FONT size=2>The Geelong and District Memorial Swimming Centre was opened by the Mayor Sir Roy Fidge on 8th December 1967. The building is dedicated to all servicemen and women who paid the supreme the sacrifice during times of war.

name: Geelong North War Memorial

The site was unveiled by CR. Neville Lewis on Ocotber 11th 1992, to commemorate the service and sacrifice of men and women of the Shire of Corio who served in the Second World War, Malaya, Korea, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: North Geelong South East Asia War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The North Geelong South East Asia War Memorial comprises of three brick pillars dedicated to conflicts between 1939-1970, including Singapore in the Second World War and Malaya.

name: Gembrook Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Gembrook Memorial Obelisk, on Redwood and Gembrook Roads, is dedicated to the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Gembrook R.S.L. War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Gembrook R.S.L. War Memorial consists of a brick flagstaff inscribed simply with "Lest We Forget."

description: <FONT size=2>The Gisborne War Memorial is a granite obelisk dedicated to the memory of Gisborne's fallen men of the First World War and also those who served in the Korea, Malaysia and Vietnam campaigns.

description: <FONT size=2>After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. description: <FONT size=2>The Glenthompson War Memorial Hall was built 18th March 1902 on land donated by John McLennan. On 17th September 1955, the Hall was rededicated as a War Memorial by Mrs S.M. Forbes.

name: Glen Waverley Memorial Gates

The Gates are in wrought iron and incorporate the words "Lest We Forget" in their design. They have sandstone pillars and plaques dedicated to eight servicemen who fell in the Second World War.

name: Glen Waverley War Memorial
description: The Glen Waverley War Memorial was established in January 1999. It is dedicated to 44 fallen soldiers from the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam and Kuwait. The inscription reads " Pass not this place in sorrow but in pride and may you live nobly, as they died knowing that their death in freedom's cause stands as a beacon light to point the way to paths of peace, Lest We Forget."

name: Goomalibee Avenue of Honour
description:
The Goomalibee Avenue of Honour was planted between 1942-1943 to commemorate the First World War and Second World War. The Avenue is located along the Baddaginnie-Goomalibee Road and comprises of 10 White cedar, 15 pines and 3 Gum trees. As of 2011 the trees in this Avenue were in a poor condition.

In Australia, commemorative trees have been planted in public spaces since the late nineteenth century. Arbor Days were held regularly in most Victorian State Schools during the late 1800s and early 1900s, and numerous trees were planted in parks in Melbourne and throughout Victoria to mark the visits of important and famous people.

This tradition of commemorative planting was continued in 1901 when at the end of the Boer War trees were often planted for each soldier of the district who was killed in South Africa. These plantings, however, rarely consisted of more than two or three trees in each town.

During and after the First World War avenues of honour consisting of trees lining significant streets became a popular form of commemoration. They represented a new egalitarian approach to the commemoration of soldiers where rank was not a consideration: each tree symbolises a person.

Avenues of honour are a uniquely Australian phenomenon. Australians, and in particular Victorians, embraced the idea of planting them more enthusiastically than any other country in the world. The Eurack Avenue of Honour is the earliest known avenue of honour to be planted in Victoria and dates from 1916.

By the time of the Second World War avenues of honour had declined in popularity as a means of commemoration. Today it is estimated that over 300 avenues of honour have been planted in Victoria to commemorate service personnel since 1901.
