Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Goorambat Memorial Stone
description: The Goorambat Memorial Stone rests inside the Victory Park. The stone lists the names of six men who died serving in the Second World War: J.G. Groat, L.W. Heaney, E.T.L. Osborne, R.H. Osborne, E.M. Palmer and F. Peck.

name: Goornong Soldiers Memorial Hall
description:
The Goornong Soldiers Memorial Hall originally occupied a timber building constructed in 1889. The Hall was then rebuilt into the current brick building that now caters for diverse community functions.

After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Goroke and District Memorial Hall
description: Inside the Goroke War Memorial are bronze honour rolls listing the names of those who served in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam. The honour rolls were opened by Brigadier Grant Cavenagh on 8th June 2003.

name: Granya War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Granya War Memorial, located in the former School grounds, comprises of a pillar monument dedicated to the First World War. The monument was erected on August 14th 1920.

name: Great Western Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Great Western Memorial Obelisk, located inside the Great Western Memorial Park, is centrally positioned amongst the war memorials behind the memorial gates. The obelisk commemorates 44 fallen and returned soldiers who fought in the First World War. There is also a dedication to John Thomlinson and Henry Best Jnr who fought in the Boer War. Originally erected by George Grey of Stawell in April 1924, outside the Mechanics Institute, the memorial was relocated to the park in 1956.

name: Great Western WWII Memorial Flagpole
description: <FONT size=2>The Great Western WWII Memorial Flagpole is situated to the other side of the Memorial Obelisk in the Great Western Memorial Park. It was was unveiled in 1956 by the Curran family in memory of Rex Curran, who died on the Kokoda trail on August 9th 1942, aged 22. The names of Peter Seppelt, John Walker and John Thomlinson were also added to the granite pedestal of the flagpole in an Australia Remembers ceremony c.1995.

name: McKinnis Memorial Seat
description: <FONT size=2>The McKinnis Memorial Seat, near the Memorial Obelisk in the Great Western Memorial Park, was presented by the McKinnisfamily at the unveiling ceremony in 1956. The seat is dedicated to the memory ofRoy McKinnis of the Royal Australian Navy. He lost his life in naval operations, on12th September 1944, in the Pacific during the Second World War.

name: Greensborough War Memorial
description:
The Greensborough War Memorial, on Henry and Ester Streets, comprises of a granite obelisk raised on two red marble pillars and a two-tiered plinth. The monument lists the names of 15 soldiers who fell in the First World War. A wall was later erected behind the monument with plaques commemorating the service of Australians in the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam and Kuwait.

For more information see: http://wikinorthia.net.au/index.php/Greensborough_War_Memorial

name: Gringegalgona Soldiers Memorial Hall
description:
The Gringegalgona Soldier's Memorial Hall, is located on the west side of the Coleraine-Balmoral Road, just north of the intersection of Gringe Dip Road, was built in 1925 by the local community as a tribute and memorial to those who fought and died in World War One. The land appears to have been given by William Toleman. According to the title, the Crown sold one acre for ₤4 'as a site for a Public Hall' on 21st April 1925. The trustees were Alexander John Watt, Henry Joseph Brody, Michael J Byrne, John James Smith and William Toleman, the last three being returned soldiers. A Mr V Yuill drew up the plans, possibly Vine Yuill of Sandford who was probably related to W J Yuill another one of the returned soldiers. The builder was a Mr Burgin whose tender was ₤490.

The Soldier Settlement Board, or Closer Settlement Board, had subdivided the Gringegalgona Estate in 1920.The squatting run, famous for its wool growing capability, dated from the early 1840s. It had been owned by two families, the first led by Simon Cadden, the second by Duncan Robertson and then his son, William 'Gringe' Robertson. The former built the fine two-storey mansion in 1873. Even by the early twentieth century the run still comprised 28,000 acres of open woodland country watered by dams, tanks and waterholes, and was stocked with 25,000 merino sheep. William Robertson died in 1918. The successful soldier settler applicants for the subdivided blocks were announced in the Argus in October 1940.

Twenty-eight returned soldiers eventually settled on blocks of between 800 and 1000 acres, building homes from trees they supplied to the local sawmill, improving the pastures, growing wool and planting crops. By 1923 rabbits had appeared in unprecedented numbers, eating the country bare of feed to such an extent that the sheep numbers on many blocks were reduced to around 300, and these in a state of near starvation. Some settlers soon failed and walked off their blocks. Others sought work on the roads, cutting timber, or shearing. Notwithstanding the dire times, the first meeting about the hall was held in the home of H J Brody. Money was raised by holding sports meetings and gymkhanas. During the construction, the Argus noted 'The Gringegalgona Soldiers Memorial Hall benefited to the extent of £114/4/6 as the result of a gymkhana and £170 was raised for the hall at Pigeon Ponds in a similar way'. The hall at Gringegalgona was typical of the practical local response to the deep national grief after the death and injury of World War One.

Memorial halls were built throughout Victoria, often associated with sporting facilities such as tennis courts. Their scale varied from modest halls like that at Gringegalgona, all that could be expected from small, new and often isolated communities, through to much more formal buildings in established towns. A small number of memorial halls were multi-purpose and even lavish in the facilities provided for the returned soldiers. One of the grandest was the new municipal complex at Jeparit, also built in 1925 but costing ₤8,100, a combined effort of the local Mechanics Institute, the Returned Sailors and Soldiers Imperial League of Australia (later known as the Returned & Services League of Australia), local citizens and the Dimboola Shire Council. It was partly funded by cinema ticket sales. Interestingly, there is no mention of films being screened at the Gringegalgona hall. Perhaps the most symbolic example, however, is the memorial hall at the tiny settlement of Paschendale, near Merino in the Glenelg Shire, which was completed in 1928. The Gringegalgona Memorial Hall must be seen as the best the community could achieve in the circumstances.

It is clear that the Gringegalgona Memorial Hall fulfilled its practical objective and became a focus for community activities including through the Great Depression and another World War. It provided 'a venue for concerts, dances, church services and usual gatherings after sporting events'. Anglicans, Presbyterians, Methodists and Lutherans conducted church services at the hall including baptisms, conformations and Sunday school. The last church service to be held was in December 1960. Functions were still held regularly in the hall until the 1970s including an Annual [Melbourne] Cup luncheon and card evenings organised by Ruth Toleman. Mrs Toleman cut the ribbon at the Ball held to celebrate the arrival of electricity, first supplied by the State Electricity Commission in October 1965.The photograph taken of local dignitaries includes women wearing furs with corsages and one of the original soldier settlers, Mr J J Smith and his wife. It can be surmised that the decline in activities would be due to improved transportation and better roads, allowing easier access to Hamilton and Horsham, and the introduction of television, for which electricity was essential, in the 1960s. More recently, the hall has been used for garden club events, community barbecues and CFA meetings.

name: Grovedale United Services Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Gunbower Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Gunbower Soldiers Memorial Hall was established on August 20th 1924 in memory of those district servicemen who fell in the First World War. A plaque added in 1995 lists the names of the eleven men who never returned from the Second World War.

name: Hamilton War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Hamilton War Memorial, located in the Melville Oval, was unveiled April 25th 1926. The monument is a grand statue featuring the figure of peace, raised on four pillars. The memorial lists the names of 160 soldiers who died fighting in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, the Indonesian Confrontation andVietnam.

name: Hamilton Gallipoli Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Hamilton Gallipoli Memorial is located beside the lake. The memorial consists of a plaque with a relief map of the Gallipoli peninsula, marked with the significant places an dates of various battles of the Allied campagin against Turkish forces. There is also a memorial planting of a Pine tree and some Rosemary bushes, which have grown from cuttings brought back from the Gallipoli Peninsula.

name: Hamilton Sailors and Soldiers Fathers Association Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Located inside the Hamilton Cemetery is a marble tablet and urn erected by the Hamilton Sailors and Soldiers Fathers Association in memory of those district servicemen who died fighting in the First World War. It also honours those parents from the districts whose sons enlisted and the fallen of the Second World War.

name: Hamilton RAAF Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Hamilton Airforce Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Melville Oval on Lonsdale and Brown Streets, are dedicated to the men and women who served with the Royal Australian Air Force during times of war.

name: Hamilton Memorial Rose Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Hamilton Memorial Rose Garden, inside Melville Oval, features plantings and plaques planted in memory of those who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Sabah/Sarawak and Vietnam. The roses were planted on 11th November 1986 by Mr. S.C. FitzPatrick (M.C., O.B.E., F.R.I.C.S.), G.N. Joseph (a Vietnam Veteran) and W.C. Button (M.M).

name: St. Andrews Church Peace Memorial Hall
description: The foundation stone for the St. Andrews Church Peace Memorial Hall waslaidonMarch 16th 1957 by Dr. S.C. FitzPatrick. It is dedicated to those who who served and those who died servingin the First and Second World Wars. The inscription reads: "These turned from the quiet of this parish that their children might worship here in freedom and peace."

name: Hamilton Boer War Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>The Hamilton Boer War Memorial Plaques are located inside the Anglican Church. This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Hamilton Vietnam Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Hamilton Vietnam Memorial, on Lonsdale and Alexandra Streets, was unveiled on October 3rd 1998 by Brigadier P.W. Beale. The memorial comprises of three natural stone monuments with plaques that record the areas in Vietnam where Australians fought.

name: Hamilton College Memorial Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Hamilton College Memorial Garden comprises of a rose bushes, unveiled on April 24th 1996, in memory of the 125th Anniversary of the College and former pupils who have served in times of war.

name: Anzac Hostel Brighton (Kamesburgh Mansion)
description:
The Anzac Hostel Brighton (Kamesburgh Mansion), at 74-104 North Road Brighton, is a large two storey, rendered brick Italianate mansion set in an extensive formal garden. Kamesburgh was built in 1874 for businessman William Kerr Thomson by builder David Mitchell to the design of architect Lloyd Tayler. The property remained a domestic dwelling until the ownership of the prominent pastoralist, financier and politician Duncan McBryde.

In 1918, negotiations with the Repatriation Department led to purchase from McBryde by the well-known Melbourne businessmen and philanthropists, the Baillieu brothers. The Baillieu brothers bought the property for £25000, gifting it as a rehabilitation centre for severely incapacitated ex-servicemen who required constant observation and nursing care, though not hospital treatment. The donation was the largest Australian philanthropic gift for veterans of the First World War and was later formalised in the Repatriation Fund (Baillieu Gift) Act of 1937. The Baillieu brothers in agreeing to this purchase desired that when the purpose for which the hostel had been acquired had been fully served, the hostel should be realised and the proceeds applied to provide university scholarships tenable by lineal descendents of ex-servicemen who were deceased or totally and permanently incapacitated as a result of war service. The Kamesburgh mansion was renamed Anzac Hostel and formally opened on 5th July 1919 by Sir Arthur Stanley, Governor of Victoria.

In this period the building was converted with the addition of a lift and an enlargement of the service wings and the administration of the building handed to the Red Cross.When it first opened the Hostel had twenty-five beds and seven nurses on staff. The Repatriation Department also constructed an occupational therapy building (the day centre) and a mortuary. The Anzac Hostel continued to provide care for disabled servicemen from 1919 until 30th June 1995 when the house was converted for use as a school. However a new Anzac Hostel was built on the grounds and opened 27th July, 1998.

name: Hamilton History Centre Boer War Honour Roll
description: <FONT size=2>The Hamilton History Centre, at 43 Gray Street, is located inside the Mechanics Institute building. Inside a Boer War Memorial Honour Roll was donated by the Hamilton Patriotic Association in memory of six local men who served. The honour roll is in printed form and features portrait photos of each man.

name: Hamilton WWI Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The First World War Plaque on Clarke Street, Hamilton is dedicated to 26 men from Clarke Street who enlisted, representing the highest enlistment/resident ratio in Australia. A memorial avenue was planted along Clarke Street on 24th August 1918. The plaque was laid on Armistice Day 1987.

name: Hamilton WWII Memorial Rose Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Second World War Memorial Rose Garden is located near the Hamilton Uniting Church. The garden is dedicated to all men and women who served in the Second World War and commemorates the 50th Anniversary of the end of the conflict, 1945 -1995.

name: Hamilton Beersheba Memorial Palms
description: <FONT size=2>The Hamilton Beersheba Memorial Palms were planted beside the Uniting Church. The trees comprise of Aleppo Palms and are dedicated to the Hamilton men of the 4th Light Horse Regiment who fought in the Battle of Beersheba, 31st October 1917.

name: Hamilton Primary School WWI Memorial Tablets
description: <FONT size=2>Several War Memorial Tablets are located on the walls of the quadrangle in Hamilton Primary School at 42 Grey Street. The tablets are dedicated to the First World War, listing the names of those who served. There is also a tablet specifically dedicated to the Gallipoli landing on 25th April 1915, inscribed with an extract from General Ian Hamilton's speech commending the ANZAC's performance.

name: Melton Vietnam War Memorial
description: The Melton Vietnam War Memorial is located on High Street within the median strip, in a circular grassed bed alongside the War Memorial Obelisk. It comprises two pointed double-sided cream brick piers with red brick cappings. The piers rest on a tiled triangular base that has commemorative plaques on each of the three triangular points. It has plaques which record sentiments such as: 'The people of Melton remember all who served suffered and died, Vietnam 1962-1973', and 'Vietnam 1962-1973: Together Then, Together Again'. It was opened on August 15th 1998 by Australia's Deputy Prime Minister, Tim Fischer MP.

name: Harcourt War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Harcourt War Memorial, in Stanley Park, comprises of an obelisk dedicated to the First World War. The monument lists the names of 44 fallen and returned servicemen.

name: Harcourt WWII Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Harcourt WWII Memorial Gates forme the entrance to Stanley Park. The gates are inscribed with the names of 104 fallen and returned soldiers from the Second World War. The Gates have also been dedicated to the Korea, Malaya and Vietnam wars.

name: Harcourt Memorial Trees
description: <FONT size=2>Two Memorial Trees are located within Stanley Park, one is dedicated to H.A. Struhs, 2/21 Battalion who died at a Prisoner of War Camp on Hainan Island, 9th April 1944. The second tree has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Harrow WWII Memorial Seats
description: <FONT size=2>The Harrow WWII Memorial Seats are located on the Main Street, near the Memorial Obelisk. The first seat was donated by the Harrow Branch of the Country Women's Association in memory of Private Eric Walker, who died of illness during the Second World War. The second seat was also donated by the Harrow Country Women's Association, in memory of R.A.F. Squadron 612 F/O John Joseph Minogue. Minogue was killed over the English Channel on 23rd May 1944.

name: Harrow War Memorial Lamp Post
description: <FONT size=2>The Harrow Boer War Memorial Lamp Pole was erected by the Harrow R.S.L. on Anzac Day, 25th April 1988, in memory of Harrow district soldiers who served in the Sudan and Boer Wars.

name: Hastings Primary School Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Hastings Primary School Memorial Gates, on Hodgins Road, is inscribed simply with "Honour for Service."

name: Haven Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Bacchus Marsh War Memorial
description: The Bacchus Marsh War Memorial is located in Main Street in front of the R.S.L. building. The memorial consists of a cuboid, clad in Castlemaine slate, bearing the inscription,"Erected by the people of the Shire of Bacchus Marsh in recognition of those who served their Country in War."

name: Hawkesdale Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Hawthorn War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Hawthorn War Memorial, in St. James Park on Burwood Road, was erected in March 1929. The memorial is a coloured brick cenotaph, dedicated to the First World War, with inscriptions added for theSecond World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam wars.

name: Hawthorn Rowing Club War Memorial
description:
The Hawthorn Rowing Club War Memorial is a small stone obelisk dedicated inscribed with the words"In memory of fallen members Hawthorn Rowing Club, They Fought, They Fell."

This memorial was unveiled on 11 October 1919. It was financed by the Guy Family in memory of their son Lieutenant LC (Claude) Guy. He was an outstanding oarsman listed amongst the dead. The memorial has been moved about four times since its original establishment. In 2007 it was moved into landscaped parklands behind the Hawthorn Rowing Club. It is now accessible from 2a Burwood Road.

The memorial lists fallen Hawthorn Rowing Club servicemen from World War I and World War II. In World War I forty-three men enlisted and three died. In World War II forty-eight enlisted and three died.

The Hawthorn Rowing Club run annual Service, with trumpet Last Post and Reveille at 11.00am on the Sunday prior to Anzac day.

For more information contact the Hawthorn Rowing Club (www.hawthornrowingclub.com).

name: Hawthorn Secondary College Memorial Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Hawthorn Secondary College Memorial Garden was established by the School in honour of the men and women who served during the Second World War. The garden was planted as part of the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War, 1945-1995.

name: Lubeck WWI Memorial
description: The Lubeck First World War Memorial resembles a rough, upright stone with a marble plaque that lists the names of nine local men who served in the First World War. The memorial was inside the Soldiers Memorial Reserve but has been reerected outside the Lubeck Memorial Hall.

name: Lubeck Memorial Gates
description: The Lubeck Memorial Gates formed the entrance to the Soldiers Memorial Reserve. The gates are constructed from a white wrought iron and rest beneath a wooden arch with gold lettering "Soldiers Memorial Reserve." The gate has since been relocated to stand opposite the Lubeck Memorial Hall.

name: Castlemaine RSL
description: <FONT size=2>The foundation stone for the Castlemaine RSL was unveiled by Brigadier General C.H. Brand on 14th February 1920, in memory of fallen comrades.

name: Balmoral Memorial Wall
description: The Balmoral War Memorial Wall is located at the intersection of Coleraine Road and Bell Street next to the Memorial Obelisk. It is constructed from light brown textured concrete bricks ('Besser Bricks') with two panels of perforated concrete blocks set into the wall. In front of the wall is a metal flagpole painted red, white and blue and a rose garden. These memorials were erected after each of the World Wars by the people of Balmoral as a tribute to those who served and those who fell in each of the great wars.

name: Hawthorn RSL Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Hawthorn RSL Hall, located on Glenferrie Road, was erected by the Returned Sailors and Soldiers as a club. The foundation stone was unveiled by Lieutenant General Sir H.C. Chauvel on 15th May 1920.

name: Terang WWII Memorial
description: The Terang WWII Memorial, outside the Terang RSL, comprises of a small rock monument inscribed with "Australia Remembers 1945-1995, In Honour of the Men and Women Who Served Australia In Time of Conflict During World War II, Lest We Forget."

name: Myrtleford War Memorial
description: The Myrtleford War Memorial, in Memorial Square on Myrtle Street, comprises of a memorial statue erected to commemorate the First World War. The monument features marble tablets listing 153 names of district service men and women, including tablets added for those who served in the Second World War.

name: Hawthorn Club War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Hawthorn Club War Memorial Plaque, on Glenferrie Road, is dedicated to the honour of 94 members of the Club who served during the Second World War, 7 of whom were killed.

name: Hawthorn South War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Hawthorn South War Memorial, on Anderson Road, is dedicated to the memory of all those Australians who gave their lives in times of war.

name: Hawthorn West Christ Church Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Hawthorn West Christ Church Memorial Hall is located on the corner of Creswick and Derham Streets.On 24th November 1923, the foundation stone for the Hall was unveiled by the Honourable Sir William M. McPherson, in memory of the men from the parish who served in the First World War.

name: Hazelwood Soldiers Settlement Memorial
description: The Hazelwood Soldiers Settlement Memorial, at the lookout off Brodribb Road, commemorates 51 returned soldiers from the First World War who were allocated land in Hazelwood to develop dairy farms. On 24th April 1988, the monument, a stone and plaque, was erected by the Morwell Yinnar and Boolara Members of the Returned Services League of Australia and the Morwell Shire Council.

name: Healesville War Memorial
description: The Healesville Shire Council and the RSL joined forces in the erection of a cenotaph outside the Memorial Hall. The cenotaph, made of polished and dressed granite, was unveiled by the RSL President Fred Clarke on Anzac Day 1961, in memory of "Our Glorious Dead."

name: Healesville Post-WWII Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Healesville Post-WWII Memorial, on the Maroondah Highway next to the R.S.L Club, comprises of a font on a decorative plinth. The memorial is dedicated to those men and women who served Australia between 1945-1973, including with the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F) Japan and conflicts in Korea, The Malayan Emergency, Sabah/Sarawak, Malayan Peninsula and Vietnam.

name: Heathcote Memorial Higher Elementary School
description: <FONT size=2>The Heathcote Memorial Higher Elementary School, at 31 Herriot Street, features a plaque commemorating the First World War. The plaque rests on the outside of the School building and lists the names of 76 soldiers who served.

name: Heathcote Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Heathcote Memorial Swimming Pool is dedicated to those of the McIvor Shire who fell in the Second World War.

name: Heathcote War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Heathcote War Memorial, in front of the Heathcote R.S.L. Public Hall on High Street, comprises of an obelisk monument. The memorial is dedicated to the memory of the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Heatherton WWII Memorial Obelisk
description: The Heatherton WWII Memorial Obelisk is located near the driveway of the Memorial Reserve in Ross Street, Heatherton. The memorial consists of an obelisk with one smooth face and three coarse faces on a roughly hewn plinth. A drinking fountain is incorporated into the base of the obelisk. The entire memorial is constructed from grey granite. The memorial is inscribed: Erected by the citizens of Heatherton in memory of all who served 1939 - 1945 for God King & Country. It is likely to date from the late 1940s.

name: RSL Memorial
description: The Returned Services League of Australia Memorial, is one of seven war memorials in the Heatherton Memorial Reserve. The memorial was erected c.2000 and comprises of a simple concrete block with a plaque mounted on the front. It is dedicated to all the Australian Returned Services Leagues.

name: Heatherton Memorial Reserve WWII Monument
description: <FONT size=2>The Heatherton Memorial Reserve WWII Monument consists of two granite forks on a granite base. It was originally unveiled in the Cheltenham Park on May 2nd, 1962 by Sir George Holland. The memorial is one of seven war memorials in the Reserve.

name: Heatherton WWI Memorial
description: The Heatherton First World War Memorial consists of a matching pair of granite, truncated columns with a wreath around the top on a tall plinth. These columns were erected on behalf of the residents of the Shire of Moorabbin and is one of seven war memorials in the Heatherton Memorial Reserve. They were once located outside the RSL Hall on the Nepean Highway Cheltenham but were relocated to the Reserve due to road widening works near the hall. The small monument between the two columns is constructed from bluestone and acknowledges the support of the RSL and the Australian Government in relocating the monuments in April 2000.

name: Heatherton Navy Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Heatherton Navy Memorial, one of seven war memorials in the Heatherton Memorial Reserve, commemorates all those who served with the RAN, RANR, RANVR, RANR(S), WRANS, RANNS and MN in all theatres of war. The memorial is a simple white column with the naval emblem and was erected in the late 1990s.

name: Moorabbin and Highett War Service League Memorial
description: The Moorabbin and Highett War Service League's Memorial is is one of seven war memorials in the Heatherton Memorial Reserve. The memorial is a small and rectilinear with a classical temple style front motif as a plaque, it isdedicated to those who died during the First World War.

name: Heatherton Boer War Memorial
description: The Heatherton Boer War Memorial, in the Memorial Reserve, consists of a red granite column on a bluestone base.The memorial is one of seven war monuments in the Reserve.

name: Heidelberg War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Heidelberg War Memorial, on Studley and Burgundy Streets, was unveiled on 20th June 1921. The memorial takes the form of an obelisk, listing thirty-two names of the fallen. Memorial panels were erected around the obelisk, on the 90th Anniversary of the Gallipoli Landing 25th April 2005, in memory of the Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital Rose Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital Rose Garden, on Waterdale Road, commemorates the lives of nurses who lost their lives in Malaya during the Second World War and on the A.H.S. Centaur, a hospital ship sunk of the coast of Queensland on 14th May 1943 by a Japanese Submarine.

name: Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital Siege of Tobruk Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital Siege of Tobruk Memorial comprises of a small plaque erected on 8th August 1996, on the 56th Anniversary of the Siege of Tobruk. A fig tree was also planted in remembrance of a similar tree that existed within the Defence Perimeter of Tobruk, 1941.

name: Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital Gallipoli Garden Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital Gallipoli Garden Memorial comprises of a plaque and flagpole unveiled on 2nd July 1991,to celebrate 50 years of the Hospital's services.

name: Heidelberg Remembrance Garden
description:
The Heidelberg Remembrance Garden commemorates an array of conflicts and personnel including memorial plaquesfor The Boer War, First World War heroes and Light Horse Regiment, Second World War Heroes and Infantry Battalions, an R.A.A.F. Propeller, Prisoners of War, Korea, Vietnam, Victoria Cross Winners, the Partially Blinded Soldiers' Association, War Widows, Totally and Permanently Disabled Soldiers Association, Tubercular Ex-Servicemen and Women and Australian Womens' contributions to Army and Navy services.

Other memorials in the Remembrance Garden include plaques dedicated to Private Bruce Kingsbury VC, and to his battalion, the 2/14th. The plaque lists the names of the 225 soldiers who paid the supreme sacrifice in New Guinea on the Kokoda Track, Gona and the Markham Ramu Valley, in North Africa and the Middle East, and the Balikpapan in Borneo.

A Vietnam Memorial was unveiled on 17 August 1999. The Repat holds a special place for Vietnam veterans. The text of the memorial reads:

This memorial is the culmination of thoughts and ideas gathered through contact with Vietnam veterans and particularly those who have had care and treatment through the Austin & Repatriation Medical Centre and the previous Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital.

The rock is a permanent reminder of the paitents who have been cared for and the staff who have given that care.

The white cross is a representation of those who shall stay young forever. The polished front represents the peace and tranquility that those who returned expected from the community. The uncut rough edges represent those who feel they never finished what could only be described as an extremely difficult task.

The reverse of the memorial represents the general feelings of those who returned and their experiences held in relation to negotiating acceptance that they served their country to the best of their ability.

On the reverse of the memorial, a poem is inscribed:

The Five Hundred Not Returned

By Len Curd, Service No. 39042, Unit 106 Field Battery, Nui Dat 1967-68

In earlier days of nationhood

Brave men fought on foriegn shores

Then once again the call was made

For men to fight and die in scores.

Five Hundred men, young and brave

For their country went to war

Most not yet old enough to vote

Yet gave their life on foriegn shore.

Five hundred men of this country great

For them as a nation we should weep

We sent them to die in a hopeless cause

Their sacred memory we must keeps

Fifty thousand were sent to fight

To uphold the traditions their fathers earned

In Vietnam they did their fathers proud

Now let us mourn the Five Hundred Not Returned.

name: Heidelberg Remembrance Park Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Heidelberg Remembrance Park Memorial, on Banksia Street and Studley Road, comprises of a plaque and flagpole dedicated to all citizens of Heidelberg who fought for Australia in times of war.

name: Heidelberg West War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Heidelberg West RSL Memorial, on Bell Street,was a colour stone cenotaph with a black crucifix and the simple inscription "Lest We Forget." This structure was replaced by two polished, black granite slabs similarly inscribed with "Lest We Forget."

name: Heidelberg West RSL Foundation Stone
description: <FONT size=2>The Heidelberg West RSL Foundation Stone, laid on 30th October 30th 1954, was dedicated by Major General Selwyn H. Porter in memory of the First World War, Second World War and Korea.

name: Heyfield War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Heyfield War Memorial, on George and Temple Streets, comprises of a pillar topped by an orb. The monument is dedicated to the First World War and Second World War.

name: Heyfield Memorial Hall
description: The Heyfield Memorial Hall is located at 2 Burnett Court. In June 1916 a conference of Returned Soldiers' Association recommended formation of the Returned Sailors and Soldiers Imperial League of Australia (RSSILA, now known as the Returned and Service League or RSL). After the First World War RSSILA branches all around Australia commenced a program of building halls in which their members could meet. Many RSL Memorial Halls are still in use in their communities and house honour rolls listing the local people who served and died during war.

name: Heyfield Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Heyfield Memorial Swimming Pool is located on Mary Street.

name: Heywood and District Memorial Hospital
description: The Heywood and District Memorial Hospital was opened by Dr. J.H. Lindell on 3rd October 1957.

name: Heywood and District Memorial Hospital Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The entrance gates to the Heywood and District Memorial Hospitalfeature the names of those who served in the Second World War.

name: Highett Post Office Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Highett Post Office Memorial Plaque was erected by the Highett R.S.L. on the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War, August 1995. It is dedicated to all Australian men and women who paid the supreme sacrifice during the Second World War.

name: Highton Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Highton Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the sports ground, are dedicated to six Highton men who served in the First World War and two Highton men who served in the Second World War.

name: Hill End War Memorial
description:
The Hill End War Memorial is located outside the Hill End Public Hall at 2494 Willow Grove Road. The memorial comprises of a granite obelisk on a rough-hewn stone plinth, surmounting a two-stepped stone base. It is enclosed within a low fence of concrete bollards linked by rusted iron chain links inside of which is planted Rosemary, a traditional plant of remembrance. It commemorates the dead of both world wars, in Hill End and nearby Fumina. The inscription reads:

"Erected by the residents of Hill End and Fumina in memory of those who made the Supreme Sacrifice in the Great War 1914 - 1919. T.G. Bloxom, E.H. Burgess, L. Cummins, H.V. Dogral, F.H. Hitchins, W.F. Paul. World War II 1939-45; T.C. Rees."

name: Hopetoun Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The foundation stone for the Hopetoun Memorial Hall was unveiled by bereaved mothers on 16th April 1923 in memory of their sons and the town's men who never returned from the First World War. Attached to the building is a tablet with the names of those who served in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: Hoppers Crossing St Peters Memorial Church
description: <FONT size=2>The Hoppers Crossing St Peter's Memorial Church, established on 6th October 1972, is dedicated to the memory of the fallen of the Second World War.

name: Horsham Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>The Horsham Cenotaph, on Firebrace and Hamilton Streets, was unveiled on 25th April 1958 in memory of the Second World War.

name: Horsham Memorial RSL Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The memorial stone for the Horsham Memorial RSL Hall was unveiled by E. Gulliver and laid by Brigadier General G.H. Brand on 22nd January 1921.

name: Hamilton Lamb Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Hamilton Lamb Memorial Hall, at 13 Kalkee Road, was opened in 1959. It is dedicated to the memory of Lieutenant George Hamilton Lamb, known as "Hammy", 2/2 Pioneer Battalion and Citizens Military Force. Lamb was elected as the Country Party member for the seat of Lowan in 1935 and re-elected while a Prisoner of War on the Burma Railway, where would die of illness on 7th December 1943. Lamb was the only politican to die of the 177 Australian politicians who served in the Second World War.

name: Horsham and District World War II Memorial Drive
description: <FONT size=2>The Horsham and District World War II Memorial Drive, located along Doeen Road, is marked by a cenotaph and plaque.

name: Horsham Boer War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Horsham Boer War Memorial Plaque is located on the old shire offices building and marks Roberts Avenue. The plaque was established in December 1901 to commemorate the service of British and Australian troops in the Boer War.

name: Horsham Post-WWII Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Horsham Post-WWII Memorial comprises of plaque, flagpole and wall dedicated to the memory of the Korean War, Vietnam War, Malaya and Borneo.

name: Horsham War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Horsham and District Cenotaph and War Memorial, in Sawyers Park, was unveiled on 18th April 2004 by John Forrest MP. The memorial comprises of flagpole and panels listing the names of those who served in the Womens Services, the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam, Bougainville, Iraq and East Timor.

name: Horsham Memorial Seat
description: <FONT size=2>The Horsham WWII Memorial Seat is located near the Horsham War Memorial Cenotaph in Sawyer Park. The seat is dedicated to the memory of First World War soldiers W.H. "Dick" Brown and E.F. Brown and Second World War soldiers A. Croydon Brown, W.H. "Bill" Brown and Jack Harper.

name: Horsham WWII Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>The Horsham WWII Memorial Plaques comprise of two small memorials dedicated to locals who served during the Second World War in Darwin. The first plaque is dedicated to the 19th Machine Gun Battalion (23rd Brigade) and their defence of 64 enemy air attacks on Darwin between 19th February 1942 -1944. The second plaque, erected 19th Februrary 2008, commemorates the 66th Anniversary of the first air attack on Australia and the Reigonal Personnel Units who defended Darwin.

name: Huntly War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Huntly War Memorial, in the Garden of Remembrance, comprises of a granite obelisk dedicated to those who served in the First World War, Second World War, Malaya, Korea, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Huntly Remembrance Garden and Plaques
description: The Huntly Remembrance Garden contains the Huntly War Memorial Obelisk and over twenty plaques featuring the names of men and women who served in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: Huntly Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Hurstbridge RSL War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Hurstbridge RSL War Memorial Plaque, on Anzac Avenue and Heidelberg-Kinglake Road, was erected in memory of all those who served Australia in times of war and those who paid the supreme sacrifice. It was unveiled by Peter Graham, President of the Eltham Shire Council, on 15th February 1991.

name: Hurstbridge Anzac Memorial Park
description: <FONT size=2>The Hurstbridge Anzac Memorial Park, on Anzac Avenue and Heidelberg-Kinglake Road, was established on 15th February 1991.

name: Illabarook and Rokewood Junction Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Illabarook and Rokewood Junction Memorial Hall, located at 44 Chathams Road, was established in 1957. After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. name: Inglewood Town Hall Memorial Clock
description: <FONT size=2>The Inglewood Town Hall Memorial Clock, on Verdon and Market Streets, is dedicated those who served in the Second World War.

name: Inverloch Memorial Rose Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Inverloch Memorial Rose Garden is located outside the community centre. The garden features plaques dedicated to those Inverloch residents who served and those who made the supreme sacrifice during the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Irrewillipe Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Irymple Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>The Irymple Cenotaph, located inside the grounds of the Irymple Memorial Swimming Pool, is dedicated to the memory of the Second World War. The monument features a bronze plaque with the names of 18 residents who made the supreme sacrifice and a plaque dedicated to the contribution of women from the Sunraysia District who served with the Australian Women's Land Army between 1942-1945.

name: Ivanhoe War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Ivanhoe War Memorial, on Studley and Upper Heidelberg Roads, comprises of a tablet framed by two classical pillars and a pediment. The tablet lists the names of those who served (including 47 fallen soldiers) in the First World War and the Second World War. In 1995, on the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War, a low pebble wall was erected around the monument. The wall features plaques dedicated to the fallen of the Second World War and those who served Australia in Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Ivanhoe East Memorial Kindergarten
description: <FONT size=2>The Ivanhoe East Memorial Kindergarten, located at 1 King Street, was built by the City of Heidelberg War Memorial Trust.

name: Jamieson War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Jamieson War Memorial, in Jamieson Park, comprises of a small stone monument and plaque. It was erected on April 25th 1986 in memory of those Jamieson residents who have served in the Defence Forces of Australia.

name: Jamieson Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Jeparit WWI Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Jeparit World War I Memorial, on Memorial Avenue, was erected on 19th June 1920. The memorial varies from the commonly erected digger statue, featuring a female figure instead. On the statue's base there 120 names of both the fallen and returned soldiers who served in the First World War.

name: Jindivick War Memorial
description:
The Jindivick War Memorial is located in a garden at the junction of Drouin Road and Jackson's Track. The memorial comprises of a coloured stone cairn and is dedicated to four residents who fell in the Second World War. Against each name is the date and the place of battle where they died:

W.L. Wembridge, Bardia 5.1.41

T.N. MacFarlane, El Alamein 31.10.42

G.A. Pincott, Salamaua 27.5.43

E.H. Peel, Lost at Sea 1.7.42

name: Jung WWII Honour Rolls
description: <FONT size=2>Two stone honour rolls, listing the names of those who served in the Second World War, are located on the exterior of the Jung Public Hall.

name: Jung War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Jung War Memorial, in Peppercorn Park, has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Kallista War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Kallista War Memorial, on Tom Roberts Road and Church Street, comprises of two boulders leant against one another. The monument was unveiled on the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War, August 19th 1995. The memorial is dedicated to 87 fallen and returned Kallista residents who served in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War and Vietnam.

name: Kanagulk Memorial Park
description: <FONT size=2>This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Kanagulk Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. name: Kangaroo Flat Soldiers Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Kangaroo Flat Soldiers Memorial, on the Calder Highway and View Street,comprises of a granite obelisk set upon three small flights of stairs. The monument is dedicated to the memory of the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam and Kuwait. Originally erected in 1914, the monument lists the names of 17 fallen residents who fought in the First World War and 6 names those who fell during the Second World War.

name: Kaniva Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Kaniva Memorial Wall is located on Progress Street on the site of the old Memorial Hall. The wall stands at the end of a paved circle behind a flagstaff and artillery gun. It was erected in memory of those who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Kaniva Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>Inside the grounds of the Kaniva Memorial Swimming Pool, on Baker Street, is an artillery gun and a cenotaph memorial dedicated to all the men and women who have served in the armed services during times of war.

name: Katandra West Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>The Katandra West Cenotaph was erected in memory of 21 year old Peter D. Hobart who was killed during the Second World War. Bronze honour rolls were later added to the monument to include all the Katandra West residents who served in the Second World War, First World War and Vietnam.

name: Katunga War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Katunga War Memorial is located on Bristol Street outside the R.S.L. Hall. The memorial comprises of a flagstaff dedicated to Katunga residents who fell in the First World War and lists the names of five servicemen who died in the Second World War: J.S. Christie, R.S. Ralston, A.M. Welch, C. Flack and E.P. Wignell.

name: Keilor East Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Keilor East Memorial Plaque is located on Hoffmans Road on the outside wall of the East Keilor R.S.L, next to a flagstaff and artillery gun. The plaque comprises of a cross and the simple epitaph "Lest We Forget."

name: Keilor East War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Keilor East War Memorial, in Heinze Park off Hoffmans Road, comprises of a grey cenotaph topped by a gold cross. The memorial site was unveiled by Les Crofts (OAM, JP) on 17th March 1996. The plaques attached to the memorial are dedicated by the Keilor East R.S.L. in memory of those Australians who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and South Vietnam.

name: Kennington War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Kennington War Memorial consists of a flagpole located outside the shire offices. The memorial is dedicated to all residents of the shire who served Australia in times of war.

name: Roby Manuel Memorial
description: The Roby Lewis Manuel Memorial, in Atkinson Memorial Park, comprises of a brass plaque on an upright stone. The inscription is dedicated to airman "Captain Roby Lewis Manuel DRC and bar twice MID, born October 7 1895, died October 18 1975." Roby was a member of the Australian Flying Corps when it began in 1917 and he fought over German lines, shooting down fifteen planes and battling the 'Red Baron' squadron. He led the fly past in London on Anzac Day 1919 and served again in the Second World War.

name: Kerang Memorial Municipal Chambers
description: <FONT size=2>The Kerang Memorial Municipal Chambers, on Victoria Street, opened on 25th March 1927. On the entrance porch are four bronze tablets listing the names of local residents who served in the First World War, including the names of 175 men who never returned home.

name: Kerang Memorial Hall
description: The Kerang Memorial Hall was opened on 21st September 1954. Inside the hall, honour rolls list the names of 1370 fallen and returned servicemen who fought in the Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Kerang WWII Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Kerang WWII Memorial Plaque, outside the Memorial Hall, was erected in the 50th Anniversary yearof the end of the Second World War, 13th August 1995. The plaque was unveiled by Major General WB "Digger" James (AO MBE MC), National President of the Returned and Services League of Australia, in memory of all Australian men and women who served in the Second World War.

name: Kergunyah Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Kew Library Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Kew Library Memorial Wall, on Civic Drive and White Horse Road, features four plaques dedicated to the conflicts in Korea, Borneo, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Mt Scopus College War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mt Scopus College War Memorial, in the school grounds, is dedicated to the fallen Jewish Servicemen who fought in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Kew RSL War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Kew RSL War Memorial comprises of a slate stone flagstaff with a platform and stairs. The memorial is adorned only with a bronze wreath and the inscription "Lest We Forget."

name: Booroondara Cemetery Boer War Grave
description: <FONT size=2>Inside Booroondara Cemetery lies the Huddart family grave and a memorial to the youngest son Cymbeline Alonso Edric killed in the Boer War. Edric served with the Royal Navy aboard the HMS Doris, before he was killed in action at Enslin, Cape Colony on 25th November 1899. Edric was the first Australian to be killed in the Boer War, he was 18 years old.

name: Kiata Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Kiewa Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Kiewa Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Recreation Reserve, commemorate those who served in the First World War, Second World War and Korea.

name: Kiewa Memorial Park
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Kilsyth Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Kilsyth Memorial Hall, on Dandenong Road, was established 7th August 1954. The Hall commemorates those who served in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: Kinglake War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Kinglake War Memorial comprises of a flagstaff on a paved square on Whittlesea Road and Exton Road.

name: Kinglake Memorial Reserve

name: Kinglake School Memorial Statue
description: <FONT size=2>A contemporary sculpture of a Digger is located in front of the Kinglake School.

name: Kingston WWI Cairn
description: <FONT size=2>The Kingston WWI Cairn is located at the junction of the Avenue of Honour and Alcorn Road. The memorial, unveiled on 11th November 2000, commemorates the service of 281 local men and women who enlisted in the First World War.

name: Koondrook Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Koondrook Memorial Hall was opened in 1925 to commemorate the First World War, plaques were later added in memory of the Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Koondrook RSL Memorial Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Koondrook RSL Memorial Garden, on Arbuthnot Street, comprises of a rose bed and rough stone cairn. The garden is dedicated to those who paid the supreme sacrifice in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: Koondrook WWII Cairn
description: A rough stone cairn memorial was erected outside the Koondrook RSL to commemorate the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Koo Wee Rup Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Koo Wee Rup Memorial Wall is located outside the Western Port Memorial Hospital on Rossiter Road. The wall is dedicated to the memory of 19 local residents who fell in the First World War and 8 who fell in the Second World War.The plaques were transferred from the original Koo Wee Rup and District Fallen Soldiers Memorial Hospital.

name: Koo Wee Rup Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Koo Wee Rup Memorial Hall, on Rossiter Road, was opened in July 1925 to commemorate the First World War.

name: Koo Wee Rup and District War Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Koo Wee Rup and District War Memorial Swimming Pool was opened on 2nd February 1975 by the Minister for Youth, Sport and Recreation, B.J. Dixon.

name: Koo Wee Rup Memorial Seat
description: <FONT size=2>The Koo Wee Rup Memorial Seat, in Lions Park, commemorates the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Koo Wee Rup and District War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Koo Wee Rup War Memorial, in front of the community centre, comprises of a black obelisk and two panels listing the names of all those locals who served in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, the Indonesian Confrontation, Vietnam and peace keeping missions.

name: Koroit and District Memorial Health Services
description: <FONT size=2>The original Koroit District Memorial Hospital was opened in 1955 and converted in 1994 to provide nursing home facilities and mental health services. A plaque on the building is dedicated to the memory of the First and Second World Wars.

name: Korong Vale War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Korong Vale War Memorial, in Borella Park, is dedicated to the memory of the First World War and Second World War. The memorial comprises of a digger statue standing with hisrifle upside down, the symbolic funereal position of "reversed arms."

name: Borella Park
description:
Borella Park was opened on Anzac Day, 25th April 1988, by the Shire President C.R. L.E. The park is dedicated to the memory of Victoria Cross winner of Lieutenant Albert Chalmers Borella (1881-1968) of the 26th Australian Infantry Battalion A.I.F.He was awarded theVC for most conspicuous bravery in attack on 17 to 18 July 1918 at Villers- Bretonneux. The citation reads:

Whilst leading his platoon with the first wave, Lieutenant Borella marked an enemy machine gun firing though our barrage. He ran out ahead of his men into the barrage, shot two German machine gunners with his revolver, and captured the gun. He then led his party, now reduced to ten men and two Lewis guns, against a very strongly held trench, using his revolver, and later a rifle, with great effect, causing many enemy casualties. His leading and splendid example resulted in the garrison being quickly shot or captured.

Borella was born at Borung, Victoria, and educated at Borung and Echuca districts; he also served for eighteen months with the Victorian Rangers. In 1910, he was a fireman in Melbourne, resigning in January 1913 to take up a pastoral lease, drawn by ballot, on the Daly River.

In 1915, Borella was a cook for a survey party in Tennant Creek and set out for Queensland to volunteer for active service. At the outbreak of the war, volunteers from the Northern Territory were not being accepted. With Charlie, an Aboriginal man, he walked 88 miles (140 kilometres) and swam across flooded rivers. After borrowing a horse at powell Creek, just north of Renner Springs, Northern Territory, he rode to Katherine, where he caught the mail coach to the railhead at Pine Creek. He sailed from Darwin to Townsville on 8 March 1915 with four other men who were among the first fifteen volunteers for active service from the Northern Territory.

Borella enlisted in the 26th Battalion in March 1915 and served at Gallipoli before proceeding to the Western Front. Lieutenant Borella received the Military Medal for conspicuous bravery in the attack on Malt Trench, north of Warlencourt on the night of 1 March 1917, winning the Victoria Cross a year later in 1918.

At the end of the war, Borella was invalided back to Australia. From 1920, he farmed a soldier settlement block near Hamilton in Victoria. In 1924, he stood for the seat of Dundas in the Victorian Legislative Assembly as the National Party candidate, but was narrowly defeated.

On the outbreak of the Second World War, Borella was appointed lieutenant in the 12th Australian Garrison Battalion with which he served until 1941 when he was attached to the Prisoner of War Group at Rushworth. Promoted to captain on 1 September 1942, he served with the 51st Garrison Company at Myrtleford until discharged in 1945. He then moved to Albury where he died in 1968 and was buried in North Albury.

name: Korong Vale Boer War Honour Roll
description: <FONT size=2>The Korong Vale Boer War Honour Roll is located inside the Mechanics Institute on Allen Street. The honour roll comprises of brass and lists the names of 4 men who served.

name: Stanley Savige Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Stanley Savige Memorial Gates, at the entrance to Coleman Park, are dedicated to Lieutenant General Savige who founded Legacy. Savige died on 15th May 1954, the gates were dedicated to him on 27th November 1955.

name: Kyabram War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Kyabram War Memorial, in the Memorial Gardens on Allan Street, was erected on 25th April 1922. The monument comprises of a marble obelisk resting on four red pillars and a three-stepped base. It is dedicated to those who served in the First World War, listing the names of 63 locals who never returned home.

name: Kyabram Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Kyabram Memorial Gates were erected by residents, at the cost of £20,000, as a memorial to the Second World War. The gates list the names of those who died fighting between 1939-1945 and a plaque added on ANZAC Day 1989 to commemorate the Korean War.

name: Haslem Street Primary School
description: <FONT size=2>The entrance gates to the Haslem Street Primary School are dedicated to former students who died in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Kyabram and District Memorial Community Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Kyabram and District Memorial Community Hospital, on Fenaughty Street, was opened by Councillor William McMaster Smith on 9th November 1958.

name: Kyneton Memorial RSL Club Rooms
description: <FONT size=2>The Kyneton Memorial RSL Club Rooms were opened by Sir Dallas Brooks on 28th May 1954, in memory of fallen comrades. Plaques were added to the building to mark the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War and Australians who served in Vietnam.

name: Kyneton Boer War Honour Roll
description: <FONT size=2>The Kyneton Boer War Honour Roll, inside the Town Hall, lists the names of local residents who served between 1901-1902.

name: Kyneton WWII Memorial Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Kyneton WWII Memorial Garden, near the town monument, commemorates the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.
