name: Lake Boga Community Centre Memorial
description: The Lake Boga Community Centre Memorial comprises of an artillery gun and flagpole located outside the building.

name: Lake Bolac Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Lake Bolac Memorial Hall was erected in 1922, on the site between the blacksmith shop and the hotel. In 1959, a Memorial Foyer was added to the building to commemorate the Second World War. On the exterior of the building is a black marble tablet listing the names of those residents who served and those who did not return from the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam.

name: Lake Charm Boer War Honour Roll
description: <FONT size=2>The Lake Charm Boer War Honour Roll, inside the Lake Charm Memorial Hall, is dedicated to Pte. T.J. McCurdy of the 3rd Buchmen's Contingent.

name: Lake Marmal Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Lake Marmal Memorial Hall was erected in memory of the First World War. After the First and Second World Wars, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Lakes Entrance War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Lakes Entrance War Memorial, on Marine Parade, comprises of a granite obelisk resting between two flagstaffs on a paved square. The obelisk was originally erected to commemorate the First World War but was rededicated to include the names of those who served in the Second World War. A plaque was also added to include later wars in Korea, Malaya, Borneo,Vietnam and the Gulf War.

name: Lakes Entrance WWI Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Lakes Entrance WWI Memorial comprises of a plaque on a rough stone, erected on 11th November 1998 by the Lakes Entrance Reigonal Historical Society. The plaque lists the namesof 26 residents who fought and died between 1914-1918.

name: Landsborough WWI Memorial Park Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Landsborough and District R.S.L. Memorial Park Gates, on Forestry Road, are dedicated to the fallen of the First World War and Second World War.

name: Landsborough Anglican Church Memorial Fence
description: <FONT size=2>The brick fence in front of the Landsborough Anglican Church features a memorial plaque dedicated to John Ingram, who died of wounds at Rouen on December 1st 1916.

name: Lang Lang War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Lang Lang War Memorial, on Western Port Road, comprises of a small grey obelisk engraved with the names of 21 residents who fell in the First World War. It has since been rededicated to commemorate those who served in the Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Lang Lang and District Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Lang Lang and District Soldiers Memorial Hall, on McDonalds Track, is dedicated to the memory of the First World War. The Hall originally comprised of the 1880s timber Mechanic's Institute Hall, a brick facade was added after the First World War when it was rededicated as the Soldiers Memorial Hall and Free Library. In 1966, the Hall was destroyed by fire and then rebuilt in 1972 in its current form, with the help of local fundraising.

name: Langkoop Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Langkoop Memorial Hall is dedicated to the veterans of the First World War who returned to settle the area with their families. A commemorative stone unveiled on 8th April 1920, lists the names of those soldiers who were alloted the 37,100 acres of land that became known as the Elderslie Estate.

name: Lara Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Lara Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Sports Ground, are dedicated to the men and women who served in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam. The gate pillars list the names of those who served and include a plaque to commemorate the planting of the Avenue of Honour.

name: Lara RSL War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Lara RSL War Memorial comprises of a coloured stone flag staff.

name: Lascelles Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Lascelles Memorial Gates, on Wychunga and Boree Streets, are dedicated to 82 fallen and returned residents who fought in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Laverton Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Laverton Memorial Swimming Pool was officially opened by Brian Dixon, Minister for Youth, Sport and Recreation, in June 1976. The Pool is dedicated to the memory of those Australians who served in times of war.

name: Learmonth Honour Avenue Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Learmonth Honour Avenue Memorial Wall was officially opened by Sir Edward "Weary" Dunlop on 1st August 1993. The wall lists the names of 234 fallen and returned soldiers who fought in the First World War.

name: Learmonth Boer War Memorial Obelisk
description: The Learmonth War Memorial Obelisk, located on the Sunraysia Highway, commemorates the Boer War. The obelisk is constructed from red granite and is specifically dedicated to Sergeant Charles Vaughn, killed in action in South Africa, Feburary 13th 1901.

name: Leitchville Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Leitchville Memorial Hall, on Hawkin Street and Findlay Avenue, commemorates those who gave their lives in the First World War.

name: Leongatha War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Leongatha War Memorial, outside the Remembrance Hall, is a granite obelisk dedicated to the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Sabah-Sarawak, the Malayan Peninsula (Indonesian Confrontation) and Vietnam.

name: Leongatha Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Leongatha Memorial Hospital was opened by the Governor of Victoria, General Sir Dallas Brooks, on 24th June 1958.

name: Leopold Memorial Park
description: <FONT size=2>This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Lethbridge Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Lethbridge Memorial Gates form the entrance to the sports ground on Stephenson Street. The gates are dedicated to the memory of Lethbridge men who served in the Second World War.

name: Lexton War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Lexton War Memorial, outside the RSL Hall, comprises of an artillery gun and plaque. The memorial was unveiled by the Waubra Sub Branch in 1975, in memory of Australian men and women who have served in times of war.

name: Lilydale Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Lilydale Memorial Wall, on the Maroondah Highway and Clarke Street, was erected 1st September 1996. The wall is dedicated to the memory of Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam and Peacekeeping Missions. Five men are listed as the fallen in the Vietnam War: Michael J. Hannaford, Raymond J. Moore, Malcolm R. Robertson, Geoffrey L. Tweedie and Gary L. Willoughby.

name: David Mitchell Estate Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The David Mitchell Estate Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Cavehill Quarry, are dedicated to former employees of the Quarry who served in the Second World War. The gates list the names of 73 fallen and returned servicemen.

name: Lilydale Mafeking Tree
description: <FONT size=2>The Lilydale Mafeking Tree, in Melba Park, was planted by the Lilydale community on 13th June 1900 to commemorate the successful defence of Mafeking, South Africa during the Boer War. A British garrison of men, led by Colonel Baden-Powell, held down Mafeking town which was under siege from Boer forces for over 209 days.

name: Lilydale Militia Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Lilydale Militia Memorial comprises of a plaque dedicated to those residents who served in the Victorian Mounted Rifles 1891-1900, the 48th Battalion 1911-1918 and the 24th Battalion 1918-1943.

name: Lindenow War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Lindenow War Memorial, outside the Memorial Hall, consists of a coloured stone wall, flagpole and plaque. Unveiled on Australia Day 2000, the memorial is dedicated to all those residents who served in times of War, sacrificed their lives and to all those who supported the war effort on the home front, through industry and work in the community.

name: Little River Memorial Gates
description: The Little River Memorial Gates form the entrance to the Recreation Reserve. The inscription reads: "These gates commemorate the loyalty, devotion and valour of those who served in the World War 1939-1945. In War - Resolution. In Defeat - Defiance. In Victory - Magnanimity. In Peace - Good Will."

name: Loch Post Office War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Outside the Loch Post Office is a squat, black obelisk dedicated to the Second World War and Vietnam. Engraved in gold on the base of the monument are 179 names of those locals who served and those who never returned.

name: Loch Public Hall
description: <FONT size=2>This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Loch Sport War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Loch Sport War Memorial, outside the R.S.L, comprises of two intersecting red-brick walls capped by a cross and the epitaph - Lest We Forget.

name: Lockington and District Community Centre
description: <FONT size=2>The Lockington and District Community Centre contains the original foundation stone of the Memorial Hall. The Hall was erected in 1922 as a memorial to those who fought in the First World War.

name: Lockington Wall of Remembrance
description: <FONT size=2>The Lockington Wall of Remembrance, outside the Community Centre, was erected 15th August 1995. The Wall comprises of a cross, a garden bed and a plaque dedicated to all those who have served the Australian Military at home or abroad.

name: Lorquon Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Lorquon Memorial Hall was opened in 1956. After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Lower Homebush War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Lower Homebush War Memorial comprises of an Honour Roll plaque located in the grounds of Primary School. The plaque was unveiled on 11th April 1993 to honour those locals who served in the First World War, seven of whom paid the supreme sacrifice.

name: Lubeck Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Lucknow Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Lucknow Memorial Hall, at 105 Alpine Road, was opened by W.O. Fulton on 9th October 1953. After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Lysterfield War Memorial
description: The Lysterfield War Memorial comprises of an asymmetrical stone monument with plaques dedicated to 32 fallen and returned locals who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Vietnam and East Timor.

name: Former Macarthur and District Memorial Hospital
description: The Macarthur and District Memorial Hospital was opened by E.P. Cameron, Minister of Health, on 20th November 1960. The building is now used as a community outreach centre.

name: Macarthur Soldier Settlement Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Macarthur Soldier Settlement Memorial, comprising of a boulder and plaque, is dedicated to ex-servicemen of the Second World War who settled estates in thedistrict between 1948-1961. With their families, the ex-servicement established farms on estates such as East Elwood, Archers, Alanvale, Eerilya, Glengleeson East, Glen Gleeson West, Tarrone, Moyne Flats, Deerhurst, Gerrigerrup, Mt. Napier, Moyne Falls, Koornong, Weerangcourt and Youngs.

name: Macedon War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Macedon War Memorial Plaque, located at the junction of the Avenue of Honour and Mt Macedon Road, is dedicated to those locals who served in First World War and Second World War.

name: Macedon Peace Memorial Drinking Fountain
description: <FONT size=2>The Macedon Peace Memorial Drinking Fountain, in the school grounds, was erected to commemorate the signing of the peace Treaty of Versailles on 28th June 1919.

name: McKinnon War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The McKinnon War Memorial, on Mckinnon Road and Wattle Grove, comprises of a granite obelisk dedicated those residents who served in the First World War. The obelisk listst the names of those who served and the inscription: "Erected by the residents of McKinnon as a tribute of love and gratitude to her glorious dead and to returned men who fought to keep the empire free in the Great War 1914-1918." A plaque was added in memory of those who fell in the Second World War, Malaya,Korea, Vietnam and Borneo.

name: Maffra WWI Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Maffra Memorial Hall, on Johnston Street, was erected after the First World War to commemorate peace. The foundation stone was laid by Mrs. John Mills in August 1922. Another memorial stone was laid by J.W. McLachlan in memory of the fallen.

name: Maffra Memorial Tree
description: <FONT size=2>The Maffra Memorial Tree was planted to commemorate the 75th Anniversary of the end of the First World War. It was planted by W.L. Cumming, Shire President, 11th November 1993.

name: Maffra Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Maffra Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Maffra Memorial Swimming Pool was opened by General Sir Dallas Brooks on 19th October 1960.

name: Majorca War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Majorca War Memorial consists of a stone obelisk dedicated to the First and Second World War.

name: Maldon Anzac Hill Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Maldon Anzac Hill Memorial was established as part of the Maldon Sub-Branch Returned Services League, 1988 Bicentennial Year Project. The Memorial comprises of a plaque and German-made Turkish Gun, which was used against Australian Forces at Gallipoli in 1915.The gun was restored with money raised by local residents and was unveiled on 24th April 1988.

name: Maldon Memorial Stone
description: <FONT size=2>The Maldon Memorial Stone, inside the Shire Gardens, was erected in memory of the First World War. The monument features an ornate bronze plaque inscribed with, "In Memoriam. Their name shall live for evermore. In grateful memory of the men from this shire who gave their lives in the Great War." At the top of the monument dedications have been added for the Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Mallacoota War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mallacoota War Memorial, on Maurice Avenue, comprises of a brick panel and flagstaff. The memorial was unveiled on 14th April 1989 by Rev. Ken Campbell in memory of all those who served their nation. In 1995, plaques were added to the monument to honour men and women who served Australia and for those who men and women who paid the supreme sacrifice during the Second World War.

name: Mallacoota RAAF Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mallacoota R.A.A.F Memorial Plaque was erected by Malacoota Sub-Branch R.S.L. It commemorates the service and sacrifice of R.A.A.F personnel who were stationed at Mallacoota during the Second World War.

name: Malmsbury Memorial Gateway
description: The Malmsbury Memorial Gateway is located at the entrance to the Botanic Gardens on the Calder Highway. The gateway reads, "Malmsbury's tribute to her brave men who enlisted in the Great War 1914-1918."

name: Malvern War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Malvern War Memorial is located inside Central Park on Wattletree Road and Kingston Street. The memorial comprises of an ornamental bluestone obelisk, engraved with the gold lettering of 183 names of fallen residents. Unveiled on 19th March 1922, the memorial has been rededicated to conflicts after the First World War, including the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam. The original inscription reads, " In memory of those brave men residents of Malvern, who gave their lives in the Great War 1914-1918. Erected by a grateful Englishman."

name: Malvern Town Hall War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Malvern Town Hall War Memorial, located in the foyer of the Hall on Glenferrie Road, was erected on 23rd August 1931. Carved by Paul Montford, the memorial comprises of three marble relief statues; a mother cradling a child and a soldier. The figures stand, with heads cast down, on either side of a tablet adorned with a wreath and the Rising Sun emblem. Resting between them is an honour roll book encased in glass, which records in illuminated script the names of those Malvern and Prahan servicemen who died in the First World War. The tablet is inscribed with the dates of the First World War, Second World War, Malaya, Korea, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: East Malvern Hockey Club Memorial Tree
description: <FONT size=2>The East Malvern Hockey Club Memorial, in Central Park, is a small bronze plaque erected beneath a Palm tree. The plaque is dedicated to members of the East Malvern Hockey Club who died serving in the Second World War.

name: East Malvern RSL Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The East Malvern RSL Memorial Gates were unveiled by Lady Brooks on 8th October 1955. The gates were the initiative of the Ladies Auxiliary (East Malvern Sub-Branch R.S.S.A.I.L.A.) and stand in memory of the fallen.

name: East Malvern RSL Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The East Malvern RSL Memorial Plaque, on the outside wall at the entrance, was erected in honour of the men and women who served in the First World War, Second World War, Malaya, Korea, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Manangatang War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Manangatang War Memorial, on the main street, was erected by the Manangatang RSL Sub-Branch. The memorial is a red brick flagstaff with a black cross and the epitaph, "Lest We Forget."

name: Mannibadar Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Mansfield War Memorial Arch and Gates
description:
The Mansfield War Memorial Arch, at the entrance to the Sports Ground, was erected in 1921 as a memorial to residents who died fighting in the First World War. TheMansfield Memorial Gates were designed by Irwin and Stevenson AARIBA, William Street Melbourne. Irwin was a Melbourne Uni. Architect who was a WW1 returned soldier who studied in London prior to returning to Victoria. Anecdotally, the Gates are modeled on the Menin Gates in Belgium.

In 2007, the Minister for Veteran Affairs Bruce Billson unveiled plaques for the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Vietnam, Malaya, Indonesian Confrontation, Vietnam, Korea, East Timor, Gulf War, Iraq War, Afghanistan and Peace Keeping missions.

Front inscription reads:

LEST WE FORGET.

ERECTED BY THE RESIDENTS OF MANSFIELD AND DISTRICT TO THE MEMORY OF THE FALLEN SOLDIERS IN THE GREAT WAR 1914 - 19

name: Marcus Hill Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Maribyrnong War Memorial
description: The Maribyrnong War Memorial, inside McDonald Gardens, comprises of a stone obelisk erected on 30th April 1922. First dedicated to the First World War, it now includes dedications to the Second World War, Malaya, Korea and Vietnam. The main inscription is an excerpt from Robert Laurence Binyon's poem For The Fallen (1914), "At the going down of the sun and in the morning we will remember them."

name: Victorian Anti-Aircraft and Searchlight Units Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Victorian Anti-Aircraft and Searchlight Units Memorial stands outside the Highpoint West Shopping Centre on Rosamond Road, Maribyrnong. The memorial plaque commemorates the site as the headquarters of the Anti-Aircraft Searchlight Companies that defended Melbourne during the Second World War. The units trained in Maribyrnong going on to serve in Darwin, New Guinea, Borneo, Java and the Middle East.

name: Maribyrnong "Sandy" Horse Memorial
description:
The Maribyrnong "Sandy" Horse Memorial Plaque is located outside the Community Centre on Randall Street. The plaque is dedicated to the honour of the Australian Light Horseman and the horses they rode during the First World War. Of particular note is the Light Horse "Sandy", the favourite charge of Major General William Throsby Bridges, Commander of the 1st Division of the Light Horse. Bridges died of wounds on 15th May 1915 at Anzac Cove but Sandy was sent onto to Egypt where he remained until the end of the war.

After the end of the war Sandy was shipped back to Australia where he lived for another six years at the Maribyrnong Remount Depot before he was put down in 1923 due to blindness. Of the 169,000 horses shipped from Australia to the front, only one, Sandy, returned home. Bridges was the only Australian First World War dead to return home to Australia (excepting the Unknown Soldier).

name: Marungi Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Marungi Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the recreation reserve, are dedicated to those who served in the Second World War.

name: Maryborough South East Asia Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Maryborough South East Asia Memorial, in Phillips Gardens, was unveiled on 16th February 1997 by John Gault, Chief Commissioner of the Central Goldfields Shire. The memorial is a flagstaff with a large concrete base engraved in gold with the dates of the wars in Korea, Vietnam, Malaya and Borneo. On 18th August 2006, the flagstaff was presented to the Central Goldfields Shire by the Victorian Vietnam Veterans Community to mark the 40th Anniversary of the Battle of Long Tan.

name: Marysville Primary School War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Marysville Primary School War Memorial, on Falls Road, is a flagpole monument dedicated to Trooper Ralph G.Gould. The Gould family presented the monument in memory of their son and brother who was killed in action at Borneo on 30th June 1944, and in memory of the pupils of the school who served in times of war.

name: Former Marysville Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Marysville Memorial Hall and Local History Centre was destroyed in 2009 during the Black Saturday Bushfires.

name: Victorian Rowers Association Judge's Box Memorial
description: The Victorian Rowers Association Judging Box, on Jeffreys Parade, was dedicated as a memorial to the First World War in 1930. The front inscription simply reads "Oarsmen Memorial Judges Box 1914 - 1918."

name: Meeniyan War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Meeniyan War Memorial Obelisk is a small granite monument erected next to the First World War Memorial on Whitelaw Street. The obelisk is dedicated to the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Women's Services Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Women's Services Memorial, in Alexandra Gardens, is dedicated to the 70,000 women who served Australia in the Navy, Army, Airforce and Auxillary Services. The memorial commemorates the contribution of women in times of war from nursing soldiers in the Boer War, to working in hospitals, camps, barracks, ships and underground during the First World War, Second World War, Malaya, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Melbourne Nurses Memorial Centre
description: The Melbourne Nurses Memorial Centre, at 431 St. Kilda Road, is a memorial to the Australian Nurses who died during the Second World War. It was established following a public appeal in 1946, initiated by Victorian nurses who had returned from the war, especially Betty Jeffrey and Vivian Bullwinkel. Over the next two years, they collected 78,000 pounds and the Nurses Memorial Centre opened on 14 May 1949. Jeffrey became the centre's administrator, but continuing ill-health forced her to retire in 1954. Outside the building is a memorial cenotaph with a bronze bust of a nurse in uniform and a plaque.

name: Centaur Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Centaur Memorial, outside the Fawkner Towers in Slater Street, comprises of the mast of the hospital ship Centaur which was torpedoed on 14th May 1943. The mast was donated in 1951 by Huddard Parker Limited in memory of the nurses aboard the Centaur who lost their lives.

name: Chamber of Manufacturers War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Chamber of Manufacturers War Memorial, at 370 St Kilda Road, is a bronze sculpture of a digger in action with one arm swinging a bayonet and his leg placed forward on a mound of earth. It was sculpted by C. Web Gilbert and dedicated to the loving memory of Australia's sons who fell in the First World War.

name: Melbourne General Cemetery Jewish War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Inside the Melbourne General Cemetery, on College Crescent, is an obelisk dedicated to the memory of fallen Jewish soldiers from Victoria who served in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: St. Peter's Anglican Church War Memorial
description: Outside St. Peter's Church, on Gisborne and Albert Streets, is a crucifix monument dedicated to the First World War. The memorial comprises of a bronze crucified Christ mounted on a sandstone platform with the inscription Invictus Pax 1914 - 1918. On the back of the monument the inscription reads, "This wayside crucifix was unveiled on 16 March 1924 by the Governor General and blessed by the Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne. It is a war memorial to honour, in the first instance, the 366 young men and women who went out from this city Anglican Church St. Peter, to serve in the Great War. Through generations it has remained a lovingly tended place of remembrance, devotion and prayer. INVICTUS PAX 'Peace to the unconquered.' 1914-1918."

name: Victorian Rowing Association Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Victorian Rowing Association Memorial, on Boathouse Road and Alexandria Avenue, was unveiled on 30th March 1924. The memorial takes the form of a marble cylinder with brass plaques on a hexagonal base. The plaques list the names of former Rowing Assoication members who were killed in the First World War.

name: Mercantile Rowing Club Memorial Boat House
description: <FONT size=2>The Mercantile Rowing Club Memorial Boat House is located on Jeffrey Parade, on the Yarra Riverbank.

name: Sir Edward Weary Dunlop Memorial Statue
description:
In the Kings Domain, on St Kilda Road, stands a memorial statue of Sir Edward "Weary" Dunlop. The statue was sculpted by Peter Corlett and unveiled in 1995.

At the outbreak of the Second World War, Dunlop was working as a surgeon at St. Mary's Hospital, Paddington. He enlisted in the Australian Army Medical Corps (6th Division) on 13 November 1939 as Medical Officer, Headquarters, Australian Overseas Base, Jerusalem, and appointed Acting Assistant Director of Medical Services. He was promoted to major on 1 May 1940 and appointed Deputy Director of Medical Services on the staff of the Australian Corps Headquarters and AIF Headquarters in Gaza and Alexandria.

Appointed as AIF Medical Liason, he served in both Greece and Crete. On 18 July 1941, he was senior surgeon with the 2/2nd Casualty Clearing Station at Tobruk. With the withdrawal of the 6th and 7th Divisions from the Middle East, Dunlop and the 2/2nd Casualty Clearing Station were transferred to Java. Lieutenant Colonel Dunlop was in command of No.1 Allied General Hospital at Bandung when Java fell to the Japanese, and he became a prisoner of war.

Australian prisoners of war on Java under Dunlop's command were transferred later in 1942 to Singapore. On 20 January 1943, he left Singapore for Thailand in charge of 'Dunlop Force' to work on the Burma-Thailand railway. He remained there until the war ended, labouring tirelessly to save wounded, sick and malnourished men. Many times he put his own life at risk as he stood up to the brutality of his Japanese captors.

Other doctors, such as Albert Coates, acted in an equally selfless way, but Dunlop was the one to become an inspiration among Australian prisoners of war and in Australia after the war. Returning to Australia in October 1945, he was demobilised on 1 February 1946. In February 1946, Dunlop resumed his medical career, establishing a thriving private practice and working as honorary surgeon at the Royal Melbourne Hospital. In 1969, he was Team Leader of the Australian Surgical Team to South Vietnam.

Dunlop maintained an ongoing concern for the health and welfare of former prisoners of war. He led commemorative tours to the Burma-Thailand railway. He came to reject hatred of his former captors and promoted reconciliation with the Japanese. Dunlop died at home on 2 July 1993.

name: Melbourne University War Memorial
description: The Melbourne University War Memorial, on the South Lawn between Wilson Hall and the Old Law Quadrangle, comprises of a cenotaph dedicated to the First World War and Second World War. On the four faces of the monument, latin inscriptions read "Bene Meritis Domi Militiaeque 1914-1918, 1939- 1945, De Imperio, De Academia, De Patria."

name: North Melbourne War Memorial
description: The North Melbourne War Memorial, on King and Hawke Streets, was erected by the North and West Melbourne Red Cross Society. The memorial comprises of a stone pillar dedicated to the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Sabah Sarawak, Malaya and Vietnam. The inscription first engraved after the First World War reads, "In imperishable memory of Australia's sons who died in the cause of freedom in the Great War 1914-1918."

name: Errol Street Primary School Memorial Fountain
description: <FONT size=2>The North Melbourne Drinking Fountain, in the grounds of Errol Street Primary School, was erected in honour of former students who served in the First World War.

name: Charles Moore Boer War Memorial Fountain
description:
The Boer War Memorial, in St. Vincent Gardens on Montague Street and St. Vincent Place, comprises of a pillar dedicated to the memory of Trooper Charles "Charlie" Moore. Moore was the first VFL/AFL footballer killed in war. Moore was 25 when he enlisted in the 4th Victorian Contingent, the Victorian Imperial Bushmen. The 631-strong unit left Melbourne on 1 May 1900, commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Nicholas William Kelly, who was wounded in Feburary 1901 and invalided to England. On 12 May, Moore was on patrol near Mt Tooberg, South Africa when he had his horse shot out from underneath him. He took cover behind the body of the fallen horse and was seriously wounded when a bullet passed through its dead body. Moore eventually killed his Boer opponent after eight shots and was crawling to safety when he was found by his comrades. He was taken to the nearby Kwaggashoek Farm but died of his wounds on 13th May 1902, aged 26.

Moore is buried in the Dutch Reformed Church Cemetery Somerset East, Eastern Cape, South Africa. His memorial in St Vincents Place, Albert Park, is across the road from his mother's house.

Among Moore's comrades was Corporal Harold 'Pompey' Elliot, who was awarded the DCM for the capture of a Boer patrol near Doornkloof in Feburary 1901. As brigadier general, Elliot commanded the 15th Brigade in the First World War. Moore's comrades also included Captain Edwin Tivey, who was awarded the DSO by Edward VII for his actions in Phllipstown and rose temporarily command the Australian 5th Division inthe First World War. The Victorian Bushmen lost fourteen men killed in action, fatally wounded or dead from disease.

name: Johnson Memorial Shelter
description: The Johnson Memorial Shelter, inside St. Vincent Gardens,was erected in 1916. The shelter is dedicated to the memory of Dr. Frederick Miller Johnson killed at Gallipoli on 29th November 1915. The epitaph reads "He died as he lived, nobly doing his duty."

name: South Melbourne Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The South Melbourne Memorial Hall, at Ferrars and James Service Place, was opened 9th March 1924 by the Governor of Victoria and Earl of Stradbroke. The hall was dedicated to the First World War in 1924 and then on Anzac Day 1952 was rededicated to the Second World War.

name: Melton Primary School Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>On 11th November 1998, the Melton Primary School Memorial Gates were relocated to Willows Historical Park on Reserve Road and Nixon Road. Inscribed only with "Lest We Forget", the gates are dedicated to the First World War.

name: Mentone War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mentone War Memorial is located on Mentone Road opposite the RSL Hall. The memorial comprises of a black flagstaff engraved with a gold cross and "Lest We Forget."

name: Merbein Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Merbein Memorial Gates form the entrance to Kenny Park on Box and Smith Streets. The gates commemorate the First and Second World Wars, listing the names of those residents who served.

name: Merbein Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Merbein Memorial Wall, on Commercial Street and Main Avenue, lists the names of those servicemen and women who fought in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam.

name: St Johns Merbein Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The foundation stone for St Johns Merbein Memorial Hall was laid on 23rd September 1956, in memory of the fallen of the First World War and Second World War.

name: Meredith War Memorial Obelisk
description: The Meredith War Memorial Obelisk, on Staughton and Wallace Streets, was erected in memory of the First World War. The inscription reads: " To the undying memory of the men of this district who served their king and gave their lives in the European War 1914-1918." Inscriptions were added to commemorate those who served in the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Meredith Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Millewa District Honour Roll
description: <FONT size=2>The Millewa District Honour Roll was erected in the Pioneer Forest Plantation on 28th April 1991. The roll lists 326 names of fallen and returned Millewa district servicemen who fought in the Second World War and Korea.

name: Merino Soldier Settlement Memorial
description: The Merino Soldiers Settlement Memorial commemorates the establishment of the Glenorchy Estate by 38 servicemen who returned from the First World War. The plaque was erected in 2004 by the Glenorchy Progress Associaton with funds from the Federal Government's "Saluting Their Service Program."

name: Merrigum War Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Merrigum War Memorial Hall was opened by John McEwen, Deputy Prime Minister and Minsiter for Trade, on 30th March 1959. After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Merton Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Metcalfe War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Metcalfe War Memorial, located in front of the Shire Hall, comprises of a stone obelisk unveiled on 11th December 1920. The monument lists the names of 55 fallen and returned district servicemen who fought in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: Metung War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Metung War Memorial is located on Metung Road and Kurnai Avenue. The memorial comprises of a flagstaff with a brick pyramid base and the inscription "Lest We Forget."

name: Miga Lake Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Miga Lake Memorial Hall was opened on 10th July 1930 to commemorate the First World War.

name: Milawa Boer War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Milawa Boer War Memorial Plaque, inside the Public Hall, is dedicated to the memory of Private Sam Oliver. Oliver, a member of the Bushman's Corps, was killed at Rustenberg in South Africa on 22nd July 1900.

name: Mildura Memorial Clock Tower
description: <FONT size=2>The Carnegie Library, at 74 Deakin Avenue, is surmounted by the Mildura Memorial Clock Tower built in memory of the fallen of the First World War.

name: Mildura Primary School War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mildura Primary School War Memorial, on San Mateo Avenue, comprises of a white stone obelisk. It is dedicated to the memory of former students who served inthe First World War and to those residents who never returned home.

name: Carnegie Library WWI Honour Roll
description: <FONT size=2>The Carnegie Library WWI Honour Roll is located on the left pillar of the entrance to the library. The brass honour roll lists 100 names of those who served in the First World War.

name: Mildura Peace Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mildura Peace Memorial, on Deakin Avenue, commemorates the end of the First World War and those who from the district who died fighting. The memorial comprises of a marble female figure, standing with her head bowed at the foot of a cross.

name: Mildura Memorial Reflection Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Mildura Memorial Reflection Pool, inside Henderson Park, comprises of a pool and flagstaff inscribed with, "Lest We Forget." Pillars were added next to the memorial to with the names of those who served in the Second World War, Korea, Vietnam and Borneo.

name: Mildura RAAF Memorial (Henderson Park)
description: <FONT size=2>The Mildura R.A.A.F. Memorial Plaque is located inside Henderson Park on Deakin Avenue. The plaque is dedicated to the memory of No. 2 Operational Training Unit, R.A.A.F. Mildura and the airmen and airwomen who served during the Second World War. The memorial also stands in memory of those who lost their lives training on the base or during subsequent missions in the war.

name: Mildura Vietnam and Korea Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mildura Vietnam Memorial was opened by Tim Fischer M.P. and dedicated by Chaplain Ron Wood on 19th August 1995. The memorial features a red brick wall flagstaff with three plaques for Korea, Vietnam and South East Asia and the emblems of the airforce, army and navy. In front of the wall is a black plaque with a gold cross and two black marble panels that read, "Together then, together again."

name: Mildura Anglican Church Memorial Stone
description: <FONT size=2>The Mildura Anglican Church Memorial Stone commemorates District servicemen who made the supreme sacrifice during the Second World War. The stone was unveiled by the Archdeacon J. Hardingham on 19th May 1957.

name: Mildura Greek Orthodox War Memorial Church
description: <FONT size=2>The Mildura Greek Orthodox War Memorial Church is located at 1/304 Deakin Avenue.

name: Mildura Sacred Heart Peace Memorial Church
description: <FONT size=2>The transept of the Mildura Sacred Heart Peace Memorial Church has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Mildura War Cemetery RAAF Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mildura War Cemetery RAAF Memorial is dedicated to the memory of airmen and airwomen who lost their lives whilst members of the No. 2 Operational Training Unit, R.A.A.F. during the Second World War.

name: Mildura Cross of Remembrance
description: <FONT size=2>The Mildura Cross of Remembrance is located inside the War Cemetery.

name: Mincha Memorial Gates
description: The Mincha Memorial Gates, at the entrance to Mincha Hall, commemorate residents who served in the Second World War.

name: Miners Rest War Memorial
description: The Miners Rest War Memorial, on Creswick Street, comprises of a granite obelisk dedicated to the memory of the First World War. The monument was officially unveiled by Sir A.J. Peacock on 23rd May 1920. The inscription reads: "In honour of our men this district who gave their lives in the Great War 1914-19. Duty nobly done. Erected by residents A.D. 1920."

name: Minhamite Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Minyip Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Minyip Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the sports ground, are dedicated to the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Minyip Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Minyip Mafeking Tree
description:
The Minyip Mafeking Tree was originally planted, on Donald - Murtoa Road, on 6th June 1900. The tree commemorates the successful defence by Colonel Baden Powell and his garrison of Mafeking in South Africa during the Boer War. The garrison defended Mafeking over 209 days from a Boer siege.

In 1970, the tree was replaced by the Minyip C.W.A and again on Anzac Day in 1996. A plaque was also added to the railed enclosure of the tree, to commemorate those who served in the Korean War (1950 -1953) and in the following peacekeeping missions in Korea between 1953-1958.

name: Minyip War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Minyip War Memorial comprises of a flagpole mounted on a rough stone base. It is dedicated to the memory of all those men and women who have served Australia in times of conflict.

name: Mirboo North War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Mirboo North War Memorial Obelisk, outside the RSL Hall, stands in memory of those residents who pioneered settlement in the area and in memory of those residents who served the district in times of war.

name: Mirboo North and District Memorial Higher Elementary School
description: <FONT size=2>The Mirboo North and District Memorial Higher Elementary School was established on 2nd April 1925 in memory of the First World War.

name: Mirboo North Memorial RSL Hall
description: The Mirboo North Memorial RSL Hall was established in 1957. A small marble tablet inset into the outside wall of the building is marked with a gold cross and the inscription Lest We Forget.

name: Mitcham War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mitcham War Memorial, in Halliday Park on Mitcham Road, was established on 15th October 1922. The memorial consists of an Italian marble statue of a First World War Bugler mounted on a granite pedestal and bluestone base. The pedestal and base are engraved with the names of 125 fallen and returned servicemen, including those who served in the Second World War. The memorial was later rededicated to the memory of those who served in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Brian Street Memorial Plaque
description: Brian Street in Mitcham was named in memory of Private Fred Brian Cox, of the Australian Army Ordnance Corps, who was killed in action in Japan on 15th March 1945, aged 23.

name: Ross Street Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>Ross Street in Mitcham was named after a Leading Aircraftman William Ross Bremner Fenton, Royal Australian Air Force, who was killed training in South Australia on 11th August 1942, aged 20.

name: Ronald Street Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>Ronald Street in Mitcham was named in memory of Sergeant Ronald Moseley Peake, Royal Australian Airforce, who was killed in action over Germany on 12th March 1943, aged 21.

name: Owen Street Memorial Plaque
description: Owen Street in Mitcham is named after Gunner Owen Spencer Loftus, Royal Australian Artillery, who was killed in action in Indonesia on 17th April 1942, aged 33.

name: Alwyn Street Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>Alywn Street in Mitcham was named in memory of Warrant Officer Alwyn Terence Till, Royal Australian Air Force, who was killed in action in Belgium on 21st August 1944, aged 23.

name: Mitiamo War Memorial
description:
The Mitiamo War Memorial, on Glossop and Forrest Streets, was established on 22nd October 1919. The Mitiamo sub-branch of the R.S.L. was very active in the area from the end of the First World War, erecting the memorial in honour of those who went from the Mitiamo district to serve in the First World War. The memorial comprises of a marble female statue symbolising remembrance, erected on a paved cruciform within a park.

Over 80 names were inscribed on the monument; 23 of whom never returned. Commemoration celebrations included a parade of soldiers and the Pyramid Hill Brass Band that left from the railway station grounds at 2.00pm. At the conclusion of the parade, a number of speeches were made, refreshments provided and the evening saw the conducting of a concert. In 2009, two small concrete blocks were added at the entrance to the park, bearing the dates of the Second World War.There is also an individual granite stone which is dedicated to Sergeant Thomas Henry Clarke.

Sergeant Thomas Henry "Harry" Clarke was one of four members of the mainly Queensland 2/9th Battalion killed in action on 21 January 1944 on Shaggy Ridge. Shaggy Ridge is a 6.5 -kilometre-long-razor-backed ridge that is the highest feature in the Finisterre Mountains in north-eastern New Guinea. The ridge was named after Captain Robert "Shaggy Bob" Clampett of the 2/27th Battalion, whose company was the first to reconnoitre its approaches.

In 1943, Shaggy Ridge was the site of main Japanese defensive position blocking access from Ramu Valley to the track and road network that joined it with the north coast. In January 1944, sufficient supplies had arrived for the 18th Brigade, including the 2/9th to force the Japanese off the ridge.

The attack began on 19 January. On 21 January, A Company of the 2/9th attacked a Japanese position named Green Sniper's Pimple, the highest point on Shaggy Ridge. The unexpected direction of these attacks, up slopes the Japanese obviously regarded as almost impassable, allowed the Australians to establish foothold quickly, and it was secured by the end of the day. Their new occupants, however, had to withstand several counter-attacks and persistent and accurate artillery bombardment. Four men were killed, including Sergeant Clarke.

name: Mitiamo WWII Memorial
description: The Mitiamo WWII Memorial is a plaque and granite boulder dedicated to Sergeant Thomas Henry (Harry) Clarke, 2/9 Australian Infantry Battalion. Clarke was killed in action 21st January 1944 at Shaggy Ridge, New Guinea, aged 31 years old. The memorial was donated by his brother Gavin. The inscription on the plaque reads: "Greater love has no one than this. To lay down his life for his friends. John 15-13."

name: Modewarre Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Modewarre Memorial Hall was erected in 1923 in memory of the First World War.

name: Moe RSL Club Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>On the outside of the Moe R.S.L. are two memorial plaques; a mosaic tiled plaque dedicated to peace in the Pacific and a bronze plaque dedicated to those who served during the Second World War.

name: Moe Memorial RSL Hall
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Mologa WWI Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Mologa War Memorial Obelisk, in the Railway Ground, comprises of a pillar dedicated to the eighteen local men who served in the First World War, ten of whom paid the supreme sacrifice.The memorial has an axe finished granite base with a polished granite middle stage terminated by pediments to all faces and surmounted by a dressed granite obelisk with pyramidal cap.

name: Molyullah Memorial Hall
description: The Molyullah Memorial Hall, on Centre Road, was established in 1956. After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Monbulk RSL War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Monbulk War Memorial is located outside the R.S.L. on Main Street. The memorial comprises of a boulder and plaque commemorating the service of Australian men and women in conflicts between 1899-1991.

name: Monbulk & District Senior Citizens Centre War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Monbulk and District Senior Citizens Centre War Memorial, on Moores Road, is dedicated to residents who died on active service in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War and the Malayan Emergency. It was erected in 2001 as a joint centenary federation project by the Monbulk Primary School and the Monbulk R.S.L.

name: Montmorency War Memorial
description: The Montmorency War Memorial is located outside the R.S.L. in Petrie Park. The memorial is a red brick cenotaph featuring the emblems of the Australian Army, Navy and Airforce and the epitaph Lest We Forget.

name: Dawson Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Dawson Memorial Plaque was erected by the residents of Coimadai in memory of G.W. Dawson who was killed during the Second World War. The plaque was formerly located in Wiseman's Hall but has since been moved to the Shire Depot.

name: Moonee Ponds War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Moonee Ponds War Memorial is located inside the Army Depot on Pascoe Vale Road. The memorial comprises of a brick cenotaph dedicated to the memory 30 officers, 585 NGOs and Men of the 58th Battalion A.I.F. who died fighting in France, during the First World War.

name: St Thomas Memorial Church Tower
description: <FONT size=2>The St. Thomas Memorial Church Tower, at 760 Mt. Alexander Road, was erected as a memorial to those who served in the Second World War. A replacement foundation stone for the tower was laid on 28th March 1954 by the Governor Sir Dallas Brooks.

name: St Thomas Soldiers Memorial and Kindergarten Hall
description: St. Thomas Soldiers Memorial and Kindergarten Hall was built in memory of 43 residents who died serving in the First World War. Included in the design of the building is the Soldiers Memorial Clubrooms. The foundation stone for the hall was laid by Major Tivey on 18th September 1920, with an inscription that reads- "They died the noblest death a man may die, fighting for god and right and liberty and such a death is immortality."

name: Moorabbin WWII Sundial
description: The Moorabbin WWII Sundial, in Halley Park, was erected in 1995 as part of the Australia Remembers, 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War. It honours all those men and women who served during the Second World War.

name: Moorabbin War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Moorabbin War Memorial Plaque, on Chesterville Road, was erected on 23rd May 1995 to commemorate the Second World War. The site formerly housed a War-time Naval Signal Station, playing a crucial role in winning the war in the Pacific. The station was manned by personnel from both the Royal Australian Navy, Women's Royal Australian Navy and the U.S. Navy between 1942-1945.

name: Moorabbin Vietnam War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Moorabbin Vietnam War Memorial is a plaque erected at the edge of a pond, featuring a memorial cross, inside Basterfield Park. The inscription reads, "This memorial commemorates all Australians who paid the supreme sacrifice in the Vietnam War (1962-1973). All gave some -Some gave all."

name: Mooralla Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Mooralla Memorial Gates was the entrance to the former school on East West Road. The gates were erected in memory of Sergeant John S. Thomson who lost his life on 6th April 1945, aged 21 years old.

name: Mooralla Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Mooralla Memorial Plaque, on East West Road near the memorial gates, commemorates former site of the Soldiers Memorial Hall between 1922-1979.

name: Moorooduc WWII Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Moorooduc Memorial Gates form the entrance to Moorooduc Park Reserve on Derril Road. The steel gates are attached to a low stone wall and feature a bronze plaque inscribed with, "Moorooduc Memorial Gates, dedicated 13th April 1952, to the memory of servicemen and women of World War II."

name: Mooroolbark War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mooroolbark War Memorial is located in Hookey Park on Charles and Station Streets. The memorial comprises of a small cairn and a flagstaff erected on Anzac Day 1987. The inscription reads, "In honour of men and women who served in the defence of Australia allowing communities like Mooroolbark to develop."

name: Mooroopna War Memorial Rotunda
description: The Mooroopna War Memorial, inside the gardens on McLennan Street, was erected on 25th April 1928 in memory of the First World War. The Mooroopna community contributed £1,100 to erect the rotunda which lists 145 men and 21 nurses, all of whom trained at the Mooroopna Hospital. The Classical rotunda is a reinforced concrete construction witha domed roof. It features anoctagonal plan supported by plain Ionic columns on square bases. The octagonal frieze contains moulded panels with the pressed cement lettering 'France', 'Belgium', 'Palestine' and 'Gallipoli' alternating with blank panels, all of which are moulded. The structure is raised on an octagonal concrete base which is stepped on all sides. The plinth is surrounded on three sides by a non-original galvanised steel rack for floral wreaths.

name: Mordialloc WWI Memorial Fountain
description: <FONT size=2>The Mordialloc WWI Memorial Fountain, on Beach Road and the Nepean Highway, honours those residents who served in the First World War.

name: Mornington Honour Roll
description: The Mornington Honour Roll, inside Memorial Park on Barkly Street, was erected on 18th October 1925. The stone and bronze Honour Roll lists the names of 120 fallen and returned locals who fought in the First World War. Originally located in Elliot Square, the memorial was moved to the park on 8th November 1998. The main inscription reads, "Sons of this place let this of you be said, that ye who live are worthy of your dead: they gave their lives that we who live might reap a richer harvest, ere we fall asleep."

name: Mornington Prisoner of War Memorial Wall and Garden
description: The Mornington Prisoner of War Memorial Wall and Garden, located inside the Memorial Park on Barkly Street, was opened on 9th November 1986.

name: Mornington BCOF Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mornington B.C.O.F. Memorial comprises of a plaque located inside the Memorial Park on Barkly Street. The plaque commemorates those who served and died serving with the British Commonwealth Occupation Force in Japan, between 1946-1951.

name: Mornington War Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Mornington War Memorial Wall, inside the Memorial Park on Barkly Street, is dedicated to those who have served in conflicts since the Second World War. The wall includes plaques for Malaya 1950-1960, Korea 1950-1953, Borneo 1963-1966, Vietnam 1962 - 1973, The Gulf 1991, EastTimor 1999, Afghanistan 2002 and Iraq 2003.

name: Mornington Memorial Seats
description: <FONT size=2>The Mornington Memorial Seats are located inside the Memorial Park on Barkly Street. The seats are dedicated to the men of the Burma-Thailand Railway, Nursing Sisters, 2/22nd Battalion Lark Force Association and one donated by the Gull Force (2/21 Battalion) Association.

name: Mornington Army Water Transport Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mornington Army Water Transport Memorial, inside the Memorial Park, commemorates small ships and craft that transported water during the Second World War. The Water transport units were active in training around Mornington and patrolling the coastline. The memorial is specifically dedicated to 1st, 2nd and 3rd Australian Water Transport Groups who served in Tobruk, New Guinea, Darwin, Bougainville, New Britain, Morotai and Borneo.

name: Mornington Boer War Memorial Troughs
description: <FONT size=2>The Mornington Boer War Memorial Troughs are dedicated to the Australian Mounted Riflemen who fought in South Africa. The plaque's inscription states that 16,175 men and 16,314 horses left Australia to serve in the Boer War from 1899-1901. The total loss of life was 518, while the casualty list was 1400. The memorial also acknowledges the service of Australian Nursing Sisters in South Africa and the service of Australians in early colonial conflicts such as Sudan (1865) and the Boxer Rebellion (1900-1901).

name: Mortlake Boer War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Mortlake Boer War Memorial Plaque, inside the Anglican Church, is dedicated to Private W.E. Clarke (2nd Victorian Contingent) who died in South Africa on 5th July 1900.

name: Morwell WWII Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Morwell WWII Memorial Gates were erected in memory of Maryville employees who gave their lives during the Second World War. Each pillar features an honour roll of the fallen.

name: Maryvale Private Hospital Memorial
description: The Maryvale Private Hospital Memorial comprises of a flagstaff and plaque dedicated to all those servicemen who have died in times of war, on peacekeeping missions or have died since their return home. The memorial was donated in 2004 by the Morwell R.S.L. Sub-Branch in appreciation of the medical services provided to veterans and widows.

name: Mount Beauty War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mount Beauty War Memorial is located outside the Tawonga and District Hospital on Lakeside Avenue. The memorial comprises of a stone cenotaph dedicated to the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam and the Gulf War.

name: Mount Clear Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Mount Evelyn War Memorial
description: The Mount Evelyn War Memorial, located inside the R.S.L. Memorial Garden on Birmingham Road, comprises of a coloured stone cairn dedicated to the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam. The main inscription reads, "Lest We Forget. This plaque was erected in grateful memory of those who gave their lives during the two world wars, 1914-1918 and 1939-1945."

name: Mount Evelyn Memorial Pre-School
description: The Mount Evelyn Memorial Pre-School, on Birmingham Road, was built in 1945 as a memorial to all those who served during the Second World War. The inscription reads, "This Pre-School Centre stands as a living memorial to all who served in the Second World War 1939-1945, by working for the happiness and well-being of its children Mount Evelyn seeks to Honour worthily their sacrifice. In 1956, this hall was re-built through the labour and perserverance of committee mothers and friends working under the inspiration and leadership of Mrs. O.J. Adams (President since its inauguration in 1945)."

name: Mount Evelyn Memorial Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Mount Evelyn R. & S.L. Memorial Garden is located at the junction of York and Monbulk Roads.

name: Mount Macedon War Memorial Reserve
description: <FONT size=2>The Mount Macedon War Memorial Reserve was officially declared a memorial reserve on 11th November 1994 by Premier Jeff Kennett. The entrance to the reserve is marked by memorial gates and inside stands the Mount Macedon War Memorial Cross.

name: Mount Macdeon War Memorial Reserve Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The gates at the entrance to the Mount Macedon War Memorial Reserve, were erected by the community and R.S.L. in memory of the men and women who died serving in times of war. There is also a plaque specifically dedicated to those who fell in the Second World War.

name: Mount Martha Scout Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Mount Martha Scout Memorial, in Joseph Harris Park, commemorates 32 scouts who died fighting in the Second World War. The site comprises of a replica gateway of the entrance to the Brighton District Camp site at Lysterfield and features two of the original Lysterfield tablets, engraved in gold with the names of the 32 fallen. The memorial was officially unveiled on 8th November 2003 by Major General D. McLachlan and was funded with assistance from the Department of Veterans' Affairs, Victorian Scout Foundation, Bay-Park Joseph Harris Park Commitee and the Scout Heritage Centre.

name: Mount Waverley F.C. Ross Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Mount Waverley F.C. Ross Memorial Plaque once formed a part of the now dissappeared Avenue of Honour. In 1974, the plaque was unearthed by road works at the corner of Blackburn and England Roads and repositioned beneath a tree to honour F.C. Ross, 12th Battlion, killed in France in 1917.

name: Mumbannar Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>Mumbannar Memorial Hall was built in 1958 to commemorate the First World War and Second World War.

name: Murchison War Memorial
description: The Murchison War Memorial, on Stephenson Street, is an ornamental structure featuring a cupola with a small orb that rests on four red granite columns on a granite pedestal. The cupola features the emblem of the Australian Commonwealth Military Forces, while the pedestal lists the names of those locals who served in the First World War and the Second World War. The main inscription reads, "We lie dead in many lands, that you may live here in peace."

name: Murchison WWII Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Murchison WWII Memorial Gates form the entrance to Murchison Primary School on Impey Street. The gates are dedicated to all former students who served in the Second World War and feature the names of nine men who never returned home.

name: Murchison Italian Soldiers Memorial
description: The Murchison Italian Soldiers Memorial, inside the Cemetery on Murchison-Nagambie Road, comprises of an abstract metal monument topped by a star and featuring anchors on each corner of the base. The Italian inscription translates as, " To the heroic soldiers of land-sea-sky that for the homeland sacrificed their youth. The Italian Federation of Ex Service and War Veterans and The Association of Arms." The monument was unveiled by General G. Rosa Diaz on 4th November 1975.

name: Italian Prisoners Of War Memorial
description:
Inside the cemetery on Murchison-Nagambie Road, is a memorial dedicated to Italian Prisoners of War who died while interned in the Murchison camps. The memorial comprises of a stone pedestal topped by a green metal wreath; which features a golden hand clasping a cross and a star joining the two fronds at the top and an Italian helmet at the base. On the front face of the pedestal is a map of Italy and the inscription: "Who for the homeland spent life and more. This monument was erected by Italian prisoners of war in the Rushworth (Vic)concentration camp and transported to this Italian chapel of Murchison (Vic) on 7th September 1968 through the interest of Cavilieri Urbano A. Segafredo President and Founder of the Bendigo Section of the Italian Federation of Ex Service and War Veterans." The memorial was moved to Murchison in 1968 from Rushworth, where it had been constructed by Italian prisoners of war.

During the Second World War, 4000 Italian, German and Japanese prisoners of war were detained at Murchison. Those who died at Murchison were buried in the local cemetery, but floods in 1956 did major damage to the graves. Luigi Gigliotti persuaded Italian families living in the Goulburn Valley to pay for the building of a mausoleum - the Ossario. He also managed to persuade the authorities to bury all the Italian prisoners of war and detainees who died in Australian prison camps in the mausoleum, which was completed in 1961.

name: Murchison Italian War Memorial Plaque
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Murrayville War Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Murrayville War Memorial Gates, at the entrance bowling club, comprise of brick pillars and a wrought iron arch inscribed with "Lest We Forget." The pillars feature bronze honour rolls dedicated to the ex-servicemen and women who served in the Second World War, Korea, Vietnam, in the Permanent Forces and in the National Service.

name: Murtoa Soldier Settlement Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Murtoa Soldier Settlement Memorial, unveiled on 3rd October 1998, commemorates Soldier Settlers and Families who pioneered Dairy Farming at Murtoa North forty years before in 1958.

name: Myrniong War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Myrniong War Memorial, on the Old Western Highway, consists of a large red brick wall with name plaques of those who served in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Myrrhee Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities'histories.

name: Myrtleford Rothery Memorial Tree
description: <FONT size=2>The Myrtleford Rothery Memorial Tree is located on Clyde Street in front of the post office. The tree, a Kurrajong, was planted by Joseph Rothery as a living memorial to his daughter Nurse Elizabeth Rothery, who died on June 15th 1918.

name: Myrtleford District War Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Myrtleford District War Memorial Hospital, on O'Donnell Avenue, was opened on 11th October 1959 by Sir George Holland. It is dedicated to the memory of those who served in the Second World War.

name: Nagambie Memorial Clock Tower
description: <FONT size=2>The Nagambie Memorial Clock Tower, on High and Marie Streets, was erected on 19th December 1954. The memorial stands as as a tribute to those who served in the Second World War, including eleven residents who made the supreme sacrifice. Plaques added to the memorial commemorate the Korean War and list the names of those men and women who served in the Second World War.

name: Nanneella Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Naringal WWII Memorial
description: The Naringal Monument consists of a simple stone cairn, commemorating the Second World War. Erected March 24th 1985, the memorial lists 29 names of fallen and returned soldiers.

name: Nar Nar Goon War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Nar Nar Goon War Memorial is located on Seven Mile Road and Carney Street. Erected on 11th November 1999, the memorial is dedicated to the district men and women who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam. The memorial consists of a wide grey obelisk encircled by a tiered wall, with plaques featuring the names of those who served.

name: Nar Nar Goon Soldiers' Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Nar Nar Goon Soldiers' Memorial Hall, on Spencer Street, was established in 1921 in memory of the First World War. On 29th March 1980, Governor Henry A. Winneke reopened the building as a community centre.

name: Nar Nar Goon North Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Nar Nar Goon North Memorial Hall is located at the junction of Dore and Bessie Roads. After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Narrawong War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Narrawong War Memorial comprises of a flagstaff and and granite cairn dedicated to the memory of all men and women "who served, died and suffered in the Navy, Army and Air Force, defending Australia."

name: Narre Warren Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Narre Warren Memorial Gates have been re-sited in the park near the Municipal Offices. The gates comprise of two stone pillars featuring the names of those district servicemen who fought in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Narre Warren North War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Narre Warren North War Memorial, near the Memorial Drive, commemorates those who served in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam. The memorial consists of a stone obelisk and features the names of those who served on each face of the monument.

name: Narre Warren North Soldier Settlement Memorial Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Narre Warren North Soldier Settlement Memorial Garden, in Kalora Park, is dedicated to the returned servicemen and their families who farmed the area between 1934 - 1975. The settlement blocks averaged 15 acres in size and were used for dairy and poultry production. The garden was offically opened by Mayor Cr. Janet Halsall on 1st March 2008. The soldier settlers listed on the plaque are Thomas and Annie Edwards, Edward and May Ivens, Leslie and Mary Lowry, John and Kathleen Rogers, Alfred and Sarah Sherriff, Francis and Jessie Stephenson, Arthur and Lila Street.

name: Nathalia WWII Memorial
description: Flanking the Nathalia War Memorial statue is a stone wall with plaques and flagpoles dedicated to the Second World War. The plaques list both the soldiers who returned from battle and those who lost their lives.

name: Nathalia Memorial Gardens
description: <FONT size=2>The Nathalia Memorial Gardens, on Murray Valley Highway, are dedicated to the men and women who served in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam. Unveiled by B.C. Ruxton on 13th November 1988, the gardens include a chained boulder monument and 64 rose bushes for the 64 locals who died fighting in both world wars. There are also several memorial tree plantings dedicated to specific conflicts: on 18th August 1966 the Asian Bell Tree was planted by Garry Edwards (6th Batt. R.A.R.) in memory of those who died in the Battle of Long Tan in Vietnam, a tree planted in 1992 was dedicated to those servicemen who were Prisoners of War, another tree was planted for those women who served as nurses, in the navy, army and airforce and also planted in 1992 a tree dedicated to the memory of the District Rats of Tobruk.

name: Nathalia Memorial Swimming Pool
description: Nathalia MemorialSwimming Pool bears a plaque dedicated to all those who served and the inscription Lest We Forget.

name: Natimuk Memorial Rotunda
description: <FONT size=2>The Natimuk Memorial Rotunda, inside the Reserve on Wimmera Highway and Elmes Street, is dedicated to the First World War and Second World War. A bronze plaque attached to the bandstand is inscribed: "Erected In Memory Of the Men of This District Who Gave Their Lives for Their Country in the Great War 1914- 1919." At a later point a plaque was added for the Second World War, listing the names of Natimuk locals who served and were killed in action or died whilst prisoners of war.

name: Natimuk WWII Memorial
description: The Natimuk WWII Memorial is located in the Reserve, in front of the Rotunda Memorial. The memorial is a small cairn and plaque erected in 1995 as part of the Australia Remembers 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Natimuk WWII Memorial Seats
description: <FONT size=2>The Natimuk WWII Memorial Seats are located in the Reserve on the Wimmera Highway and Elmes Street. The park bench closest to the Rotunda Memorial is dedicated to the memory of Gordon McLachlan, while the bench under a tree nearby is dedicated to Alfred Scott.

name: Natimuk and District Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Natimuk Soldiers and District Memorial Hall, on the main street (Wimmera Highway), was formerly the Mechanics' Institute. The memorial stone, attached to the Hall's facade, was laid by Carl Schmidt on July 14th 1901.

name: Natte Yallock War Memorial
