description: The Natte Yallock War Memorial, on Maryborough - St. Arnaud Road, comprises of a granite cenotaph on a two-tiered base. Attached to the monument are two bronze honour rolls listing those residents who lost their lives serving in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: Natte Yallock Memorial Trees
description: <FONT size=2>The Natte Yallock Memorial Trees are located on Maryborough-St. Arnaud Road opposite the War Memorial Cenotaph. The trees are individually dedicated to Pte. J.F. Evans (58th Battalion) killed in New Guinea on 7th July 1943 and Flt. Sgt. N. Cross (R.A.A.F) killed in England 18th December 1943.

name: Netherby War Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Netherby Memorial Gates are located at the entrance to the sports ground.

name: Neuarpurr War Memorial Arch
description: The Neuarpurr War Memorial Arch was the entrance to the former Memorial Hall. Attached to the lintel is a plaque inscribed with "Neuarpurr Soldiers War Memorial 1939-1945."

name: Newborough Cenotaph
description: The Newborough Cenotaph is located in the park between Boolarra and Darlimurla Avenues. The Cenotaph itself is not inscribed but at its base is a simple dedication "Lest We Forget 1914-1919 1939-1945."

name: Newbridge War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Newbridge War Memorial, on Laanecoorie-Newbridge Road and Lyons Street, comprises of a polished grey granite obelisk set on a red brick paved square. The obelisk is dedicated to the First World War and is engraved in gold with the names of 46 resdients who served, including those who did not return.

name: Newtown War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Newtown War Memorial is located on Pakington Street in the gardens outside the former Municipal Offices. The monument is a small brick block with a plaque, elevated on a paved area above stone stairs. It was erected by the City of Newtown in memory of all those who lost their lives in war defending Australia.

name: Newtown Memorial Sunday School
description: <FONT size=2>The Newtown Memorial Sunday School, on Potter Street, is dedicated to former students who fought in the First World War. A memorial stone was laid by Ald. Howard Hitchcock, Mayor of Geelong, on 2nd October 1920.

name: Newtown WWI Memorial Baby Health Centre
description: The Newtown WWI Memorial Baby Health Centre, on Russell Street, was opened by J.F.S. Shannon on 30th September 1927.

name: Newtown WWII Memorial Baby Health Centre
description: <FONT size=2>The Newtown WWII Memorial Baby Health Centre, on Ruthven Street, was opened by Edith Latham Kernot on 6th June 1951.

name: Nhill War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Nhill War Memorial, in Goldswrothy Park on Victoria Street, comprises of a marble digger statue erected on 13th September 1921. On the pedestal 271 names of those who served in the First World War, including the names added for those who served in the Second World War.

name: Nhill Memorial Community Centre
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Noble Park RSL War Memorial
description: The Noble Park R.S.L. War Memorial is located inside the window of the R.S.L. building at 1128 Heatherton Road. The memorial comprises of a white cross mounted on a tiled base and bears the simple inscription "Lest We Forget."

name: Noble Park RSL Commemorative Park
description:
The Noble Park RSL Commemorative Park, at the junction of Mons Parade and Heatherton Road, was opened by the Governor of Victoria Richard E. McGarvie on 26th November 1995. The centrepiece of the park is a paved flagstaff and rough cut stone, with a dedication that reads:

"To the memory of all men and women who served their countries in all wars. And to those that did not return they will never know the beauty of this country, see the seasons change, enjoy nature's chorus, all we enjoy we owe to them. They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old, age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn, at the going down of the sun, an in the morning, we will remember them."

name: Noble Park Child Casualties Memorial
description: Inside the Noble Park Commemorative Park, at the Junction of Mons Parade and Heatherton Road, is a plaque and small garden dedicated to all the children who lost their lives in war. The epitaph reads, "This is a land of peace good angels know it well, glad songs that never cease within God's garden swell, in our memory you dwell."

name: Noble Park Memorial Swimming Pool
description: The Noble Park Memorial Swimming Pool is dedicated to the services and sacrifices of men and women who served Australia in the armed forces during the Second World War. The pool was opened on Anzac Day 1963 with a bronze plaque that reads, "The deeds and services of these men and women provided the inspiration to the Springvale - Noble Park Memorial Swimming Pool Association to help establish this swimming pool as a perpetual expression of gratitude of the citizens of the City of Springvale."

name: Noble Park Nurses Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Noble Park Nurses Memorialis located inside the Commemorative Park at the junction of Mons Parade and Heatherton Road. The memorial is a rough granite stone with a plaque dedicated to 100 years of service given by Australian Nurses in all wars, from the Boer War through the two world wars and conflicts until 2000. The monument was officially opened by Mrs Wilma Young nee Oram (AM, former P.O.W. of the Japanese) on Remembrance Day 1999.

name: Noradjuha Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Noradjuha Memorial Hall, on Noradjuha-Tooan East Road, was erected in 1953. After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Norlane RSL War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Norlane R.S.L. War Memorial, at 29 Rose Avenue, comprises of a flagstaff with a rough stone base. The stone base is inscribed with "Lest We Forget" and originally belonged to the Memorial Infant Welfare Centre. On Anzac Day 1991, the stone was moved to the R.S.L. grounds and unveiled with the flagstaff by Mayor Joan Rowe.

name: Norlane Memorial Infant Centre
description: <FONT size=2>The Norlane Memorial Infant Centre, on Sparks Road and Plume Street, was established in 1954.

name: Norman Lane Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>Inside Norlane Secondary College is a memorial plaque for serviceman Norman Lane, after whom the suburb of Norlane was named.

name: Northcote RSL War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Northcote R.S.L. War Memorial comprises of a broken pillar monument, erected in 1921 to commemorate the First World War. Inscriptions were added for the Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam. There is also a special plaque for the first Australian killed in the First World War, a resident of Northcote, W.G.V. Williams. Williams was a member of the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force that captured the German possession at Rabaul in New Guinea on 11th September 1914.

name: Northcote Boer War Memorial Tablet
description: <FONT size=2>The Northcote Boer War Memorial Tablet is attached to the outside of the Memorial R.S.L. Hall. The tablet was erected by the members of the Star of Northcote Tent No. 217 to the memory of Bro. Fredrick G. Dau, killed in action at Schurverberg Hoek, South Africa on 23rd August 1901.

name: Northcote Police Station Memorial
description: TheNorthcote Police Station Memorial Plaque, attached to the outside of the building, is dedicated to a former constable who died during the Second World War. The inscription reads, " To honour Northcote's bravest son, First Constable Rod Breavington (Corporal VX63100 RAAOC), 14.4.1904 - 2.9.1942. For his example of service and sacrifice. Unveiled on 7.6.1990 by K.Glare, Chief Commissioner."

name: Northcote WWI Memorial
description: The Northcote WWI Memorial, outside the R.S.L., is a bronze plaque depicting the battle at Rabaul in New Guinea. It was at Rabaul fighting against German Forces, that Australia suffered its first casualty of the First World War - Seaman William Williams. It also commemorates Captain Brian Pockley, of the Army Medical Corps, who gave his distinctive Red Cross armband to the mortally wounded Williams and carried him back to the H.M.A.S. Berrima. Pockley was mortally wounded soon after his heroic rescue effort and both he and Williams died aboard the Berrima on 11th September 1914.

name: Northcote Anzac Memorial
description: The Northcote Anzac Memorial is located on Separation Street behind Northcote Plaza. The memorial site comprises of a rough-cut stone monument and plaque, a contemporary sculpture featuring a slouch hat and a bronze sculpture of the H.M.A.S Berrima. The Berrima was one of the ships to take part in Australia's first Naval Conflict against the Germans in 1914. The site was opened on 7th April 2002 in honour of all servicemen and servicewomen who gave their lives for Australia.

name: Devon North Honour Roll
description: The Devon North Honour Roll, in a shelter in the corner of the School grounds, lists the names of those who served in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Nowa Nowa War Memorial
description: The Nowa Nowa War Memorial was located outside the CWA Hall but was moved to a new site beside the Princes Highway. The memorial comprises of a field stone cairn with a flagstaff and plaque inscribed with "Lest We Forget." Walls flanking the memorial were added with plaques listing the dates of the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya/Borneo, Vietnam, East Timor and U.N. Peacekeeping missions.

name: Numurkah War Memorial
description: The Numurkah War Memorial, on Saxton and Melville Streets, is an elaborate monument comprising of two marble figures: a statue of Victory and a First World War Digger. The Digger statue stands head bowed, holding a bronze rifle in the 'arms reversed' position, in front of a representation of a rock. The monument was unveiled on 16th November 1929, in memory of the First World War with the inscription "Deep graved in every British Heart, O never let their names depart." Later, names were added to the monument for the Second World War, Vietnam War and for the servicewomen of the Second World War. Altogether the monument lists 780 names of those who served.

name: Numurkah Commemorative P.O.W. Plantation
description: The Numurkah Commemorative P.O.W. Plantation,onTocumwal Road an Pine Street, was unveiled on 16th November 1986 by Mayor G. Brown-Shepherd. Trees were planted from Tocumwal Road down to the south side of the railway line. A small monument and sign mark the plantation with the inscription, "Dedicated to the servicemen of Numurkah and District who were prisoners of war during the Second World War. The quality of Australian mateship prevailed and expressed itself in enduring comradeship born out of adversity."

name: Numurkah WWII Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Numurkah WWII Memorial Hospital, on Coombs Memorial Driveand Melville Street, was opened on 13th April 1957 to commemorate those residents who paid the supreme sacrifice fighting in the Second World War.

name: Nurcoung Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Nyah Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Nyah Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Recreation grounds, were unveiled by John Clayton on 5th June 1927. The stone pillars were erected to commemorate those who served in the First World War, with names added afterwards for the servicemen who fought in the Second World War.

name: Nyah District Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Nyora Memorial Flagpole
description: The Nyora Memorial Flagpole bears a bronze plaque embossed with a torch and "Lest We Forget."

name: Oakleigh Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>On 14th November 1965, the Oakleigh Cenotaph was moved from Dandenong and Warrigal Roads to Warrawee Park on Drummond Street. The Cenotaph was originally unveiled by Major General C.H. Brand on 12th November 1933 in memory of the First World War. Inscriptions were added for the Second World War and on Remembrance Day 1979 the cenotaph was re-dedicated to Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Oakleigh Memorial RSL
description: <FONT size=2>The Oakleigh Memorial R.S.L., on Drummond Street at the end of the Avenue of Honour, was unveiled on 29th April 1922 in memory of the First World War.

name: Oakleigh Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Oakleigh Memorial Gates are located at the entrance to Oakleigh Primary School on Warrigal Road and Logie Street. The gates serve as a memorial to the First World War.

name: Ocean Grove War Memorial
description: The Ocean Grove War Memorial is located inside the R.S.L. Memorial Park on Hodgson Street and The Parade. The memorial is a rough granite pillar mounted on a two tiered, polished black granite base. The pillar stands in front of a black wall bearing the inscription "Lest We Forget" and the emblems of the Army, Navy and Airforce. It is dedicated to those Australians who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Sabah/Sarawak, Malayan Peninsula and Vietnam conflicts.

name: Ocean Grove War Memorial Gate
description: The Ocean Grove War Memorial Gate, at the entrance to the Memorial Recreation Reserve, bears the inscription "In Remembrance of those who give their lives in all wars and conflicts that we may live in freedom. Lest We Forget."

name: Ocean Grove Memorial Recreation Reserve
description: <FONT size=2>The Ocean Grove Memorial Recreation Reserve is located at 123-137 The Avenue.

name: Ocean Grove Memorial Flagpole
description: <FONT size=2>The Ocean Grove Memorial Flagpole bears several plaques dedicated to individual residents who served in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam.

name: Officer Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Officer Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the football grounds, stand in memory of the First and Second World Wars. Each pillar lists the names of those residents who served in each of the world wars.

name: Omeo War Memorial
description: The Omeo War Memorial, on Day Avenue, comprises of a flagstaff and two honour rolls dedicated to those who served in the Second World War and Vietnam. The monument was unveiled on 4th April 1987 and lists 280 names of fallen and returned servicemen.

name: Omeo Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The foundation stone for the Omeo Memorial Hall was laid by the President of the Omeo R.S.L Branch, W. Greenwood, on May 7th 1926.

name: Omeo Memorial Bridge
description:
The Omeo Memorial Bridge was builtover Livingstone Creek on Alpine Road in memory of the First World War. It was designed by Omeo Shire Engineer C.H.R. Heale and built by the Country Roads Board in 1919-21 to replace an earlier timber beam bridge known as Connely's Bridge that was badly damaged by floods in 1916. The bridge was first referred to as the "Memorial Bridge" in the August 5th 1919 edition of the Omeo Standard, which reported the opening on the 6th April 1921, where it was referred to as the "Soldiers' Memorial Bridge".

The project was largely paid for by special grants from the Public Works Department and was built using shire day labour with the preferential employment of local returned servicemen. It is believed to be the first concrete bridge in the Shire of Omeo and resembles a road bridge with cast-in-place reinforced concrete T-girders and an integral flat slab deck.

During the 1939 bushfires, the Bridge was used as a refuge by women and children. It is now only open to foot traffic following construction of a new bypass road and bridge in 1973.

name: Ondit Memorial Gates
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Ondit State School War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Ondit State School War Memorial comprises of a flagstaff and honour roll plaques listing the names of former students who served in the First World War, Second World War and were taken prisoner of war.

name: Orbost War Memorial Clock
description: <FONT size=2>the Orbost War Memorial Clock, on the corner of Scott and Nicholson Streets, is dedicated to those residents who fell in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: Orbost Secondary College Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Orbost Secondary College Memorial Gates, on Arnold Street, are dedicated to ex-pupils who served in the two world wars.

name: Orford War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Orford War Memorial, in front of the Memorial Hall, was unveiled on 6th April 2002 by Bruce Ruxton. The memorial comprises of an asymmetrical granite tablet with honour rolls plaques listing the names of those who served in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: Ouyen Memorial RSL Clubrooms
description: In June 1916 a conference of Returned Soldiers' Association recommended formation of the Returned Sailors and Soldiers Imperial League of Australia (RSSILA, now known as the Returned and Service League or RSL). After the First World War RSSILA branches all around Australia commenced a program of building halls in which their members could meet. Many RSL Halls are still in use in their communities and house honour rolls listing the local people who served and died during war.

name: Pakenham War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Pakenham War Memorial, on John and Henry Streets, commemorates the First and Second World Wars. The monument comprises of a stone obelisk and lists the names of 234 servicemen who fought in the world wars.

name: Pakenham Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Pakenham Memorial Plaque is located on Snodgrass Street outside the R.S.L. The plaque is dedicated to those who fell and those who served Australia in times of war, including allied forces.

name: Pakenham South War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Pakenham South War Memorial Plaque, on Hall and McDonald's Roads, was unveiled on Australia Day 1997. The memorial commemorates the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam, listing the names of those who served.

name: Pakenham Upper Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Pakenham Upper Memorial Plaque, near the Country Fire Authority building, is dedicated to the local men and women who made the supreme sacrifice during times of war.

name: Panton Hill War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Panton Hill War Memorial, in the grounds of St. Matthews Church, comprises of a marble cross inscribed with the names of those locals who fell in First World War.

name: Parkdale WWII Memorial
description: The Parkdale WWII War memorial takes the form of a tall and slender obelisk in plain concrete with a large three-pronged base and a simple brass wreath on the front. The plaque reads, 'This memorial was unveiled by his excellency Major- General Sir Rohan Delcombe, Governor of Victoria, 10th November, 1968.' The plaque to the right reads 'The City of Mordialloc will always remember its fallen'. The obelisk is linked to the First World War Monument by a simple concrete apron, which describes a simple contemplative space between the memorials

name: Parkville WWI Memorial
description: The Parkville WWI War Memorial, at the junction of Royal Parade and The Avenue, was erected on 4th October 1925. The memorial comprises of a marble digger holding his rifle upside down in the symbolic funereal position. The statue stands on a granite pedestal the sides of which are inscribed with thirty names of the men who paid the supreme sacrifice during the First World War, with the words on a plaque: We Died For Country; Live Ye For It. The monumental mason was Peter Morgan Jaguers of Jageurs & Son, Parkville, who had to carve the name of his son, John Davitt Jageurs, among the dead. John Jageurs enlisted on 10 May 1915 in the 24th Battalion and served at Gallipoli, where he suffered shell-shock. He rejoined his unit in 1916, but was killed at Pozieres on 29 July 1916. His grave was lost in that terrible action, and he is remembered on the Villers-Bretonneux memorial.

name: Paschendale Memorial Hall
description: The Paschendale Memorial Hall was established in April 1925. After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Pascoe Vale Primary School War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Pascoe Vale Primary School War Memorial, on Gaffney Street and Cumberland Road, comprises of a white squat obelisk dedicated to both the world wars.

name: Pascoe Vale RSL WWII Memorial Plaque
description:
At the entrance to the Pascoe Vale R.S.L. is a plaque commemorating the 60th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War. The plaque's inscription quotes two verses fromLawrence Binyon's famous poem, For the Fallen:

"They went with songs to the battle, they were young,
Straight of limb, true of eye, steady and aglow.
They were staunch to the end against odds uncounted;
They fell with their faces to the foe.

They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old:
Age shall not weary them, nor the years contemn.
At the going down of the sun and in the morning
We will remember them."

name: Patchewollock War Memorial
description: The Patchewollock War Memorial, located outside the Memorial Hall, is a flagstaff with a pyramid base. The base is enclosed witha wrought iron inscription, "Lest We Forget."

name: Patchewollock Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Patchewollock Memorial Community Centre was opened on 5th April 1980 by K.I. Wright, Member for North Western Province.

name: Patchewollock Commemorative Park
description: <FONT size=2>The Patchewollock Commemorative Park is dedicated to the pioneer settlers of the town and those who served in the Second World War. There is a plaque commemorating the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War and an Honour Roll listing the names of residents who served.

name: Paynesville War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Paynesville War Memorial is located on the Main Road outside the R.S.L. The memorial is a small white obelisk dedicated to 89 servicemen who fought in the First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Peechelba Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Penshurst Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The foundation stone for the Penshurst Memorial Hall was laid on 25th October 1963 by Viscount De L'Isle, the last British Governor General of Australia.

name: Penshurst Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Penshurst Memorial Hospital was officially opened on 2nd October 1957 by Dr. J.H. Lindell. The year before the opening on 16th December, a memorial stone dedicated to all those who served was laid by pastor E.W. Wiebusch .

name: Peronne Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The foundation stone for the Peronne Memorial Hall was laid by Mrs. E.S. Ross on February 18th 1957.

name: Piangil War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Piangil War Memorial, on Hall Street, is a granite obelisk inscribed with the names of those locals who served in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Pigeon Ponds Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Pleasant Creek War Memorial
description: The Pleasant Creek War Memorial is located on a private property known as "Anthony's Paddock", at the junction of Western Highway and Hall's Gap Road. The memorial was originally erected on the site of Treasury in Commercial Street on July 19th 1919. It comprises of a rough sandstone cairn on a three tiered base and features a marble plaque dedicating it as a peace memorial.

name: Point Addis RAAF Memorial Cairn
description: The Point Addis R.A.A.F. Memorial Cairn, on Point Addis Road off the Great Ocean Road, commemorates the use of the Surf Coast by the R.A.A.F during the Second World War. Point Addis and forest land to the north were acquired for training purposes including a bombing, strafing and gunnery range. The area was also patrolled by the R.A.N. and volunteer air observers to detect enemy activity. In 1944, a B25 Mitchell Bomber crashed in to the sea killing three airmen while two others were rescued by the Air Observers Corps. The three airmen killed were Squadron leader F.R. McGrill (M.I.D), Flight Lieutenant R.A. Wines (D.F.C.) and R.J. Cavanagh.

name: Point Cook Cenotaph
description: The Point Cook Cenotaph is located inside the Point Cook R.A.A.F Base. The cenotaph is dedicated to all those who served in the Australian Flying Corps, Royal Naval Air Service, Royal Flying Corps and Royal Air Force during the First World War, Second World War and subsequent conflicts.

name: Point Cook Korean War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Point Cook Korean War Memorial Plaque is located inside the R.A.A.F base near the Cenotaph. The plaque is dedicated to the memory of 36 R.A.A.F and 5 R.A.F personnel who lost their lives whilst serving with the 77 Squadron during the Korean War. The plaque also honours the R.A.A.F Nursing Service personnel who served during the Korean War.

name: Point Cook 467-463 Squadron Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Point Cook 467-463 Squadron Memorial Plaque is located inside the R.A.A.F Base near the Cenotaph. The plaque is dedicated to the memory of those who served in the 467-463 R.A.A.F Lancaster Squadrons.

name: Point Lonsdale War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Point Lonsdale War Memorial Obelisk, on Glaneuse and Kirk Roads, was erected on 31st December 1925. The memorial commemorates 31 residents who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Pomborneit WWII Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Pomborneit WWII Memorial is located in the grounds ofa former school which has become a public hall. The memorial is a flagpole with a plaque on the base listing the names of former student who fell in the Second World War.

name: Pomborneit Charles Cooper Boyd Memorial Gate
description: <FONT size=2>The Pomborneit Charles Cooper Boyd Memorial Gate forms the entrance to the Anglican Church. It was erected by the Boyd family in memory of Charles who was killed in action at Bougainville on 17th March 1945, aged 22.

name: Pomborneit WWII Memorial Seat
description: <FONT size=2>The Pomborneit WWII Memorial Seat, inside the Recreation Reserve, is dedicated to the memory of members of the cricket club who served during the Second World War.

name: Poolaijelo Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Port Albert War Memorial Gardens
description: <FONT size=2>The Port Albert War Memorial Gardens are dedicated to those who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Portarlington War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Portarlington War Memorial, on Pier Street, was erected on 28th September 1919. The memorial comprises of a pillar lamp post and lists the 82 names of those who served in the First World War, Second World War, British Commonwealth Occupation Force (Japan), Korea, Malaya, the Indonesian Confrontation and Vietnam.

name: Port Fairy Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>The Port Fairy Cenotaph, on Bank Street, stands on a paved square planted with rose bushes. The cenotaph is dedicated to Port Fairy and District's service personnel who fought in the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam and in Peacekeeping missions.

name: Portland War Memorial Stairs
description: The stairs leading up to the Portland War Memorial on Cliff Street, feature plaques dedicated to those who served in the Second World War, Korea, Vietnam and Malaya.

name: Portland Reginald Saunders Memorial Plaque
description: Nearby to the Portland War Memorial Statue lies a plaque dedicated to Captain Reginald Saunders. Saunders was born in 1920 in the Portland district, joining the Australian Army during the Second World War. In 1944, Saunders became the first Indigenous Australian to be commissoned as an officer. When the Korean War began, Saunders returned to the Army serving as captain in the 3rd Battalion Royal Australian Regiment, fighting at Kapyong. In later years, Saunders worked for the Office of Aboriginal Affairs as a liason and public relations officer. He died on 2nd March 1990.

name: Portland Memorial RSL Clubrooms
description: <FONT size=2>The Portland Memorial RSL Clubrooms were opened on Anzac Day 1923 by A.S. Rodgers. Inside the entrance are marble tablets featuring honour rolls with the names of those who served in the First World War, Second World War and Korea.

name: Portland Peace Garden
description: The Portland Peace Garden, outside the Shire Offices, was planted by the Portland Women's Service Club. The garden is dedicated to all civilian women and men who served, suffered and died in times of war.

name: Portland Vietnam Memorial Garden
description: The Portland Vietnam Memorial Garden, behind the shire offices, was officially opened by Tim Fischer on 14th August 1993. The garden features a plaque inscribed,"For all those who served, suffered and died - Vietnam War -1962-1973."

name: Portland RSL Memorial Bowling Club
description: <FONT size=2>The Portland RSL Memorial Bowling Club, established in 1958, is located at 33 Cape Nelson Road.

name: North Portland Memorial Water Tower
description: <FONT size=2>The North Portland Water Tower was converted to a memorial look out and R.S.L. repository. On 27th April 1996, Major General 'Digger' James dedicated the tower to 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War

name: Portland War Memorial Plaques
description:
The Portland War Memorial Plaques, outside the Shire Offices, are dedicated to various personnel who served in times of war including -

*The Victorian Vietnam Veterans Community on the 40th Anniversary of the Battle of Long Tan in Vietnam, 18th August 2006.

*38 Portland and District Servicemen taken prisoner of war including 17 who died in prison.

*34,737 Australian men and women made prisoners of war during the Boer War, First World War, Second World War and Korea. 8,600 of whom died in prison.

*Portland and district ex-service women of the Second World War.

name: Port Welshpool WWI Memorial Garden
description: Inside the grounds of the local Port Welshpool museum is a memorial garden. The garden features a small shelter and two marble tablets dedicated tothe fallen of the First World War; William Bruce Smith who died of wounds on the Western Front 10th October 1917, aged 28 years old and A.R. Rackstraw killed in action at Gallipoli on 25th May 1915, aged 23 years old.

name: Prahran AWAS Memorial Drinking Fountain
description: <FONT size=2>The Prahran Australian Women's Army Service (AWAS) Memorial Drinking Fountain, inside Fawkner Park, was unveiled by Lady Murray in October 1952 in memory of those women who served during the Second World War.

name: Prahran WWI Memorial Steps
description: <FONT size=2>The Prahran WWI Memorial Steps, on Mowbray Street, were erected in 1919 in memory of the old preparatory school boys who died servingin the First World War.

name: Prahran Nurses Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The former Prahran Nurses Memorial was located in the old Nurses Quarters of the Alfred Hopsital. The small monument included plaques for Sister Eileen Rutherford who lost her life aboard the hospital ship 'Centaur' on May 14th 1943, Matron Thomas killed in action in 1941 and Alfred Hospital trainees R.D. Freemand and F.A. Stevenson.

name: Preston War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Preston War Memorial was erected in September 1923 at the Town Hall on High Street. The memorial comprises of marble tablets attached to the walls of the cloistered entrance. The tablets list the names of those who served in the First World War, while later plaques were added in memory of the Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Puckapunyal Memorial Pavilion
description: <FONT size=2>The Puckapunyal Memorial Pavilion, inside Puckapunyal Memorial Park, was presented by the 2/7 Australian Infantry Battalion Association on 11th October 1959. It is dedicated to those who fell fighting in the Second World War in Libya, Greece, Crete, Syria, Ceylon, New Guinea and also includes an honour roll of the 7th Battalion RAR (Royal Australian Regiment) who served in Vietnam.

name: Puckapunyal WWI Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Puckapunyal WWI Memorial Plaque, inside the Puckapunyal Memorial Park, is dedicated to the 7th Battalion A.I.F. who served in Egypt, Gallipoli, France and Belgium during the First World War.

name: Puckapunyal Memorial Park
description: <FONT size=2>The Puckapunyal Memorial Park, located on the Puckapunyal Military Base, is dedicated to the memory of those fallen who trained or served at Puckapunyal. Inside the park are several memorials commemorating specific battalions and conflicts including the First World War, Second World War, Malaya,Korea and Vietnam.

name: Puckapunyal Korean War Memorial Plaque
description: The Puckapunyal Korean War Memorial Plaque was erected inside the Memorial Park by the Korean Veterans Association of Australia. The plaque is dedicated to all Australian Military Personnel who paid the supreme sacrifice serving in Korea between 1950-1953.

name: Puckapunyal National Servicemen's Memorial Obelisk
description: The Puckapunyal National Servicemen's Memorial Obelisk, inside the Memorial Park, was unveiled by Mr. Douglas W. Black (Victorian State President of the National Servicemen's Association) on 16th May 1999. It is dedicated to all National Servicemen who served in Victoria.

name: Puckapunyal Weary Dunlop Memorial Plantation
description: The Puckapunyal Weary Dunlop Memorial Plantation, inside the Memorial Park, is dedicated to the courageous actions of Sir Edward "Weary" Dunlop while imprisoned in the infamous Japanese POW camp on Thai-Burma Railway - "Hellfire Pass."

name: Puckapunyal Korea - Japan Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Puckapunyal Korea - Japan Memorial Plaque, inside the Memorial Park, is dedicated to the personnel who served with the British Commonwealth Occupation Force in Japan between 1946-1951 and in the Korean War between 1950-1953.

name: Puckapunyal 2nd Battalion Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Puckapunyal 2nd Battalion Memorial Plaque is located inside the Memorial Park. The 2nd Battalion Royal Australian Regiment trained at Puckapunyal and has seen active service in the Korean War, Malayan Emergency and Vietnam War.

name: Pyramid Hill Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Pyramid Hill Soldiers Memorial Hall, on Kelly Street, was officially opened by Colonel C. Hurry on 22nd April 1922. The Hall commemorates those men who served in the First World War.

name: Pyramid Hill Boer War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Pyramid Hill Boer War Memorial Obelisk is dedicated to Private H.J. Hiscock who died at Bloemfontein, South Africa on 19th May 1900. An honour roll plaque has since been added to the monument to acknowledge the service of all the district men who fought in the Boer War.

name: Pyramid Hill Memorial Swimming Pool
description: The Pyramid Hill Memorial Swimming Pool is dedicated to all "those who gave their lives for peace in the twentieth century."

name: Quambatook Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Queenscliff RSL Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Queenscliff RSL Hall, on King and Hesse Streets, was opened in 1993 in memory of all those who died in the service of their country. The building replaces an earlier Hall built in memory of the First World War.

name: Queenscliff WWI Memorial Garden
description: The Queenscliff WWI Memorial Garden, on Flinders Street, features a large boulder monument and plaque that lists the names of those who fell in the First World War.

name: Queenscliff H.M.A.S Goorangai Memorial
description:
The Queenscliff H.M.A.S Goorangai Memorial commemorates the loss of the ship in November 1940. Sunk in a collision with the loss of the entire crew of 24, the 223 ton gross minesweeper HMAS Goorangai has the tragic distinction of being all at once Australia's first naval loss of World War II, the first Royal Australian Navy surface vessel lost in a war, and the first Royal Australian Navy surface vessel lost with all hands. It had just returned from its minesweeping operations in Bass Strait including recovering wreck debris from the City of Rayville with Lieut-Commander Gordon Boyle on board as minesweeping adviser and was enjoying a respite from bad weather while reprovisioning in Port Phillip.

Originally built as a 'Castle' type steam trawler based on a North Sea design, it was intended to assist develop a trawl fishing industry to create jobs in NSW in Depression years but was then requisitioned by the RAN in the Second World War. Following the sinking of the SS Cambridge and MV City of Rayville in Bass Strait by German mines on 7th and 8th November 1940 respectively, three minesweepers including the HMAS Goorangai were ordered to the sweep the shipping lanes and approaches to Port Phillip, and within a fortnight were able to locate and destroy forty mines. Prime Minister Menzies also called for Australian war vessels in the Mediterranean to be returned to Australian waters, and the fated HMAS Sydney (to be later sunk by the German raider Kormoran off Western Australia with the loss of all 645 crew) was one of these vessels, returning in April 1941.

At night in wartime 'brown-out' (minimal lights exhibited) conditions the HMAS Goorangai was bound from Queenscliff to anchor at Portsea, while steaming outwards at full speed through the South Channel was the dark silhouette of the 10,400 ton outward bound passenger liner Duntroon bound from Melbourne to Sydney. The HMAS Goorangai was seen at the last minute by those on the bridge of the Duntroon, but it was too late to avert a collision. At 8.45pm the diminutive HMAS Goorangai had no chance as it was struck almost amidships by the huge bow of the fast moving liner and sank immediately. Rescue efforts were hampered as searchlights were forbidden and the Queenscliff lifeboat got stuck on a bank in attempting to attend the rescue. Lifejackets were thrown in the direction of cries of men by those on board the Duntroon but in the strong ebb tide no survivors were ever found and only six bodies recovered afterwards.

The Court of Marine Inquiry initially blamed both vessels with Capt.Lloyd of the Duntroon found guilty of misconduct. However he was later exonerated by the Court with faulty positioning of lights on the Goorangai cited as the prime cause of the accident. A censorship ban was invoked by Naval Board until the next-of-kin wereinformed, setting a precedent for similar cases and for casualties in action. The ship wreck was reportedly demolished by explosives in January 1941 but still buoyed until March 1942, with its Registration Certificate recorded as cancelled on 2nd November 1942.

Numerous calls were made over the years by relatives of the deceased servicemen to protect the wreck in 15 metres depth as a war grave and a national memorial. Items such as gas masks were known to have been found by divers, as well as distressing rumours that human bones and a skull had been removed from the site by divers in the 1970s and 1980s. However the Commonwealth Veterans Affairs Department and Australian Office for War Graves have no power to declare sunken vessels as war graves. There was no protection of the site until the Victorian Historic Shipwrecks Act (1981) was introduced. The HMAS Goorangai is now protected under the Victorian Heritage Act (1995) and it is an offence to disturb or remove any material from the site.

name: Queenscliff HMAS Napier Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Queenscliff HMAS Napier Memorial commemorates the lives of two men lost overboard from the ship in the Bass Strait on 8th March 1945: A.B. Ronald F. Back and A.B. Leslie J. Halpin. The Napier with her sister ships Nizam and Nestor formed part of the 7th Destroyer Flotilla. The plaque was erected by the "N" Class Destroyers Association of Australia.

name: Queenscliff Navy War Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>The Queenscliff Navy War Memorial Plaques are located along the Esplanade. The plaques are dedicated to those who lost their lives during the Second World War while serving in the Merchant Navy and Royal Australian Navy. There is also a memorial comprising of a former mine donated by H.M.A.S Cerberus.

name: Queenscliff Boer War Memorial
description: Inside the Queenscliff Fortifications, Gellibrand and King Streets, is a brass Honour Roll inscribed with the names of those residents who fell in the Boer War.

name: Queenscliff Anglican Church Boer War Plaque
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Rainbow War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Rainbow War Memorial, on Federal Street, is a statuary monument of a digger staring straight ahead with his rifle upside down in the symbolic funereal position. The pedestal of the statue lists the names of those locals who served in the First and Second World War, 60 of whom never returned.

name: Raywood Memorial Gateway
description: <FONT size=2>The Raywood Memorial Gateway, on Sandhurst Road, honours those who paid the supreme sacrifice in all wars and conflicts in defence of Australia. Each pillar of the gateway is engraved with the dates of the First and Second World Wars.

name: Redbank WWII Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Redbank WWII Memorial Obelisk, located in the cemetery, is dedicated to three locals who fell fighting in the Second World War: Maurice Francis Smith, Leo Edward Meagher and Roy Ernest Horwill.

name: Red Cliffs War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Red Cliffs War Memorial, on Barclay Square, is a white cenotaph listing 1007 personnel who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: St Josephs War Memorial Church
description: <FONT size=2>The St Josephs War Memorial Church, on the Calder Highway, was blessed and opened by Reverend J.P. O'Collins on 8th October 1967.

name: Red Hill Memorial Pre-School
description: <FONT size=2>The Red Hill Memorial Pre-School, on Red Hill Road, is dedicated to the fallen of both World Wars.

name: Red Hill Memorial Rose Garden
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Reedy Flat War WWI Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Reedy Flat War WWI Memorial, on Hammond Road, comprises of a marble tablet dedicated to 33 First World War servicemen.

name: Reservoir Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>The Reservoir Cenotaph, on Edwards Street, was erected on 12th November 1967. The black cenotaph is set against a white wall and flagstaff, it is dedicated to those who paid the supreme sacrifice in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam. There is also a special plaque dedicated to the memory of Leslie Thomas Farren, the first Victorian Serviceman to be killed in the Vietnam War.

name: Rheola Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Rheola Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Memorial Hall, are dedicated to the First World War and Second World War. The pillars are inscribed with the dates of the world wars and the lintel bears the rising sun emblem of the A.I.F.

name: Richmond War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Richmond War Memorial, in Barkly Gardens on Mary Street, comprises of a coloured slate flagstaff. The memorial is dedicated to those who made the supreme sacrifice in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Riddells Creek WWII Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The WWII Memorial Gates, on Kilmore Road, were unveiled on 25th June 1950 by Lieutenant-General Sir Edmund Herring in front of a crowd of 400 people.The memorial comprises of ornamental, wrought iron gates attached to dressed bluestone pillars that feature bronze plaques with the names of those who served.

name: Ringwood RSL Memorial Flagstaff
description: <FONT size=2>The Ringwood RSL Memorial Flagstaff, on James and Station Streets, is dedicated in grateful remembrance of Ringwood men and women who served in the First World War

name: North Ringwood State School Remembrance Tree
description: <FONT size=2>The North Ringwood State School Remembrance Tree, on Oban Road, was planted on Armistice Day 1955 in memory of the fallen of both world wars. The tree is a lemon scented gum and was planted in sand brought back from Gallipoli by Ron Pullin in 1936.

name: Robinvale War Memorial
description: The Robinvale War Memorial, on George Street, was opened Lieutenant-General Sir Horace Robertson on April 26th 1953. The monument is engraved with a cross and the inscription "Lest We Forget."

name: Robinvale Memorial Gateway
description:
The Robinvale Memorial Gateway, in Caix Square on the Villers Bretanneaux Walk, was opened by Madame Huguette Pillon on 5th May 1984. The gateway marks not only the First World War theatre of war but a friendship between Villers - Bretanneaux and Robinvale as sister towns, who were 'twinned' in 1984.

Robinvale is named in memory of Lieutenant George Robin Cuttle, who was killed in action dring air combat over France in 1918. Cuttle was born in 1896, the second son of Hubert and Margaret Cuttle who had a general store (Cuttles Malle Stores) at Ultima near Swan Hill. His father made him manager of a large property at Euston across the Murray River from what is now Robinvale in 1914 when he was just 18.

On the outbreak of the First World War, Cuttle, who was 203 centimetres and over 100 kilos, tried to enlist in the AIF but was rejected. Perhaps he was too big. But he was also very determined. He travelled to England and tried to enlist in the Royal flying Corps, but was again rejected as too heavy and tall for the flying machines. Instead he joined the Royal Field Artillery in July 1916 and served on the Somme, where he was awarded the Military Cross.

In late 1917, conditions for entry to the RFC had changed, and Rbin joined as an observer. He was flying with 49 Squadron, flying DH9 bombers. Returning from a mission on 9 May 1918, the aircraft was shot down. The bodies were never found and Cuttle is remembered on the Arras Flying Memorial and the Ultima War Memorial.

After the war, in 1923, Robin's parents and brother Robert went to France to search for him. At Caix, 10 kilometres from Villers-Bretonneux, they found evidence of the wreck.

In 1924, the Cuttles were planning to develop the land they had acquired on the bend in the Murray once the railway reached there. The story goes that at the opening of the land sale at the new station, Robin's mother embroidered a piece of hessian with flowers and the words Robin Vale - (Farewell Robin) and so it came about. Another story is that the post office originally known as Bumbang was renamed Robinvale for the same reason. The Cuttles built a new home named Robinswood there.

name: Rochester War Memorial
description: The Rochester War Memorial wasfirst erected at the corner of Gillies and Moore Streets in 1902 but later moved in front of the RSL at the corner Victoria and Mary Streets. The memorial consists of a granite, marble and bluestone monument with a cast iron lamp on top. Originally dedicated to Sgt. Williamson who was killed in the Boer War, inscriptions have been added over the years for the First and Second World Wars, Korea, Malaysia, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Rochester Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Rochester Memorial Wall, located near the RSL building on Victoria and Mary Streets, is dedicated to all who have served thier country at home or abroad. The memorial was unveiled on Remembrance Day 1993 and comprises of a red brick wall and small flower bed.

name: Rochester Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Rochester Memorial Hospital was erected as a memorial to the district's men and women who served in the Second World War.

name: Rochester Memorial Swimming Pool
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Rokeby Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Rokeby Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the reserve, feature coloured wrought iron with the dates of the First World War and Second World War.

name: Romsey WWII Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Romsey WWII Memorial Plaque is attached to the wall of the former Shire Office. The plaque lists the names of those Romsey men who paid the supreme sacrifice during the Second World War.

name: Romsey Anglican Church Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Romsey Anglican Church Memorial Gates were erected by the family of Charles F.D. Thomson, who died on 21st February 1943 on active service in New Guinea , aged 22.

name: Rosebud War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Rosebud War Memorial was erected by the Sailors, Soldiers and Airmen's Fathers Asssociation, in memory of men and women who paid the supreme sacrifice in times of war. The memorial comprises of a wall inscribed with the dates of the world wars and a plaque for conflicts in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam. On the central panel of the war is a silver cross and at each end of the wall rests a flower bed.

name: Rosebud RSL Memorial
description: The Rosebud RSL Memorial comprises of a flagstaff with a brick memorial wall. The wall is adorned with name plaques of Rosebud residents who served, an ornamental brass wreath and a small marble tablet featuring a white cross and the inscription "Lest We Forget."

name: Rosebud Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Rosedale War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Rosedale War Memorial, on Prince and Lyons Street, is a stone cenotaph listing the names of those district men who served in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Rosedale Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Rosedale Memorial Wall is a polished red granite panel, dedicated to all district men and women who served in times of war.

name: Rowsley Avenue of Honour
description:
The Rowsley Avenue of Honour is dedicated to the Second World War. A small roadside cairn lists the names of those who served, including those personnel who paid the supreme sacrifice. Further research is required on the exact location and condition of this Avenue.

In Australia, commemorative trees have been planted in public spaces since the late nineteenth century. Arbor Days were held regularly in most Victorian State Schools during the late 1800s and early 1900s, and numerous trees were planted in parks in Melbourne and throughout Victoria to mark the visits of important and famous people.

This tradition of commemorative planting was continued in 1901 when at the end of the Boer War trees were often planted for each soldier of the district who was killed in South Africa. These plantings, however, rarely consisted of more than two or three trees in each town.

During and after the First World War avenues of honour consisting of trees lining significant streets became a popular form of commemoration. They represented a new egalitarian approach to the commemoration of soldiers where rank was not a consideration: each tree symbolises a person.

Avenues of honour are a uniquely Australian phenomenon. Australians, and in particular Victorians, embraced the idea of planting them more enthusiastically than any other country in the world. Dating from May 1916, the Eurack Avenue of Honour is the earliest known avenue of honour to be planted in Victoria.

By the time of the Second World War avenues of honour had declined in popularity as a means of commemoration. Today it is estimated that over 300 avenues of honour have been planted in Victoria to commemorate service personnel since 1901.

name: Rowville War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Rowville War Memorial, on Fulham Road outside the Municipal Library, is a flat topped obelisk dedicated to all Australian men and women who have paid the supreme sacrifice in times of war.

name: Ruffy Memorial Seat
description: <FONT size=2>The Ruffy Memorial Seat, outside the Hall, was erected on 20th July 1999. The seat comprises of coloured stone and a plaque dedicated to those who fought in all wars to insure peace for Australia.

name: Ruffy Maygar Park
description: <FONT size=2>This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Maygar's Hill Memorial
description:
On the road from Euroa to Melbourne stands a sign for Maygar's Hill, which is dedicated to Victoria Crosswinner, Lieutenant Leslie Cecil 'Elsie' Maygar. Maygar was born at Kilmore. He, his father and three borthers owned Strathearn station, Euroa. Maygar enlisted in the Victorian Mounted Rifles in March 1891 and went with the 5th (Mounted Rifles) Contingent in March 1901. At Geelhoutboom, on 23 November 1901, Lieutenant Maygar was awarded the Victoria Cross for rescuing a fellow Victorian whose horse had been shot. With the enemy only 200 yards away, Maygar dismounted, put the man on his own horse, told him to gallop for the British lines, and ran back under heavy fire. His VC was presented by Lord Kitchener.

Maygar enlisted in the AIF on 20 August 1914 and was appointed a captain in the 4th Light Horse Regiment, serving at Gallipoli and given command of the 8th LHR as lieutenant colonel. Maygar led his regiment througout its service in Sinai and Palestine until his death, and was a much-admired leader. During the second battle of Gaza, on 19 April 1917, official historian Sir Henry Gullett (1941) records that "It was a day when true leaders recognised that their men needed inspiration, and Maygar gave it in the finest manner."

Late on the day of the battle of Beersheba, 31 October 1917, a German aeroplane, using bombs and machine guns, hit Maygar, whose arm was shattered. His grey horse bolted into the darkness and was found later by 8th Regiment troopers, but Maygar was not with him. 'He was picked up during the night by other troops...and, having lost too much blood, died the next day at Karm." (Gullett 1941).

Maygar was awarded the Distinguished Service Order in June 1917, and was mentioned in despatches three times from 1916 to 1918. He is buried at the Beersheba War Cemetery.

name: Rupanyup War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Rupanyup War Memorial Plaque, opposite the RSL Hall on Cromie Street, was erected in 1990 in memory of all personnel who served their country in times of war.

name: Waranga Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Waranga Memorial Hospital was built in memory of those who enlisted from the shire in the Second World War and paid the supreme sacrifice. The hospital has since been converted into a nursing home.

name: Rutherglen Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Rutherglen Soldiers Memorial Hall, on High Street and Murray Street, was established on 20th September 1926.

name: Rutherglen Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Rutherglen Memorial Swimming Pool, inside the Memorial Park on Murray Street, is dedicated to the memory of the Second World War.

name: Rutherglen Vietnam Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Rutherglen Vietnam Memorial, in the Memorial Park on Murray Street, comprises of a stone wall and artillery gun. The memorial is dedicated to the personal sacrifices and devotion who served the district and Australia in Vietnam between 1962-1973. The memorial was opened by Clive Mitchell-Taylor, National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, on Remembrance Day 1996.

name: Rutherglen WWII Memorial Gun
description: <FONT size=2>The Rutherglen WWII Memorial Gun, inside the Memorial Park on Murray Street, was unveiled on Armistice Day 1998 by Mayor Jenny Dale. The memorial is dedicated to personnel from the Rutherglen and surrounding districts who served in the Second World War.

name: Rutherglen Australia Remembers Memorial Flagstaff
description: The Rutherglen Australia Remembers Memorial Flagstaff is located inside the Memorial Park on Murray Street. The memorial was unveiled in 1995 as part of the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War entitled Australia Remembers. The memorial is dedicated to the men and women who served during the Second World War in both combatant and non-combatant roles.

name: Rutherglen Gallipoli Memorial Cairn
description: <FONT size=2>The Rutherglen Gallipoli Memorial Cairn is located in the Memorial Park on Murray Street.

name: Rutherglen Korean War Memorial Cairn
description: <FONT size=2>The Rutherglen Korean War Memorial Cairn is located in front of the War Memorial Pillar, inside the Memorial Park on Murray Street.

name: Rutherglen Long Tan Memorial Cross
description: <FONT size=2>The Rutherglen Long Tan Memorial Cross is located in the Memorial Park on Murray Street. The Cross was unveiled on 18th August 2006, the 40th Anniversary of the Battle of 'Long Tan' during the Vietnam War in which 18 Australians were killed. It is also dedicated to all Australian Service Personnel who served in the Vietnam War between 1962-1973.

name: Rutherglen Memorial Rose Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Rutherglen Memorial Rose Garden was unveiled on Remembrance Day 2007 by the Department of Veteran Affairs and the Indigo Shire Council. The garden is dedicated to memory of deceased local service personnel and the contribution they made to Australia in times of war and peace.

name: Rye RSL Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Rye RSL Memorial Wall, on Nelson Street, is dedicated to the memory of all fallen servicemen.

name: St Arnaud WWI Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The St Arnaud WWI Memorial forms the front porch of the Town Hall on Napier Street. The porch features two niches with First World War Diggers standing in the funereal position, with their rifles upside down. Beneath the statues are tablets which list the names of 35 servicemen who paid the supreme sacrifice in the First World War.

name: St Arnaud Schultze Memorial Tablet
description: <FONT size=2>The St. Arnaud Schultze Memorial Tablet, located inside the Town Hall on Napier Street, was erected on 31st October 1900. Henry Emil Schultze, of the Grenadier Guards, was wounded at Belmont in South Africa during the Boer War. He died aged 24 years old on 25th November 1899.

name: St James Memorial Flagpole
description: The St. James Memorial Flagpole, outside the hall, features a triangular base inscribed with, "Lest We Forget."

name: St Leonards Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>St. Leonards Memorial Hall is located on Murraduc Road.

name: St Kilda Victoria Cross Sculpture
description: <FONT size=2>The St Kilda Memorial Sculpture, in Alfred Square Gardens, was erected 21st April 1985. The sculpture depicts a white figure emerging from a tablet, thrusting his arms upwards with a rifle in his hands. The sculpture commemorates four Victoria Cross winners; Captain A. Jacka, Major W. Ruthven, Lt. L.D. McCarthy and Ft. Lt W.E. Newton. It is also dedicated to the service of all Australians in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: St Kilda Memorial Hall
description: The St. Kilda Memorial Hall, at 88 Acland Street, was established 11th November 1923. The building also features a memorial plaque dedicated to the First World War heroCaptain Albert Jacka.

name: Saint Helens Plains Soldier Settlement Memorial Plaque
description: The Saint Helens Plains Soldier Settlement Memorial Plaque commemorates two returned First World War soldiers and their families who settled in March 1920 on 527 acres of Beddison's Estate. The two soldiers and their wives were G.H. and V.E. Fischer and J. and E.P. Matheson. The plaque was unveiled by John Forest on Australia Day 2003.

name: Sale War Memorial
description: The Sale War Memorial, in front of the Memorial Hall on Macalister Street, comprises of a classical, female statue of Victory mounted on four pillars and a granite pedestal. The memorial was erected on June 16th 1924 to commemorate those who fell in the First World War and was then re-dedicated to include the names of those who served in the Second World War. A plaque next to the monument acknowledges all Australians who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Sale Primary School Memorial
description: The Sale Primary School Memorial Obelisk, on Macalister Street, is dedicated to former pupils and teachers who served in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam, Kuwait and Peacekeeping Missions. The inscription reads, "In memory of the men who kept the flag flying."

name: Sale War Memorial Cross
description: <FONT size=2>The Sale War Memorial Cross, inside the Cemetery, is dedicated to the Second World War. The cemetery contains 58 War graves comprising of 2 Army and 56 R.A.A.F personnel.

name: Sale RSL Boer War Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>Inside the Sale R.S.L. are two memorial plaques dedicated to the fallen of the Boer War; M.W. Atkinson who died at Smithfield on 27th June 1900 and A.H. Wilson who died at Rensburg on 10th Feburary 1900.

name: Sandford Boer War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Sandford Boer War Memorial Plaque is located inside the Anglican Church. The plaque is dedicated to Private Thomas Stock who died at Rensburg, South Africa 10th Feburary 1900.

name: Sandringham and District Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Sandringham and District Memorial Hospital, at 193 Bluff Road, was opened by Sir Rohan Delacombe on March 15th 1964.

name: Sandy Creek Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Sassafras War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Sassafras War Memorial Cairn, on the Sassafras Village Green, is dedicated to all who have served Australia.

name: Sea Lake WWII Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Sea Lake WWII Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Sports Ground, are dedicated to the fallen of the Second World War.

name: Sebastopol Cenotaph
description: The Sebastopol Cenotaph, on Albert Street, is marked with a cross and the inscription "To the fallen." It is flanked by two flagpoles.

name: Sebastopol Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Sebastopol Memorial Gates, at the Sports Ground on Burnett Street, are dedicated to the fallen.

name: Sebastopol Memorial RSL Hall
description: In June 1916 a conference of Returned Soldiers' Association recommended formation of the Returned Sailors and Soldiers Imperial League of Australia (RSSILA, now known as the Returned and Service League or RSL). After the First World War RSSILA branches all around Australia commenced a program of building halls in which their members could meet. Many RSL Halls are still in use in their communities and house honour rolls listing the local people who served and died during war.

name: Sebastopol WWII Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Sebastopol WWII Memorial Plaque is located next to the Cenotaph on Albert Street. The plaque commemorates the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War and the sacrifices of men and women in service of Australia. It was unveiled on August 15th 1995 by Mr. M. Ronaldson.

name: Sebastopol Memorial Seat
description: <FONT size=2>The Sebastopol Memorial Seat, on Albert Street, was donated by the Women's AuxiliaryServices and R.S.L Sub-Branch in memory of the fallen.

name: Serpentine Memorial Complex
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Seville Primary School Memorial Gates
description:
The Seville Primary School Memorial Gates, on School Road, are dedicated to the First World War. The gates also feature plaques dedicated to a former pupil and Victoria Cross winner Captain George Mawby Ingram, who was an "Inspiring example of bravery and leadership to those around him regardless of the danger" in the attack on Montbrehain, France in 1918.

In the advance, which began at dawn, Ingram's 24th Battalion suffered heavy casualties because of strongly defended enemy positions. Without hesitation, Ingram, at the head of his platoon, rushed a post, captured nine machine guns and killed forty-two Germans who had shown stubborn resistance. Later, after his company had suffered severe casualties and many officers had fallen, he took control of the situation once again, rallied his men under intense fire, and led them forward. He rushed another fortification and overcame serious resistance. Twice more that day, he displayed great courage and leadership in the capture of enemy posts and the taking of sixty-two prisoners.

Ingram was born near Bendigo and spent most of his childhood around Lilydale, where he went to the local state school, and then was apprenticed as a carpenter and joiner.

From 1905 to 1914, Ingram was a member of the militia forces and was attached to the Australian Garrison Artillery. On 10 December 1914, he enlisted as a private in the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force, and served in New Guinea until his discharge on 19 January 1916. On the same day, he enlisted in the AIF and, a year later, was with the 24th Battalion in France.

Ingramwas awarded the Military Medal "for great courage and initiative as a member of the bombing section, by excellent placing of his bombs" at Grevillers, near Bapaume, in March. He was in hospital from April until June, and again during September and October, after which he rejoined his battalion. Lieutenant Ingram was awarded the Victoria Cross for his part in the last Australian infantry action, the attack on Montbrehain on 5 October 1918.

In April 1919, he returned to Melbourne and on his discharge became general foreman wit E.A. and Frank Watts Pty Ltd, building contractors. After the completion of the Shrine of Remembrance, he became a guard there. During the Second World War, he served with the Royal Australian Engineers and attained the rank of captain.

Captain Ingram died at home in Hastings on 30 June 1961 and was buried in Frankston Cemetery.

name: Seymour Hospital Memorial Gates
description: The Seymour Hospital Memorial Gates, on Brettounex Street, are dedicated to the First World War. The pillars list the names of the fallen and the inscription, "We lie dead in many lands that you may live in peace."

name: Seymour Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Seymour District Memorial Hospital, on Brettounex Street, was erected to commemorate those who paid the supreme sacrifice in the Second World War.

name: Seymour Light Horse Memorial Trough
description: <FONT size=2>The Seymour Light Horse Memorial Trough, in the park on Light Horse Drive, was opened on by Mayor Murray D.V. Smith on 21st June 1992. The memorial is dedicated to the memory of the horses and soldiers who tended to them while camped in the Seymour area during the First and Second World Wars.

name: Seymour Light Horse Park Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Seymour Light Horse Park Memorial Wall, inside the park, features plaques dedicated to various battalions and regiments who trained in the Seymour area and went on to serve in the world wars.

name: Seymour St Andrew's Memorial Centre
description: <FONT size=2>St Andrew's Memorial Centre was unveiled on 26th October 1968 by Reverend L.N. Bean. The building is dedicated to the memory of those who paid the supreme sacrifice during the First and Second World Wars and in thanksgiving for those who returned home.

name: Sheep Hills War Memorial
description: The Sheep Hills War Memorial, in front of the Sheep Hills Mechanics Hall, is dedicated to the First and Second World Wars. The memorial features a flagpole and is flanked by two more. Above the list of names of those servicemen and women is the inscription, "And these our dead shall not have died in vain."

name: Shelford War Memorial
description: The Shelford War Memorial, on Shelford Road, was unveiled on April 16th 1999. The memorial comprises of a large boulder and plaque dedicated to three fallen Second World War servicemen. The inscription reads, "Pass not this stone in sorrow but in pride and may you live nobly as they died."

name: Shelford Soldier Settlement Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Shelford Soldier Settlement Memorial Plaque commemorates 51 farms on the Shelford Estate and 18 farms on the Golf Hill Estate, that were established by returned servicemen between 1953- 1956.

name: Shepparton and District War Memorial
description:
The Shepparton and District War Memorial is bordered by Marungi, Welsford and Fryers Streets. The site replaces the former memorial on Fryers Street and now comprises of a large area paved with flagstones, a cross made of lawn and two sculptures of infantrymen (including the original memorial's 1924 sculpture) set against angular white walls. The white wall of the memorial is dedicated to fallen servicemen and those who fought in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam, East Timor, Iraq and Afghanistan.

The 1924 sculpture, Helping Hand by Web Gilbert, depicts Pte. John Raws reaching his hand down to help his brother Robert from the trenches at St. Quentin during the First World War. Both were killed in action at Pozieres. The second sculpture, Bela Angyal's 2000 sculpture Mateship, was inspired by the famous war photographer Damian Parer and his image of a temporarily wounded and blinded Pte. Wally Johnson being helped by Sgt. Gordon Ayre, of Shepparton, across the Francisco River in Papua New Guinea.

Gordon Ayre, had joined the militia in 1938. He was he was called up for full-time duty in November 1941, aged 36. He transferred to the AIF in September 1942, and landed in New Guinea in March 1943. In May, the 58/59th was sent to take part in the offensive to capture Lae and Salamaua.

On 30 June, the 58th/59th attacked Bobdubi Ridge, which was heavily defended by the Japanese. In hard fighting over two day days, the battalion managed to secure a position on the ridge. At the end of July, the Old Vickers position was captured and the way opened to Salamaua. The Australians captured Salamaua on 11 September and Lae fell on 16 September.

Ayre was awarded an immediate Military Medal for his untiring and courageous work as a stretcher-bearer in the action on the bobdubi Ridge, at the Old Vickers and Coconuts positions in that month. In the citation, Sergeant Ayre is credited with saving the lives of three wounded comrades on 30 June when 'he unhesitatingly went forward under a hail of enemy fire' and remained with them until he was able to evacuate. The citation, in Ayre's service records, states that on 5 July he:

went forward with native carriers to locate a seriously wounded man. While evacuating him the party came under heavy fire from mortars and machine guns, and the carriers abandoned the stretcher. Sergeant Ayres displayed unflinching devotion to duty and outstanding paitence and courage and remained with the paitent until he was able to reassemble the carriers. He guided them back to safety under great difficulties, at one time moving breast deep 500 metres up the Francisco River. On 28 July he courageously managed the evacuation of a further 8 casualties under heavy shell fire.

The Francisco River was (and still is) a horrible malarial area, and Ayre contracted the first of a recurring series of bouts of malaria here. He served in New Guinea until July 1944, when, after periods in hospital, he was posted to the Murchison Prisoner of War Group in February 1945 - by now he was aged 43. His distinguished service ended when he was discharged in June 1947.

The First World War panels list the eighty-three men of the district who lost their lives. They include Richard Nicholls, who worked in a grocer's shop in Shepparton, and who enlisted aged 16 on 12 June 1916 in the 2nd Pioneer Battalion. He transferred to the 46th Battalion in February 1918, and was a battalion runner.

Private Nicholls was awarded the Military medal for gallantry as a runner on 6 April 1918 when he carried an important message over a kilometre of exposed ground before dawn, helping bring a wounded officer on the way. According to Red Cross records, he said 'my company commander will want me' and made his return journey in the daylight, crawling from shell hole to shell hole, exposed to snipers.

On August 8 1918, Nicholls contributed to Germany's 'Black Day' for the action in which he was awarded the Distinguished Conduct Medal for exceptional bravery near Hamel. The citation records that during an attack he noticed a group of the enemy putting up a stiff fight in a gully, and, collecting a small party of men, led them across the gully to cut them off. Although the men with him were held up by the intense machine-gun fire, he kept on and succeeded with the help of an officer in taking several of the enemy prisoners. His daring and initiative were a fine example to his comrades. Ten days later he was mortally wounded by a shell at Lihons, and is now buried in the Villers-Bretonneux Military Cemetery. Nicholl's older brother, Ernest William Nicholls, enlisted in 1918 and served with the 58th Battalion, also serving in the Second World War.

name: Shepparton High School Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Shepparton High School Memorial Gates, on Hawdon Street, are dedicated to 36 former pupils who fell serving in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Shepparton East War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Shepparton East War Memorial Obelisk formerly located outside the Hall was re-sited on the school grounds. The obelisk commemorates the fallen of the First World War, Second World War and Korea.

name: Skipton RSL Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Skipton RSL Memorial, on Anderson Street, comprised of a small brick cairn and plaque dedicated to district servicemen who fell in the Second World War.
