name: Skipton WWII Memorial Tree
description: The Skipton WWII Memorial Tree was planted on Anzac Day 1995 as part of the Australia Remembers 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War. The tree was planted by the the Skipton School children.

name: Smythesdale Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Smythesdale Memorial Wall, on Miners Road, was erected in 1996. The wall features honour rolls listing the names of those district servicemen who fought in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam.

name: Sorrento RSL Memorial Flagstaff
description: The Sorrento R.S.L. Memorial Flagstaff, on the median strip of the main street, was erected in memory of all Australian men and women who gave their lives in times of war.

name: Sorrento War Memorial Obelisk
description:
The Sorrento War Memorial Obelisk, on the foreshore, was unveiled on 11th December 1921 by Captain Stanley Bruce MHR and dedicated by Reverend E. Warner. Inscribed on the memorial are the names of ten Sorento men who lost their lives in the First World War and 34 others who enlisted locally. Another six names are local men who lost their lives in the Second World War.

The monument was built by G. Dawe of Carlton and money for the memorial was raised by public subscription under a large commitee including: Reverend E Warner (Chairman), Reverend Gray Robertson, J Tayton, WM Croad, JH Thomas, J Clark, W Stringer, CH Morgan, H Watts, JJ Kiel, RH Wilkins, W Hurley, James Wright, D Macfarlan.

Captain Stanley Bruce was the local member of Parliament, he was later Prime Minister of Australia but lost his seat in the 1929 election and went to live in England. He became Lord Bruce of Melbourne and was the first Australian born to take a place in the British House of Lords.

The shire has recently refurbished the surroundings of the monument.

name: Southbank Merchant Navy Memorial
description: The Southbank Merchant Navy Memorial is locatedoutside the Melbourne Maritime Museum on South Wharf Road. The memorial comprises of an anchor elevated on a three tiered base, the inscription reads "To all those in the Merchant Navy who served, suffered and perished at sea."

name: South Yarra Primary School Memorial Gateway
description: <FONT size=2>The South Yarra Primary School Memorial Gateway, at 601 Punt Road, comprises of a roofed brick entrance featuring an honour roll listing the names of 327 fallen and returned First World War servicemen.

name: South Yarra WWII Victory Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>Outside 90 Gordon Grove, South Yarra are two small plaques commemorating the dates of the Allied Second World War Victory in Europe 9th May 1945 and the Victory in the Pacific 19th August 1945.

name: Spotswood War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Spotswood War Memorial, on Mary Street outside the R.S.L., comprises of a squat white obelisk and flagpole. The obelisk is dedicated to the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

name: Spotswood WWII Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Spotswood RSL Memorial Obelisk, on Mary Street, is a polished black monument dedicated to all who served in defence of Australia between 19th February 1942 (the day Japanese attacked Darwin) until Victory in the Pacific on 15th August 1945.

name: Springvale War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Springvale War Memorial, on Springvale Road outside City Hall, was unveiled on 3rd September 1950. The memorial is a black tablet engraved with a gold cross dagger and rests on a three tiered granite base. It was opened by Sir Dallas Brooks and dedicated to Springvale's fallen servicemen who fought in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Stanhope Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>The Stanhope Cenotaph, on Birdwood Avenue and Monash Street, commemorates those who paid the supreme sacrifice in the Second World War.

name: Stanhope Primary School Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Stanhope Primary School Memorial Gates were erected as a tribute to former pupils who served in the Second World War.

name: Stanhope Korean War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Stanhope Korean War Memorial is located next to the Cenotaph monument on the Midland Highway. The memorial is a small stone tablet dedicated to two servicemen: Sgt. W.A. Hoodless and Pts B.C. Perkins.

name: Stanley Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>Stanley Memorial Hall, on Stanley-Beechworth Road, was openedin 1956. After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Stawell War Memorial
description: The Stawell War Memorial (in front of the WWI Memorial Statue) was constructed in the late 20th century and commemorates those who fought and died in the Second World War, Malayan, Korean, Borneo and Vietnam Wars. It is constructed of granite in the form of a coffin and is adorned with a spherical polished granite sculpture depicting planet Earth.

name: Stawell Anglican Church WWII Memorial
description: The Stawell Anglican Church WWII Memorial comprises of a Celtic Cross monument and a plaque on the church wall erected in "Thanksgiving for peace and a memorial to the fallen of World War II. Lest We Forget."

name: Stonyford WWII Memorial Gateway
description: <FONT size=2>The Stonyford WWII Memorial Gateway forms the entrance to the Memorial Hall. The gates were erected in memory of Pte. A.J. Stokie who died as a prisoner of war at Ambon, Indonesia in 1945.

name: Stratford War Memorial
description: The Stratford War Memorial, in the Memorial Park on Tyers Street, comprises of a stone obelisk dedicated to those district servicemen who fought in the First World War and Second World War. The inscription reads "Remember with Thanksgiving the Faithful Men who went forth from the Avon Shire for God and Right. The names of those who returned not again are hereon inscribed to be Honoured for Evermore."

name: Stratford Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Stratford Boer War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>Inside the Stratford Mechanic's Institute is a brass honour roll dedicated to 16 fallen and returned residents who served in the Boer War.

name: Stratford Boer War Headstones
description: <FONT size=2>Inside the Stratford Cemetery are memorial headstones for two fallen Boer War soldiers: Sgt. David Pruden killed 21st July 1900 and his relative Tpr. Charles R. Pruden who died in South Africa on 3rd November 1905.

name: Strathbogie Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Strathbogie Memorial Hall was erected to commemorate the Second World War. After the First and Second World Wars, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Strathdownie Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Strathdownie Memorial Hall was erected in memory of the First World War. After the First and Second World Wars, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Strathmerton War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Strathmerton War Memorial Obelisk, on Murray Valley Highway outside the Public Hall, is dedicated to 64 fallen and returned servicemen who fought in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Streatham Memorial Hall
description: The Streatham Memorial Hall was erected in memory of the Second World War. The facade of the building features a tiled panel with a dagger cross and the inscription, "Lest We Forget."

name: Streatham St Monicas Memorial Church
description: <FONT size=2>St. Monica's Memorial Church was erected to the memory of all those who gave their lives in the service of their country.

name: Sunshine Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>The Sunshine Cenotaph, outside the R.S.L. on Dickson Street, features tablets dedicated to those who served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Sunshine Long Tan Memorial Cross
description: <FONT size=2>The Sunshine Long Tan Memorial Cross was erected on 18th August 2006 to commemorate the 40th of Anniversary of the Vietnam Battle of Long Tan in 1966. The memorial also acknowledges all those Australians who paid the supreme sacrifice in the Vietnam War.

name: Sunshine VP Day Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Sunshine VP Day Memorial was erected August 2005 to commemorate the 60th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War and Victory in the Pacific.

name: Sunshine WWII Honour Roll
description: <FONT size=2>The Sunshine WWII Honour Roll is located at the entrance to the R.S.L. The roll lists the names of H.V. McKay Massey Harris' employees who paid the supreme sacrifice in the Second World War.

name: Surrey Hills Shrine
description: <FONT size=2>The Surrey Hills Shrine is located in Surrey Gardens onUnion and Norfolk Roads. The shrine was designed by John K. Blogg in 1917 to commemorate the First World War. The shrine resembles a small shelter containing brass honour rolls, listing the namesof district servicemen.

name: Surrey Hills Memorial Cross
description: <FONT size=2>The Surrey Hills Memorial Cross is located near the First World War Shrine in Surrey Gardens on Union and Norfolk Roads. The Cross was unveiled by the Earl of Stradbroke on September 11th 1921. The cross features plaques with the names of those who served in the First World War.

name: Sutton Grange War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Sutton Grange War Memorial Obelisk honours those who served in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War and Vietnam.

name: Swan Hill Boer War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Swan Hill Boer War Memorial, on McCallum Street, was erected on 25th April 2001. The memorial features bronze reliefs and 52 names of those who served. It is also dedicated to the Centenary of Federation, 1901-2001.

name: Swanpool War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Swanpool War Memorial, on the Midlands Highway near the Memorial Hall, is dedicated to the First World War and Second World War. The memorial comprises of a marble digger blowing a bugle and 63 names of the fallen and returned soldiers are listed on the pedestal. It originally stood on the intersection of the Midlands Highway and Tatong Road but was moved to the Memorial Hall due to road works.

name: Swifts Creek War Memorial Pillar
description: <FONT size=2>The Swifts Creek War Memorial Pillar, on Great Alpine Road and McMillan Avenue, is a broken pillar monument commemorating nineteen servicemen who fought in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Sydenham Memorial Gateway
description: <FONT size=2>The Sydenham Memorial Gateway were erected at the entrance to the Community Hall in the 1950s to commemorate the First and Second World War. The gates no longer exist but the honour rolls that featured on the pillars were moved on 27th November 1996 to the entrance of Brimbank City Council building.

name: Sydenham War Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>The Sydenham War Memorial Plaques, outside the the Community Centre, were commissioned by the community to commemorate the service of those Sydenham residents in times of war.

name: Tahara WWI Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Tahara War Memorial, on Condah-Coleraine Road, is a rough stone pillar dedicated to those who served in the First World War.

name: Talbot Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>The Talbot Memorial Plaques are located in Soldiers Memorial Park on Heales and O'Hara Streets. The plaques are dedicated to 18 fallen soldiers who served in the Second World War and Vietnam.

name: Talbot WWII Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Talbot WWII Memorial Gates form the entrance to the sports ground. The pillar lists the names of those district servicemen who lost their lives in the Second World War.

name: Talbot Boer War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Talbot Boer War Memorial Plaque, inside the ANA Hall, commemorates the life of Trooper George Hull who died on active service in South Africa on 6th January 1901.

name: Tallangatta Memorial Gates
description: The Tallangatta Memorial Gates form the entrance to the park at the north end of Banool Road. The gates comprise of white pillars and a wrought iron arch with the banner, "For God - Home - Empire. Lest We Forget."

name: Tallangatta Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Tallangatta Memorial Hall is dedicated to both the First and Second World Wars. The foundation stone for the building was laid by A. Murray McKay on 30th October 1955.

name: Tallangatta Valley War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Tallangatta Valley War Memorial, in the School grounds on Cravensville Road, is a rough surface obelisk dedicated to the memory of the fallen in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Tallygaroopna Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Tallygaroopna Memorial Hall, on Victoria and Fowler Streets, was erected to commemorate the First World War. The foundation stone was laid by M.W.J. Bourchier on 1st January 1924. The outside wall isadorned with shield plaques listing themostsignificantbattlefields: Belgium, Palestine, Mespot (Mesopotamia), Egypt, Gallipoli and France. There is also an honour roll listing the names of 43 fallen and returned soldiers from the district who fought in the First World War.

name: Tarnagulla War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Tarnagulla War Memorial Obelisk is located in the Soldiers' Memorial Park on Commercial Road and King Street. The obelisk is dedicated to 24 fallen district servicemen who fought in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Tarwin Lower War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Tarwin Lower War Memorial, in the River Reserve, commemorates district servicemen who lost their lives in the First World War and the Second World War.

name: Tatura War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Tatura War Memorial Obelisk stands in the Robert Mactier V.C. Memorial Garden on Hogan Street. The obelisk commemorates those who served in the First World War, Second World War, Vietnam and the Victoria Cross Winner Private Robert Mactier. Mactier's heroic actions in the First World War allowed his battalion to capture the village of Mont St. Quentin.

name: Tatura Honour Roll
description: <FONT size=2>The Tatura Honour Roll is located inside the Robert Mactier V.C. Memorial Gardens on Hogan Street. The Honour Roll is fixed to a small stone block and commemorates all those district servicemen and women who served in the Second World War and Vietnam.

name: Tatura Victory Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Tatura Victory Hall was built on Hogan Street after the First World War. The foundation stonewaslaid on September 14th 1925 by Brigadier General H.E. Elliot.

name: Tatura Memorial Methodist Church
description: <FONT size=2>The Tatura Memorial Methodist Church is dedicated to those residents who served in the First and Second World Wars. The memorial stone was laid on 21st February 1959 by Reverend C.K. Daws.

name: Tatyoon WWII Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Tatyoon Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Tatyoon Memorial Recreation Reserve, are dedicated to those who served in the Second World War.

name: Tempy Memorial Park
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: The Sisters War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The The Sisters War Memorial is located outside the Memorial Hall on Framlingham Mortlake Road. The memorial comprises of a large boulder with plaques dedicated to those men women who served in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam.

name: The Sisters Memorial Hall

name: Thoona War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Thoona War Memorial Obelisk, inside Progress Park, honours those who served in First and Second World Wars.

name: Thoona Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Thoona Memorial Hall was established on 3rd of August 1956. The foundation stone was laid by Mayor F.A. Cook and the hall dedicated to the memory of all those who served.

name: Thornton Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. name: Timor-Bowenvale WWI Obelisk
description:
The Timor WWI Obelisk, at the corner of Cousin Jack and Timor Roads, is dedicated to the Bowenvale members of the AIF who gave their lives in the Great War 1914-18. It was designed by Messrs Gwilym and Jones and unveiled on Easter Monday 26th April, 1926. Mrs E. M. Simmons of Timor, mother of Pte Percival Simmons, 26, who was killed in France in August 1918, performed the ceremony.

The obleisk rests inside a grassed reserve with little planting except for a mature peppercorn tree, it shares the site with tennis courts, picnic seats and a table.The obelisk is constructed from granite with three steps of smoothly finished granite with rough faced risers with smooth finished margins. The base is a cubic shaped piece of granite with rough finished faces with smooth finished margins to each face. This supports a smooth faced block which again supports a taller smooth faced block of darker stone which bears the inscribed panel. This is capped by a scotia shaped projecting cornice which is the base for a tapered needle of stone with the top finished as a pyramid. There are no inscriptions of individual names.

name: Tongala RSL War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Tongala RSL War Memorial comprises of a red brick wall, with four tablets listing the names of 71 district servicemen who fought in the Boer War, First World War and Second World War.

name: Tongala and District Bush Memorial Hospital
description: The Tongala and District Bush Memorial Hospital, on Cavell and Miller Streets, was opened on 12th September 1925 to commemorate the First World War. In 1990, the Hospital was closed and the land is now occupied by a private residence. All that remains of the Hospital is the foundation stone which records that the building was unveiled by Brigadier General H.E. Elliot in memory of "The Gallant Dead."

name: Tongala Light Horse Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Tongala Light Horse Memorial, inside the town gardens, comprises of a contemporary sculpture of a Digger with a horse saddle. The memorial is dedicated to the Australian Light Horsemen and their mounts which were left in the Middle East on the Brigade's return to Australia after the First World War.

name: Tongala RSL Mural
description: <FONT size=2>On the exterior wall of the Tongala RSL is entitled "Aussies at War." The mural depicts a montage of Australians at war including the charge and capture of Beersheba in the First World War, the navy in action in the Pacific, the airforce in the "Battle of Britain" during the Second World War and the invaluable work of nurses in treating the wounded.

name: Toora Memorial Rose Garden
description: <FONT size=2>The Toora Memorial Rose Garden is located next to the Memorial Column on orner of Stanley Street and Welshpool Road. The garden was donated by the R.S.L. in memory of those who served Australia.

name: Tooradin War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Tooradin War Memorial, on the South Gippsland Highway, was erected in April 1999. The memorial comprises a rough stone, plaque and flagpole.It isdedicated to thosewho served in the First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Tootgarook Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Torquay Anzac Memorial Wall
description: The Torquay Anzac Memorial Wall is located on the Great Ocean Road near the War Memorial. The Wall features the emblems ofthe Army, Navy and Airforce and the inscription, "Lest We Forget."

name: Towong Soldiers Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. name: Traralgon Avenue of Honour
description:
The Traralgon Avenue of Honour was planted on Kay Street in 1929 to commemorate the First World War. Kay Street was originally the main road leading into Traralgon from Melbourne and this accounted for its exceptional width, which is unusual within Traralgon. It was originally lined with pines that were planted in 1903. In 1911, there were already suggestions by members of theCouncil that an avenue of elms replace these trees.

In 1921, several pines at the Franklin Street end were removed to allow the construction of a First World War memorial 'Digger' statue, which was finally unveiled on 25th February 1923. On 20th September 1928 The Traralgon Record heralded the fact that 'Pine trees in Kay Street gardens get the axe'. In October of that year, the gardens were ploughed and the new trees later planted. Photos indicate that a picket fence surrounded a large proportion of this plantation. Also at this time, the war memorial was landscaped in gravel and patterned grass sections. There are no longer any fences or park seats and the grassed area is continuous, replacing the paths of gravel.

By 1929 all the pines had been replaced by Elm trees (Ulmus procera, Ulmus x hollandia) planted in a double row from Franklin to Breed streets. In 1979, the memorial statue was moved to face west, flanking wings were added and the names of the soldiers who died in the Second World War and Vietnam inscribed on the pedestal. As of 2011, the Elm trees have been pollarded and require extensive tree surgery to restructure the crown.

In Australia, commemorative trees have been planted in public spaces since the late nineteenth century. Arbor Days were held regularly in most Victorian State Schools during the late 1800s and early 1900s, and numerous trees were planted in parks in Melbourne and throughout Victoria to mark the visits of important and famous people.

This tradition of commemorative planting was continued in 1901 when at the end of the Boer War trees were often planted for each soldier of the district who was killed in South Africa. These plantings, however, rarely consisted of more than two or three trees in each town.

During and after the First World War avenues of honour consisting of trees lining significant streets became a popular form of commemoration. They represented a new egalitarian approach to the commemoration of soldiers where rank was not a consideration: each tree symbolises a person.

Avenues of honour are a uniquely Australian phenomenon. Australians, and in particular Victorians, embraced the idea of planting them more enthusiastically than any other country in the world. Dating from May 1916, the Eurack Avenue of Honour is the earliest known avenue of honour to be planted in Victoria.

By the time of the Second World War avenues of honour had declined in popularity as a means of commemoration. Today it is estimated that over 300 avenues of honour have been planted in Victoria to commemorate service personnel since 1901.

name: Traralgon Vietnam Honour Roll
description: <FONT size=2>The Traralgon Vietnam Honour Roll is located in Anzac Memorial Park on Ellavale Drive. There is also a plaque to commemorate all Australian men and women who served in the Boer War First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo, Vietnam and peacekeeping missions.

name: Trawalla Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Trawalla Memorial Hall was erected in memory of ex-servicemen and women. The building was opened by Premier H.E. Bolte on December 6th 1957.

name: Trawool 2/21st Battalion Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Trawool 2/21st Battalion Memorial is located on Blake Property on Tallarook-Trawool Road, where the Battalion originally formed in August 1940. During the Second World War the Battalion lost 779 of its members.

name: Trawool 2/22nd Battalion Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Trawool 2/22nd Battalion Memorial Plaque is located on the Rokeby Property, inside the gate on the north side of the highway and half a kilometre west of the bridge. The 2/22nd Battalion was formed on the site of Rokeby Property in July 1940. During the Second World War, 630 members ofthe unit died serving.

name: Trawool 46 Battalion Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Trawool 46 Battalion Memorial Plaque is located on the Farrer Property on Tallarook Road. From 1940, the site housed the Trawool Army Camp where hundreds of young Australians trained. After training the men were re-drafted, most commonly to the 2/22, 2/48, 39, 29/46 Battalion and Anti-Aircraft Units. The plaque commemorates those personnel who were killed in action, wounded or taken prisoner of war during the course of their service in the Second World War.

name: Trentham Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>The Trentham Cenotaph, on High and Market Streets, is an unpolished granite obelisk on three tiered base. The cenotaph commemorates those servicemen who paid the supreme sacrifice in the Boer War, First World War and Second World War.

name: Tubbs Hill VC Memorial Plaque
description:
On the Tubbs Hill road sign, on the west side of the Hume Highway, a small plaque is attached which is dedicated to Victoria Cross winner, Major Frederick Harold Tubb. Tubb was born at Longwood. His father, head teacher at the local school, took up a selection in the area. Tubb obtained his merit certificate and left school to manage the farm; he later worked his own land. He served in the militia in various Victorian units from 1900 to 1913.

Tubb joined the AIF on 24 August 1914 in the 7th Battalion and landed at Gallipoli on 6 July 1915. On 8 August, Captain Tubb took over a vital sector of captured trench at Lone Pine, with orders to hold it at any cost. Early on the 9th, the Turks launched a furious attack, advancing along a sap which had been barricaded with sandbags. From the parapet, with eight men, Tubb fired at the enemy; two corporals in the trench caught enemy bombs and threw them back or smothered them with greatcoats. Although Tubb was blown from the parapet and the barricade was repeatedly wrecked, each time it was rebuilt. He inspired his men, joking and shouting encouragement.

A huge explosion blew in the barricade and killed or wounded most of the defenders. Wounded in the arm and scalp, Tubb was left with Corporals Alexander Burton and William Dunstan; he led them into action, shooting three Turks with his revolver and providing covering fire while the barricade was rebuilt. A bomb burst, killing Burton and temporarily blinding Dunstan. Tubb then obtained additional help, but the Turks did not renew the attack.

Evacuated that evening, Tubb was taken to England to convalesce and was awarded the Victoria Cross. After an emergency appendectomy he was invalided to Australia, arrivingin April 1916. He persuaded a medical board that he was fit, and rejoined his battalion in France in December. His company had an important role in the Menin Road attack, 3rd battle of Ypres, on 20 September 1917. Tubb was hit by a sniper and while being taken out on a stretcher, he was mortally wounded by shell-fire. Tubb was buried in the Lijessenthoek military cemetery.

Three of his brothers also served and returned to Australia: Lieutenant Arthur Oswald Tubb, 60th Battalion; Captain Frank Reid Tubb MC, 7th Battalion; and Sapper Alfred Charles Tubb, Anzac Signal Squadron.

name: Tyers War Memorial Flagstaff
description: The Tyers War Memorial Flagstaff, located outside the Public hall, was unveiled on 10th November 2006 by Peter McGauran the Federal Member for Gippsland. The base of the flagstaff comprises of a rough cut rock and plaque dedicated to "All citizens who unselfishly served our country and all who supported them in ensuring peace and freedom. Lest We Forget."

name: Tynong War Memorial Flagstaff
description: <FONT size=2>The Tynong War Memorial Flagstaff, on Railway Avenue, was unveiled on Remembrance Day 2005. The memorial is dedicated to the Tynong men and women who served Australia in the Boer War, First World War, Second World War, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam. There is also a plaque acknowledging the special contribution of the Tynong community to Melbourne's Shrine of Remembrance. It was local amateur geologist, Mrs. Mary Ann Ryan, who suggested to the National War Memorial Committee that granite from the the original Tynong Quarry be used in the construction of the shrine.

name: Tyrendarra WWII Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>At the entrance to the Tyrendarra Anglican Church are memorial gates dedicated to five men who paid the supreme sacrifice in the Second World War: Ronald Vincent Down, Clifford Joseph Peters, John Noel Learmonth, Charles Cuthbertson Learmonth and Malcolm James Talbot.

name: Ullina War Memorial Cairn
description: <FONT size=2>The Ullina War Memorial Cairn, on Ullina-Kooroocheang Road, honours twenty-six local servicemen who fought in the First World War and ten who fought in the Second World War.

name: Undera Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Undera Memorial Hall is located on Echuca Road. description: <FONT size=2>The Underbool Memorial Gates form the entrance to the Memorial Park.The left pillar lists three district servicemen who fought in the First World War and the right pillar lists nine servicemen who fought in the Second World War.

name: Upwey Primary School War Memorial
description: The Upwey Primary School War Memorial was erected on 29th April 2003. The memorial comprises of a flagpole and plaque dedicated to the "contribution and sacrifice of servicemen and women from the Upwey District."

name: Valencia Creek Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Valencia Creek Memorial Hall was built in 1926. name: Violet Town Memorial Hall and Library
description: <FONT size=2>The Violet Town Memorial Hall and Library, on Cowslip Street, was opened in by the Shire Council on March 8th 1968. The names of 92 servicemen are honoured in the hall.

name: Violet Town Memorial Gates
description: The Violet Town Memorial Gates formthe entrance to the sports ground on Tulip and Hyacinth Streets. The gates comprise of two brick pillars bearing the dates of the First and Second World Wars and a wrought iron archway with the banner, "Lest We Forget."

name: Waaia Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Walhalla WWI Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Walhalla WWI Memorial Obelisk is located in the Central Gardens near the band rotunda.

name: Wallacedale North Hinkler Memorial Plaque
description: In the grounds of the former Wallacedale North is a memorial tree plaque dedicated to Australia's famous Aviation Pioneer Bert Hinkler. Hinkler served in the First World War as an observer-gunner with the Royal Naval Air Service but it was his 1933 flight from England to Australia that proved fatal, crashing over Italy on 7th January.

name: Wallan Mechanics Institute Hall
description: The Wallan Mechanics Institute Hall was used as a school in 1915, a venue for Belgian Relief and Homes for the Blind and as the venue for patriotic farewells.

name: Walpeup Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Walpeup Memorial Hall was established on 16th May 1923 in memory of the fallen of the First World War.

name: Walwa Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Walwa Memorial Hall was established on 27th August 1949 in memory of those who served.

name: Wandin War Memorial Pillar
description:
The Wandin War Memorial Pillar, on the corner of Beenak and Hunter Roads, was unveiled on 4th June 1921. A plaque records that the memorial is " A tribute from the people of Wandin to the memory of those men who were killed in the Great War 1914-19". The lower section was rededicated to those who served in the Second World War. Another plaque also specifically acknowledges the service of women during the Second World War.

The memorial comprises of a tall black pillar, topped with an urn and on mounted on a white marble base. It is enclosed by a low cyclone wire fence, with a flagpole alongside. Two small Italian cypresses mark the entry which is through a wrought iron gate. Several roses have been planted along the fence.

name: Wando Vale War Memorial Obelisk
description: Outside the Wando Vale Memorial Hall is a War Memorial Obelisk constructed outof locally dug granite, with a wooden painted cross at the top. The granite section is composed of two small blocks, a shaft, and two base blocks of ascending size. It is dedicated to those from Wando Vale and Wando Bridge who fell in the First World War, but also includes inscriptions for those who served in the Korean War and Vietnam War.

name: Wando Vale Soldier Settlement Memorial Cairn
description: <FONT size=2>The Wando Vale Soldier Settlement Memorial Cairn was unveiled on 15th April 2001 to commemorate returnedSecond World War servicemen who settled the Bruk Bruk Estate in 1959.

name: Wangaratta Boer War Memorial Obelisk
description:
The Wangaratta Boer War Memorial Obelisk is located on Ovens and Docker Streets inside the War Memorial Gardens. The monument was made by Hoskins & Co. Hawthorn and resembles a small basalt obelisk set on four stub columns above a plinth, with inscriptions on white marble slabs set into the basalt. It was unveiled by local soldier Col. John Hoad on 9th April 1903 to commemorate the declaration of peace at Pretoria in 1902 and the end of the Boer War. The marble slabs feature the names of four soldiers from Wangaratta, Milawa, Greta and Eldorado who died serving in South Africa. It stands next to a memorial dedicated to the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam.

Specific Memorials for the Boer War are quite rare. The presence of two separate war memorials placed side by side together in the one area is even more so. The Wangaratta memorials are both restrained and elegant in design, with their tall, slender shapes set off by the vertical planes of the cathedral and bell tower in the background. Their garden setting is enhanced by the beautiful trees around the site.

name: Wangaratta High School Memorial Gates
description:
The Wangaratta High School Memorial Gates, on Edwards Street, are dedicated to the memory of former students who fell in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam. Of the Wangaratta High School students who fell in the Second World War, none were in the 2/24th. The battalion's flag, however, the original of which was with troops at Tobruk, is used during the school's Anzac Day ceremony.

Eleven of the fourteen students remembered on the memorial were members of the RAAF, sometimes attached to RAF units. They lost their lives all over the world. Flying Officer William Emery lost his life serving with 460 Squadron RAAF over Belgium on 15 June 1943. He is buried at Heverlee War Cemetery, near Leuven, Belgium.

Sergeant Edgar Davy Francis died accidentally while on 6 (Pilots) Advanced Flying course. He is buried at St Peters Cemetery, Little Rissington, in England. His brother, Flying Officer Alan Henry Francis, 460 Squadron, was killed when his Lancaster aircraft was shot down near Bochum in Germany on 18 November 1944. All seven crew, six of whom were Australians, were killed. Francis was the navigator. Francis is buried in Reichswald Forest War Cemetery, Kleve, Germany.

Flying Officer Donald Stephen Lade was killed on 12 September 1944 flying Lancaster with 44 (Rhodesia) Squadron RAF. He is also buried in the Reichswald Forest War Cemetery.

Sergeant Geoffrey Douglas Mummery joined the AIF as a signaller in 1942, but transferred to the RAAF. He was wireless operator on a 61 Squadron RAF Lancaster shot down over Hamburg on 7 March 1945.He is buried in the Becklingen War Cemetery 85 kilometres north of Hanover. The cemetery overlooks Luneburg Heath, where Field-Marshal Bernard Montgomery accepted the German surrender from Admiral Karl Doenitz on 4 May 1945.

Flight Sergeant Edmond William O'Dwyer was killed in an accident with 20 Operational Training school on 22 July 1944 in Scotland. He is buried in the Lossiemouth Regional Cemetery, Scotland.

Sergeant Neil Wedgwood Reid, aged 19, was killed in an accident with 20 Service Flying Training course in the Middle East on 5 September 1944. He is buried in the Alexandria (Chatby) War Cemetery.

Flying Officer Alan Robert Webster was killed in action on 11 August 1944 flying Beaufighters with 30 Squadron RAAF.

Private Bernd George Fritz Binder 9RAR was accidently killed on 27 October 1969 and is buried in the Wangaratta Cemetery.

Sapper Terrence James Renshaw 1 Field Squadron was accidently killed on 30 May 1967 and is buried in the Wangaratta Cemetery.

name: Wangaratta Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Wangaratta 2nd/24th Battalion Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Wangaratta 2nd/24th Battalion Memorial Wall, inside the Wangaratta Cemetery, lists the names of those local servicemen from the Battalion who fell in the Second World War. The Wall was unveiled on 8th November 1997 by the Mayor Geoff Dinning and the President of the 2nd/24th Alan MacFarlane.

name: Wangaratta 2nd/24th Battalion Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>The Wangaratta 2nd/24th Battalion Memorial Plaques are located near the larger Battalion Memorial Wall inside the Cemetery. The first plaque commemorates the 2nd/24th Battalion 26th Brigade, 7th Division (later 9th Division), showing a timeline of events from their formation and training to the key battles they served in. The second plaque marks a Eucalyptus tree planted to commemorate those who died serving the Battalion during the Second World War.

name: Knox Remembers Statue
description: The Knox Remembers Statue is located inside the grounds of Knox City Council Municipal Offices at 511 Burwood Highway. The Statue resembles a small girl holding a bouquet while the base is inscribed with"Knox Remembers 1939-1945."

name: Wantirna WWII Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Wantirna WWII Memorial, located inside the grounds of the Salford Park Retirement Village, was unveiled on Remembrance Day 1996. The memorial comprises of a flagpole and plaque dedicated to residents of the Retirement Village who served in the Australian Defence Forces and Home Occupations during the Second World War.

name: Warburton War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Warburton War Memorial, in the park on the main street, comprises of a grey granite obelisk. The obelisk is an ornate construction featuring an orb at the top and a cupola on a granite pedestal which originally included a water fountain. The obelisk features the names of those who served in the First World War and dedications to those who fell in the Second World War, Korea and Vietnam.

name: Warburton WWII Memorial Wall
description: <FONT size=2>The Warburton WWII Memorial Wall stands in front of the Memorial Obelisk in the park on Warburton's main street. The Wall features a bronze plaque with the names of those who paid the supreme sacrifice during the Second World War.

name: Warracknabeal WWI Memorial Statue
description: <FONT size=2>The Warracknabeal WWI Memorial Statue, on Scott Street, resembles a marble digger standing in the symbolic funereal position with his rifle upside down. The pedestal lists 93 district servicemen of the Borung Shire who made the supreme sacrifice in the First World War.

name: Warracknabeal WWI Memorial Gates
description: The Warracknabeal WWI Memorial Gates are located at the entrance to the Anzac Park on Scott and Arnold Streets. The gates were erected by the women of Borung Shire in memory of the men who never returned from the First World War. The gates comprise of four large, ornate stone gate posts inscribed with the names of the fallen and cast-iron gates that feature the rising sun motifs.

name: Warracknabeal WWII Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Warracknabeal WWII Memorial, in Anzac Park on Scottand Arnold Streets, lists the names of those district servicemen who paid the supreme sacrifice. The memorial comprises of a simple polished, grey granite block and stands alongside a memorial dedicated to later wars.

name: Warracknabeal RSL Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Warracknabeal RSL Memorial, inside Anzac Park, comprises of a polished grey granite block dedicated to those who served in Korea, Borneo, Malaya and Vietnam. The memorial stands next to the larger Second World War monument.

name: Warracknabeal Anzac Memorial Grandstand
description: <FONT size=2>The Warracknabeal Anzac Memorial Grandstand is located inside the sports ground.

name: Warracknabeal Memorial Swimming Pool
description: <FONT size=2>The Warracknabeal Memorial Swimming Pool is dedicated to the Second World War.

name: Warrenbayne War Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Warrenbayne War Memorial Obelisk, near the school and recreation grounds, is dedicated to those who served in the First and Second World Wars.

name: Warrion WWI Memorial Obelisk
description: <FONT size=2>The Warrion WWI Memorial Obelisk, in the corner of the sports ground, was unveiled by Brigadier General Stewart on Anzac Day 1920. It is dedicated to the memory of district servicemen who paid the supreme sacrifice in the First World War.

name: Warrion WWII Memorial Tree
description: <FONT size=2>The Warrion WWII Memorial Tree is located inside the sports ground. The name plaque at the foot of the tree is dedicated to Private T.J. Dwyer.

name: Warrnambool Textiles War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Warrnambool Textiles War Memorial, on Harris Street, is an ornamental platform featuring an urn in the centre. The memorial was erected in honour of four residents who served in the First World War and three who served in the Second World War.

name: HMAS Warrnambool Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The HMAS Warrnambool Memorial Plaque is on the outside of the RSL Wall on Liebig and Merri Streets. The plaque commemorates the HMAS Warrnambool which operated from Darwin during the Second World War. After the war ended, the Warrnambool joined the 20th Minesweeping Flotilla to clear mines laid during the war. On 13th September 1947, the ship struck a mine off Cockburn Reef in North Queensland, sinking with the loss of four sailors and injuring twenty-six others.

name: Warrnambool Peace Commemoration Playground
description: The original playground is no longer at this site. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute furtherinformation to this record.

name: Warrnambool General Gordon Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Warrnambool General Gordon Memorial, on Cannon Hill Drive, comprises of the remains of an obelisk sunk into the ground. The marble plaque on the memorial is dedicated to General Charles Gordon who fell in Sudan on 26th January 1885.

name: Warrnambool Vietnam Memorial Flagstaff
description: <FONT size=2>The Warrnambool Vietnam Memorial Flagstaff, on Liebig Street and Merris Street, was erected on 9th February 2003. The memorial honours those who served in the Vietnam War. The front panel of the wall features a photo of a battle scene in Vietnam. The wall is also dedicated to those who served in Korea, Malaya, Borneo, peace keeping forces and in hazardous services since the Second World War.

name: Warrnambool Korean Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Warrnambool Korean Memorial Plaque, on Liebig and Merris Streets, was unveiled on 27th October 2001 by the Korea Veterans Association of Australia.

name: Watsonia Cenotaph
description: <FONT size=2>The Watsonia Cenotaph, outside the RSL on Morwell Avenue, was erected on Anzac Day 1981. The monument is dedicated to all those who served and to those who paid the supreme sacrifice in times of war.

name: Watsonia Simpson Barracks Memorial
description: This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Watsonia WWII Memorial Plaques
description: <FONT size=2>The Watsonia WWII Memorial, located on Herring Avenue, was unveiled on 8th November 1991. The memorial consists of a large rock and two plaques.The plaques are dedicated to the service of the 7th Australian Division A.I.F. in the Second World War in Egypt, Libya, Syria, Borneo and New Guinea and also the Signals 6th Australian Division.

name: Waubra Memorial Obelisk
description: The Waubra Memorial Obelisk, on Hall Street and Sunraysia Highway, was erected on 28th March 2004. The obelisk lists the names of the district servicemen who fought in the First World War, Second World War and Vietnam.

name: Waurn Ponds Avenue of Honour
description:
The Waurn Ponds Waurn Ponds Avenue of Honour is marked by a stone and plaque in the Waurn Ponds Memorial Reserve on Cochranes Road. The plaque records that the Waurn Ponds Avenue of Honour was planted in July 1919 to honour fifteen residents who served in the First World War. The plaque lists the names of those fifteeen men as well as those who served in the Second World War. Originally the Avenue was planted with thirty-one Moreton Bay Figs, Pines and Eucalypts trees but only nine trees remain.

In Australia, commemorative trees have been planted in public spaces since the late nineteenth century. Arbor Days were held regularly in most Victorian State Schools during the late 1800s and early 1900s, and numerous trees were planted in parks in Melbourne and throughout Victoria to mark the visits of important and famous people.

This tradition of commemorative planting was continued in 1901 when at the end of the Boer War trees were often planted for each soldier of the district who was killed in South Africa. These plantings, however, rarely consisted of more than two or three trees in each town.

During and after the First World War avenues of honour consisting of trees lining significant streets became a popular form of commemoration. They represented a new egalitarian approach to the commemoration of soldiers where rank was not a consideration: each tree symbolises a person.

Avenues of honour are a uniquely Australian phenomenon. Australians, and in particular Victorians, embraced the idea of planting them more enthusiastically than any other country in the world. Dating from May 1916, the Eurack Avenue of Honour is the earliest known avenue of honour to be planted in Victoria.

By the time of the Second World War avenues of honour had declined in popularity as a means of commemoration. Today it is estimated that over 300 avenues of honour have been planted in Victoria to commemorate service personnel since 1901.

name: Waurn Ponds War Memorial Plaques
description: Two plaques near the Waurn Ponds Memorial Reserve mark new additions to the Avenue of Honour. There is a name plaque for Boer War Serviceman, J.S. Lugg and S.J.H. Cole, a Vietnam Serviceman.

name: Wedderburn Jacka Park Memorial Gateway
description: <FONT size=2>The Wedderburn Jacka Park Memorial Gateway is dedicated to the First World War and the memory of Victoria Cross winner, Captain Albert Jacka.

name: Wedderburn Anglican Church Memorial Gateway
description: <FONT size=2>The Wedderburn Anglican Church Memorial Gateway, on Wilson and Kerr Streets, is dedicated to three fallen Second World War servicemen: Colin Barclay Cameron, Alfred Edwin Harrowfield and George William Finch.

name: Wedderburn Bert Hinkler Memorial Lamp
description: <FONT size=2>The Wedderburn Bert Hinkler Memorial Lamp, in Jacka Park, commemorates the heroic actions of the First World War squadron leader and his contribution to Aviation.

name: Wedderburn RSL Memorial Stone
description: <FONT size=2>The Wedderburn RSL Memorial Stone, beside the RSL building, is dedicated to all those who served in all wars.

name: Welshpool Memorial Hall
description: After World War One and Two, memorial buildings were erected in towns and suburbs across Australia in memory of those who fought and died. One of the most popular types of building was the memorial hall. In some cases memorial halls were built instead of war memorials. Memorial halls typically house honour roll(s) which display the names of local servicemen and women. After their construction memorial halls became important venues for local activity and many are still in use today. Their story is a central part of these communities' histories.

name: Werribee War Memorial Pillar
description: <FONT size=2>The Werribee War Memorial Pillar, on Watton Street, was erected in memory of the First World War and lists the names of all those district servicemen who fought. A plaque was added to the memorial with the dates of the Second World War, Malaya, Korea, Borneo and Vietnam.

name: Werribee Soldiers Memorial Park
description: <FONT size=2>The Werribee Soldiers Memorial Park is located on Duncans Road.

name: Werribee Women's Land Army Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Werribee Women's Land Army Memorial is located next to the R.S.L.

name: Werribee Light Horse Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Werribee Light Horse Memorial Plaque is located inside the racecourse grounds.

description: The Wesburn WWI Memorial, on Station Road and the Warburton Highway,is an ornamental monument featuring a four pillars supporting a pyramid. The structure rests on a two tiered base and is surrounded by rose bushes. The memorial bears the simple inscription, "Duty Nobly Done 1914-1918."

name: Whitfield Memorial Hall

name: Whorouly Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Whorouly Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the Memorial Park Sports Ground, are dedicated to those who paid the supreme sacrifice in the First World War.

name: Wickliffe Soldier Settlement Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Wickliffe Soldier Settlement Memorial Plaque is dedicated to servicemen who returned from the First and Second World Wars to establish the "Narrapumelap" Estate. The plaque was erected on 15th August 1995 as part of the "Australia Remembers" Project, marking the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Wilby Memorial Hall

name: Wilby Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Wilby Memorial Plaque was erected outside the Memorial Hall on Anzac Day 1994. The plaqueis dedicated to fallen servicemen of the Boer War and First World War.

name: Wilby Gallipoli Memorial Tree
description: <FONT size=2>The Wilby Gallipoli Memorial Tree, on Yarrawonga Road, was planted in memory of Corporal Arthur Smith. Smith was killed at Lone Pine in Gallipoli on 8th August 1915, aged 18 years old.

name: Wilby Boer War Memorial
description: Inside the Wilby Cemetery is a family memorial obelisk dedicated in part to Sidney, killed in the Boer War on 14th November 1901.

name: Willatook Soldier Settlement Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Willatook Soldier Settlement Memorial Plaque commemorates those returned servicemen who settled the Woodlands Station between 1920-32.

name: Willaura Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The foundation stone for the Willaura Memorial Hall was laid by General Sir Dallas Brooks on 17th August 1956 and the building unveiled the following year in 1957.

name: Williamstown WWII Memorial Flagpole
description: <FONT size=2>The Williamstown WWII Memorial Flagpole is located near the Cenotaph monument on Nelson Place, Ferguson Street and The Strand.

name: Williamstown Primary School Roll of Honour
description: <FONT size=2>The Williamstown Primary School Roll of Honour is located on the exterior wall of the former school on Cecil Street. The roll lists 444 fallen and returned servicemen who fought in the First World War and were former students of the school.

name: Williamstown RSL Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Williamstown RSL Hall is located at 128 Ferguson Street. Outside the entrance stands the foundation stone from the former Memorial Hall, which was dedicated to the First World War on Anzac Day 1923.

name: Williamstown HMAS Yarra Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Williamstown HMAS Yarra Memorialis located at the north end of the Strand. The memorial comprises of a flagstaff, panels and a mosaic dedicated to the sinking of the HMAS Yarra on March 4th 1942, with the loss of 138 men.

name: Winchelsea Memorial Cairn
description: <FONT size=2>The Winchelsea Memorial Cairn, inside the sports ground, commemorates those district servicemen who paid the supreme sacrifice in the First World War and Second World War.

name: Winjallok War Memorial Stone

name: Wodonga WWII Memorial Seat
description: The Wodonga WWII Memorial Seat, on Hovell Street, features the inscription "1939-1945 At the going down of the sun and in the morning we shall remember them."

name: Woodend Honour Roll
description: <FONT size=2>The Woodend Honour Roll, located beside the creek, commemorates those local servicemen who fought in the First World War, Second World War, the Korea War and the Vietnam War.

name: Woodend RSL Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Woodend RSL Memorial was opened by Brigadier Ian G.G. Gilmore Q.B.E on 9th April 1994. The memorial comprises of a coloured stone pyramid dedicated to the memory of the fallen of all wars, fought in defence of Australia.

The cairn is dedicated to the servicemen and women of the Second World War, including the 8th Division Nursing Sisters.There is also a plaque dedicated to the row of memorial trees behind the monument, which were planted in memory of nursing sisters who lost their lives in the Java Seas and Banka Island in 1942.

name: Woodhouse-Nareeb Memorial Hall
description: The Woodhouse-Nareeb Memorial Hall is dedicated to the memory of all Australian soldiers who were killed or died whilst serving in the Second World War. The hall was opened by Sister Vivian Bullwinkel in 1956.

name: Woods Point RSL Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>This site has been identified but requires further research. Please contact the database administrator if you wish to contribute information to this record.

name: Woolsthorpe Soldiers Memorial Park
description: The Woolsthorpe Soldiers Memorial Park is located on Manifold Road. The land was donated in 1919 for memorial purposes by local landowner William Lindsay, who had three sons serve in the First World War.

name: Woomelang War Memorial

name: Woorinen WWII Memorial Gates
description: The Woorinen WWII Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the sports ground, list the names of those district servicemen who paid the supreme sacrifice between 1939-1945 and feature Lawrence Binyon's famous poem For the Fallen.

name: Woorinen Soldiers Settlement Memorial Wall
description: The Woorinen Soldiers Settlement Memorial Wall is located outside the Memorial Hall on Chillingollah Road. The memorial is dedicated to servicemen who returned from the First World War to settle Woorinen and the surrounding districts.

name: Woosang War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Woosang War Memorial, on the Calder Highway, was erected on 20th October 1919. The memorial resembles a traditional granite obelisk, with the names of those who fell in the First World War inscribed on each face. After the Second World War, names of those district personnel who served were added to the base of the monument.

name: Wunghnu Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The Wunghnu Memorial Gates, at the entrance to the sports ground, are dedicated to those who paid the supreme sacrifice in the First World War and the Second World War. Each pillar features a roll of honour listing the names of the fallen district servicemen.

name: Wycheproof War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Wycheproof War Memorial Obelisk, inside Centenary Park, is dedicated to the First World War and Second World War. The obelisk is an elaborate construction with a carved stone lion at the base of the pediment and stone seats at the base of the monument.

name: Wycheproof St. Michael's War Memorial Church
description: <FONT size=2>The Wycheproof St. Michael's War Memorial Church, located on Webster and Hocking Streets, was opened on 19th November 1967.

name: Wyuna Memorial Hall

description: The Yackandandah War Memorial Pillar is located in front of the rotunda inside the Memorial Gardens on Wellsford and High Streets. The rendered white pillar, rests on a paved red brick cross and bears a plaque inscribed only with, "Lest We Forget."

description: <FONT size=2>A plaque was unveiled in 1995, on the exterior wall of the Yackandandah Athenaeum R.S.L., to commemorate the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

description: <FONT size=2>Inside the Memorial Gardens on Wellsford and High Streets is the Yackandandah WWII Honour Roll. The roll comprises of polished black marble tablets, attached to a white panel and inscribed with the names those district servicemen and women who fought in the Second World War.

name: Yalca Boer War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Yalca Boer War Memorial Plaque, located inside the Yalca North Uniting Church, is dedicated to Ernest James Rowe. On June 12th 1901, Rowe was killed serving with the 5th Victorian Coningent at Wilmansrust in South Africa.

name: Yallook East Loddon Primary School Memorial Gates
description: <FONT size=2>The East Loddon Primary School Memorial Gates feature honour rolls with the names of those district servicemen who fought in the Second World War. Plaques were added to honour those who served Korean and Vietnam Wars.

name: Yarra Glen Avenue of Honour
description: The Yarra Glen Avenue of Honour was dedicated to those who served in the Second World War on 2nd May 1948. A mix of mature oaks and elms were planted along the north side of Anzac Avenue, from the top of the Anzac Avenue hill down to the Memorial Hall.

name: Yarra Glen Boer War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Yarra Glen Boer War Memorial Plaque is located inside the Memorial Hallon theMelba Highway and Anzac Avenue. The plaque commemorates two fallen Boer War servicemen: Jepthah Johnson who was killed in action 18th February 1900 and Andrew Thomas Woodman killed in action 20th August 1900.

name: Yarra Junction RSL Memorial Cross
description: The Yarra Junction RSL Memorial Cross, on Settlement Road, is dedicated to the Australian and New Zealand Forces simply inscribed,"In memory of the fallen, lest we forget, we will remember them."

name: Yarram War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Yarram War Memorial, on Commercial Road, is dedicated to the First and Second World Wars. The memorial comprises of a digger statue standing in the symbolic funereal position, with his rifle held upside down. A plaque was erected, at the base of the statue, to commemorate service of all Australians in 20th Century conflicts.

name: Yarraville Cenotaph
description: The Yarraville Cenotaph is located outside R.S.L. on Stephen and York Streets. The cenotaph comprises of a polished granite obelisk and features the emblems of the Australian Army, Navy and Airforce. Enclosed within a wreath is the inscription "Lest We Forget" and the dates of the First and Second World Wars.

name: Yarrawonga War Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Yarrawonga War Memorial, located on Piper and Belmore Streets, was erected on Remembrance Day 1927. The memorial is an elaborate column crowned by a female figure holding a wreath of victory and at the base, a First World War Digger statue. The Digger stands supported by a marble tree trunk and holds a rifle, the barrel of which is broken. Beneath the female figure is a shield engraved with images of agriculture and prosperity: a sheep, ship, a wheat sheaf and a crossed pick and shovel. The memorial is dedicated to those local men and women who served in the Boer War, First World War and Second World War.

name: Yarrawonga State School WWI Memorial
description: <FONT size=2>The Yarrawonga State School WWI Memorial is located inside the school grounds on Piper and Tom Streets. The monument is dedicated to sixteen former pupils of the School who lost their lives in the First World War. Soon after the war ended sixteen Tamarisk trees were planted in their honour and the small monument erected in 1921. In 1995, the year of the 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War, the monument was re-dedicated to all Australian servicemen and women.

name: Yarroweyah Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Yarroweyah Memorial Hall is located on theMurray Valley Highway and Gooley Street. The memorial comprises of a flagstaff and polished black tablet which lists the names of returned Second World War soldiers, who pioneered the new irrigation settlement with their families in 1947.

name: Yea War Memorial Pillar

On the day of the unveiling, community groups gathered including returned soldiers, girl guides, boy scouts, school children and the Yea Municipal Band. The bandmaster Thorley played the Last Post. The monument was inscribed with the names of fallen district servicemen of the Boer War, First World War and later with the names of those who fell in the Second World War.

name: Yea Wakely Boer War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Yea Wakely Boer War Memorial Plaque is located inside St Lukes Anglican Church, on Lyons and Pelissier Streets. Private Wakely was killed in South Africa on 31st May 1900.

name: Yea Buckingham Boer War Memorial Plaque
description: <FONT size=2>The Yea Buckingham Boer War Memorial Plaque is located inside St Lukes Anglican Church, on Lyons and Pelissier Streets. Sergeant Buckingham died in South Africa on 24th July 1901.

name: Yea WWII Memorial Drinking Fountain
description: The Yea WWII Memorial Drinking Fountain, on Station and High Streets, was erected on 15th August 1995 as part of the Australia Remembers 50th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War.

name: Yea and District Memorial Hospital
description: <FONT size=2>The Yea and District Memorial Hospital, on Station Street, was officially opened on 13th April 1991 by Sir Edward Weary Dunlop. It is dedicated to the memory of the fallen of the Second World War.

name: Yinnar WWI Honour Roll
description: The Yinnar WWI Honour Roll stands next to the Memorial Statue on the main street. The Honour Roll comprises of a marble panel with a triptych concrete support, decorated with ornate lead lettering. It lists the names of all those local servicemen who fought in the First World War.

name: Yinnar Memorial Hall
description: <FONT size=2>The Yinnar Memorial Hall was erected by the community to commemorate the service and sacrifice of those local men and women who served in the Second World War.

name: Yulecart War Memorial
description: The Yulecart War Memorial is located within a large reserve adjoining Muddy Creek on Dartmoor - Hamilton Road. It is built of dressed bluestone blocks, takes the form of a flat topped pyramid, approximately 1.5 metres high. A bronze plaque at the base of the structures states, 'Erected in the memory of Yulecart citizens who made the supreme sacrifice in World Wars I and II.' Small bronze plaques with the names of the fallen have been attached to the sides of the pyramid.

name: South Yarra RSL Hall
